DOC.HEAD: Forty-One Alleged Mobsters Charged In Crackdown
DOC.TEXT: Charges were filed Tuesday against 41 alleged mobsters, including the son of jailed mafia boss ``Little Nicky'' Scarfo, in a statewide sweep that authorities said signals the end of the Scarfo era. Also charged was reputed DeCavalcante crime boss John Riggi and alleged members of the Bruno-Scarfo, Gambino, Colombo, Luchese, Genovese and DeCavalcante organized crime families. Twenty-nine of the defendants were arrested by Tuesday evening, authorities said. They were arraigned before Superior Court Judge Michael Degnan in Essex County. The charges listed in the criminal complaint will be presented to a state grand jury. More than 150 state police fanned out across New Jersey early Tuesday to make the arrests, which came after a year-long investigation based on information from George Fresolone, a member of the Bruno-Scarfo family, police said. Fresolone, who is now in hiding, secretly recorded more than 400 conversations with alleged mobsters and also recorded the initiation ritual of five members into the mob, authorities said. Officials refused to release details about Fresolone, why he became an informant, or whether he was being protected by police. But they said his tapes revealed how the mafia families cooperated with each other and shared illicit profits. Although Nicodemo Scarfo Sr., known as ``Little Nicky,'' is serving a 69-year federal sentence on murder and extortion charges, authorities claim he ran a criminal empire from prison in Illinois via his son, Nicodemo Scarfo Jr., 25. ``The Scarfo organization is in a state of disarray,'' said Col. Justin Dintino, a spokesman for the state police. ``It's been greatly weakened by previous indictments, arrests and killings within the organization. ``If the individuals arrested today ... are convicted, I believe that the final nail in the Scarfo organized crime organization has been placed,'' he said. Besides Riggi and Scarfo Jr., among those apprehended were Anthony ``Tony Buck'' Piccolo, 67, of Collingswood and Joseph ``Scoops'' Licata, 48, of Florham Park, allegedly top advisers to the elder Scarfo. Riggi was released on $100,000 bail Tuesday, but Scarfo Jr., Piccolo and Licata remained in the Essex County Jail. Bail was set at $100,000 each for Scarfo and Piccolo and $150,000 for Licati. Piccolo and Licata were charged with racketeering and leading organized crime. Licata, who also was charged with illegal gambling and theft by extortion, operated loansharking, bookmaking and extortion activities from the East Side Social Club in Newark, the criminal complaint alleged. Riggi, 65, of Elizabeth, was charged with similar offenses, as well as witness tampering, bribery and hindering apprehension, and Scarfo Jr., of Scotch Plains, was charged with promoting gambling and racketeering. The other defendants were charged with various offenses including conspiracy, racketeering and drug distribution. Riggi was convicted last month of extortion and violating federal labor laws and faces up to 65 years in prison. John Mavilla, 43, a member of the Newark Zoning Board, was charged with bribery and official misconduct. He is accused of taking a $2,000 bribe from an allegedly mob-controlled hauling company to approve a use variance. Fresolone tape-recorded conversations from August 1989 until late this summer, when he was initiated into the Bruno-Scarfo crime family, according to a 90-page police affidavit. During the ceremony, the trigger finger of each initiate was pricked. Each man said ``may I burn in hell if I betray my friends in the family'' as he crumpled a piece of burning paper with his bare hands, the affidavit said. A gun and a knife symbolized that members ``live by the gun and die by the gun, live by the knife and die by the knife,'' it said.

DOC.HEAD: Lack of Donors Cited at Transplant Conference
DOC.TEXT: The shortage of donor organs is so acute that hospitals must begin approaching the families of dead patients to save other lives, a transplant specialist said Tuesday. Hospital officials rarely ask grieving families to consider donating their loved ones' organs, said Dr. Calvin Stiller, head of transplant surgery at the University of Western Ontario. When they do, the question is often so awkwardly worded the families immediately reject the idea, he said. ``Sometimes it can be: `you don't want to donate the organs, do you?' '' said Stiller, who estimated that at least 80 percent of possible donor organs go unused. A panel of medical experts discussed the problem here Tuesday during the International Congress of Transplantation Society. Dr. Oscar Salvatierra, chief of University of California-San Francisco's transplant service, said media attention helped find donors in some cases. However, publicity doesn't always work, considering the ``limited donor pool,'' he told the gathering of about 2,700 people representing 47 countries. Last year, 3,993 people in the United States were registered as organ donors. By contrast, 13,290 transplants were performed, according to the United Network for Organ Sharing, which contracts with the federal government to run a national organ distribution network and registry. There are about 20,460 patients waiting for organs, the UNOS said. The public should be ``educated, encouraged and cajoled to donate for love,'' said Dr. Anthony Monaco, professor of surgery at Harvard University. The government could pay the donor, he said. ``Say, everyone could get a government insurance policy ... if they will agree to donate,'' he said. DOC.HEAD: Noble Families, Foreigners Try To Save Poland's Historic Manors
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Tuesday AMs report.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto WAR50 of Aug. 16
DOC.TEXT: Poland's noble families, dispersed around the world or reduced to cramped walkups in their native land, have little but memories of their once elegant estates. Most of the landed gentry's homes have been destroyed since the Communists nationalized their property in the late 1940s. Now, with the Communist regime gone, a last-chance effort is afoot to preserve the remaining historic manors, either by returning them to their former owners or finding new ones. Ludwika Sobanska-Tyszkiewiczowa, born to one of Poland's noblest families and married to another, remembers the vast estate of her birth in the Ukraine. At age 2, she played with nuts on the floor as the Bolshevik revolution of 1917 raged outside the sandbagged windows. As a newlywed on the eve of World War II, she moved to her husband's manor in eastern Poland. Within a year, she was swimming the river outside with her baby strapped to her back and the Red Army in pursuit. Equally vivid are recollections of the carefree opulence of those years between the wars, when the lawns and ballroom of the family palace at Guzow, outside Warsaw, was filled with Poland's dignitaries. With a wistfulness echoed even by Poles of common birth, Mrs. Sobanska lingers on the memory of her family's ``dwory,'' manor houses of the self-sufficient estates on which rural Poland's social and economic system was based for four centuries. Dwory were administrative centers for the surrounding farmland, warehouses and mills. Some were palaces, others large farmhouses. They were built in tune with the vacillating fortunes of Poland's passionately nationalist, clannish and independent nobility, which was 10 percent of the population in the 16th century and among Europe's largest through the 18th century. Of Mrs. Sobanska's properties in Poland, Guzow and a Warsaw mansion still stand, but they no longer belong to her. What did not succumb to war or shifting borders was taken by the new Communist state. Stately homes of Poland's much-romanticized gentry became the orphanages and factory headquarters of People's Poland. Farmland was divided among the peasants. Without money for proper upkeep, dwory fell to ruin and were abandoned, with tragic consequences to the nation's cultural heritage. Forty-five years later, little remains. Of the estimated 20,000 historic homes that survived World War II, only about 2,000 are salvageable. Nostalgia, the desire to right wrongs and capitalist zeal for a good bargain propel the preservation effort. Former owners may apply to reclaim their properties. The Culture Ministry and the post-Communist era's first private real estate companies also are hunting new buyers. ``What is happening in Poland now offers great hope for monuments,'' said Tadeusz Zielinewicz, the ministry's chief building conservator. ``We conservators have always been saying the best way of protecting a monument is a good use, a good owner. The state was not such a good owner.'' In many ways, it is painful work. ``It has all turned into ruin,'' Mrs. Sobanska said after a recent tour of the palace at Guzow, 25 miles east of Warsaw, now headquarters for an adjacent sugar beet factory. ``It will be too late for me, but maybe someone from my family can invest.'' Pravin Shah, a jeans merchant from Wales, stood somberly before the decaying facade and boarded-up windows of a manor in Zdunowo. ``It makes me sad to see something so beautiful standing there, waiting,'' said Shah, who is looking over Polish manors in search of an investment. Grass covered the sweeping drive and sewage choked the ornamental ponds. Sunlight filtering through a hole in the roof touched the few bits of ornamental plaster still in place. The manor was used as an agricultural school, then abandoned for a decade, and a young Polish architect bought it for a song two years ago. He wants to make it into a 55-room hotel and restaurant just 45 minutes north of the capital, but needs $2.5 million. Janusz Lipinski, co-founder of Poland's first real estate agency, Korona, is looking for a Western investor who sees the potential in a country so short of tourist accommodations. Lipinski has 100 or more applications from families seeking to buy back homes that were nationalized after the war. Parliament is working out favorable terms, but most families don't have enough money. This ``re-privatization'' of homes, as opposed to farmland, is encouraged by many people who harbor a deep respect for the stratified society of Poland's past glory. Despite four decades of communism, the names of aristocratic Polish families are easily recalled. In July, when Princess Klaudia Sanguszko visited the family estate near Tarnow in southeastern Poland, former servants lined up to meet her and the town council made her son, called ``the young prince'' by newspapers, an honorary citizen. Purchases by foreigners are more controversial and few have come to fruition. Members of Parliament, nervous about Poland's being ``bought out,'' especially by a united Germany next door, voted last month to prohibit sales of state-owned property to foreigners. Long-term leases are allowed, and privately owned tracts of land can be sold with Interior Ministry permission. Joint-venture companies also can buy. Joanna Onyskiewicz, Lipinski's partner in the Korona agency, is adamant about bringing commercial viability to Poland's historic properties. ``We have no other chance, in a country where the kitty is empty, to save our heritage ourselves,'' she said. Low prices are a large part of the lure. A manor in rundown condition can sell for as little as $1,000. Korona offers a 10-room country house with surrounding gardens that could be remodeled as a small hotel, for a modest total investment of $250,000. There is the stuff of dreams: a gutted, 36-bedroom palace from the early 18th century on 30 acres of parks that once were landscaped. The Rubber Industry Institute will sell it for $200,000. Falling in love with a Polish dwor is just the beginning. ``Buyers face a fantastic amount of red tape,'' Lipinski said. ``You have to be patient in Poland.'' Both initial questions _ Who is the owner and how much does it cost? _ require detective work in the infamous bureaucratic maze. Some properties are government-owned with a state industry as a long-term tenant. Buyers also face the daunting task of a complete renovation, from water pipes to roof, in a nation short of building materials. Strict rules for historical restoration must be followed. An ugly, polluting industry may have been built nearby, Lupinski said, sighing over a paint factory beside a moated, 15th century castle. ``It is a pleasure to work with these buildings but . . . so depressing to see their situation,'' he said, then pointed at the crumbling, lifeless Zdunowo mansion and added: ``That from 45 years of communism.''

DOC.HEAD: Gulf Hotline Provides Information, Sympathetic Ear
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Tuesday AMs report.
Eds: Katharine cq in 3rd graf.
DOC.TEXT: Distraught people telephone the Gulf Support Group for news of relatives stranded in Kuwait and Iraq, but they often end up talking about themselves. ``When people call looking for information, we ask them `Are you all right?' and other questions which will elicit how they are coping,'' Joanna Copley, one of the hotline organizers, said Monday. Ms. Copley's 27-year-old sister, Katharine, was on board a British Airways flight that stopped for fuel in Kuwait on Aug. 2, the day Iraq invaded the emirate. As of Friday, she was still in that occupied country. Many of the callers, like the widow whose only child is in Kuwait, do not want advice. They're just looking for a soothing voice and a friendly ear to hear them work through their grief, anger, frustration and guilt. ``They feel guilty, first, because they are safe in England and secondly, because if they've had a family quarrel they may wish that they'd left on better terms and that there may never be a chance to make things right,'' Ms. Copley said in an interview at the hotline offices. The hotline was set up Aug. 7 as an information clearing house for relatives of Britons stranded in Kuwait and Iraq. It receives up to 200 calls each day, said Ms. Copley, 29, a computer consultant. Her pearls and country-style dress with a large white ribbon belie a steely determination. ``I don't know why I decided to act. Maybe I react faster, or get angry quicker,'' she said. The Foreign Office estimates there are 4,000 British citizens in Kuwait and 500 in Iraq, the largest number of Westerners in the crisis area. Ms. Copley said relatives grow more anxious each day, their fears fueled by reports and rumors swirling around the Persian Gulf. The only Westerner to have been killed in Kuwait since the Aug. 2 invasion is Douglas Croskery, a 45-year-old British businessman shot near the Saudi Arabian border as he tried to leave Kuwait. On Monday, Foreign Secretary Douglas Hurd said diplomats were trying to verify the whereabouts of 123 Britons rounded up in Kuwait. And he said the Foreign Office was working closely with the Gulf Support Group, which includes a member of Parliament, Robert Hayward, among its founders. ``Our officials in Kuwait and Baghdad are doing their utmost _ they are doing a formidable job _ they are doing their utmost to keep in touch with people in difficulty, to find out what is happening,'' Hurd said. ``It's extremely difficult to do so. I pay tribute to Rob Hayward, I pay tribute to people in the same business.'' Calls have come from all over, Ms. Copley said. Britons escaping Kuwait have added to the information from diplomatic sources, but many of the escapees require counseling themselves, Ms. Copley said ``A guy I just got off the phone with admitted that he only had 10 pounds ($19). He worked in Kuwait, his house is in Kuwait and his bank account is there. He has no way of getting money,'' she said. ``These people aren't professionals, they are not wealthy ex-pats (ex-patriots). Many are oil and gas workers with only the clothes they stand up in.'' Trained volunteers have said relatives and escapees are calling ``in a serious state of desperation.'' ``Many can't talk about it without crying, both women and men. I get emotional,'' Ms. Copley said, her voice faltering. The Foreign Office also set up a telephone line for relatives, but it was heavily criticized for making it a pay-per-call number. The Foreign Office subsequently announced that the proceeds would go to charity. Ms. Copley said she would not criticize the Foreign Office, but she added: ``Families are not interested in future charities. They have immediate problems.''

DOC.HEAD: NASA Sets Columbia Launch for Sept. 1
DOC.TEXT: After a three-month delay to fix a hydrogen leak, space shuttle Columbia will lift off on an astronomy mission Sept. 1, NASA says. NASA on Monday set the launch date for the nine- to 10-day mission. Liftoff is scheduled for 1:17 a.m. EDT. Columbia will carry seven astronauts, including four astronomers who will operate the $150 million Astro observatory from the shuttle's cargo bay in their study of ultraviolet light and X-rays from stars, supernovas and other celestial bodies. The mission has been on hold since the fuel leak was found in May. A similar problem with Atlantis prompted the space agency in June to ground the shuttle fleet temporarily. Columbia's flight will be the first shuttle mission since April, when Discovery carried the flawed Hubble Space Telescope into orbit. It also will be the first shuttle flight in five years devoted entirely to scientific research.

DOC.HEAD: Scientists Test Genetically Engineered Rabies Vaccine
DOC.TEXT: Scientists are turning an isolated island into a laboratory to test a genetically engineered rabies vaccine on raccoons. In the first field test of the vaccine in the United States, 26 scientists Monday took boats to Parramore Island and put out 4,000 doses of the vaccine inside baited tubes to attract the 400 raccoons on the strip of land. Over the next year, some of the animals will be caught alive and tested to see if the vaccine produced antibodies to fight rabies. Raccoons are the biggest source of rabies in the United States, often transmitting the virus to dogs and cats that tangle with them. ``If we can control rabies in the raccoon population, we will have come a long way in handling rabies in pets,'' said Dr. Suzanne Jenkins, assistant epidemiologist with the state Health Department. The only sign of man on the 10-mile-long barrier island is a Coast Guard station at one end. ``We knew we needed an island for this test because we wanted limited access and a population of raccoons that would not be wandering off somewhere,'' Ms. Jenkins said. ``Since this is a test, it was felt it would be better if there was not public access. You don't let people into your laboratory. What we've done is create an outdoor laboratory.'' The vaccine, developed by Philadelphia's Wistar Institute, is inserted into small tubes of soft plastic treated with fish oil. ``Then the bait is covered with a crab slurry _ crab parts that have been left out for awhile _ to attract the raccoons,'' said Warren B. Cheston, Wistar associate director. As a raccoon chews on the bait, the liquid vaccine is released in its mouth. The Wistar is the nation's oldest non-profit biomedical research institute. Using genetic engineering, Wistar took from the rabies virus a minute piece of genetic material that induces formation of antibodies, and grafted that fragment onto the harmless vaccinia virus, used in smallpox vaccine. A similar vaccine is being used in Europe and Canada to control rabies in foxes. Scientists believe the Wistar vaccine could have broader application. Robert Miller of the U.S. Department of Agriculture said if the test on Parramore Island works, the department will approve a mainland test of the vaccine. Cheston said Wistar has been working with Pennsylvania to find a test site. The vaccine, engineered in 1982, may be available within five years. Ms. Jenkins said the bait could be spread from airplanes, as is being done in Canada. ``I could see using it to produce corridors of vaccinated animals around population centers to keep rabies out,'' she said. ``You could encircle isolated cases of rabies in the same manner and keep it from spreading.''

DOC.HEAD: Studies Confirm Effectiveness of Transplant Drug
DOC.TEXT: An experimental drug made from a Japanese fungus improves liver transplant patients' chances of survival by up to 20 percent over those taking the standard anti-rejection medication, scientists say. Transplant pioneer Dr. Thomas E. Starzl said Monday that 23 University of Pittsburgh studies of FK-506 confirm earlier findings of its superiority over cyclosporine. Starzl, head of the university's transplant program, told colleagues at a meeting of the International Congress of the Transplantation Society this week in San Francisco that FK-506 poses a lower risk of kidney failure and high blood pressure, side effects of cyclosporine. Both drugs prevent rejection of the transplanted organ immediately after the operation, but FK-506 also prevents delayed rejection, researchers said. ``The initial results are very encouraging,'' said Dr. John Armitage, an assistant professor of surgery at the university who conducted one of the studies. ``There's no question that FK-506 is going to find its place in future treatment.'' The university has given the drug to about 800 patients. The studies, conducted from February 1989 to June of this year, included the first look at how the drug worked on children. Doctors said high doses of steroids were unnecessary for 42 young patients who used FK-506. Some patients need steroids to reduce the toxicity of cyclosporine, but high doses can cause stunted growth, facial puffiness and other problems. ``With FK-506, we're hoping that these children will not require a second or third transplant,'' said Dr. Andreas Tzakis, an associate professor of surgery who conducted the study. ``With the scarcity of organs available for children, this drug may result in organs available for a larger number of children.'' But Dr. James Wolf, president of the United Network for Organ Sharing, said FK-506 could make more people eligible for transplants, creating pressure to find more donors. About 20,000 people are waiting for organ transplants in the United States. The drug, made by Fujisawa Pharmaceutical Co. Ltd. of Osaka, Japan, has been approved for testing exclusively at the University of Pittsburgh, although in a few cases it was given to patients at other hospitals. The drug must undergo further studies before the Food and Drug Administration approves its general use for liver transplant patients. Further tests will be required before it can go on the market for other transplant patients. ``There's no question it's a very effective drug for liver transplants,'' said Dr. Robert Corry, board member of the United Network for Organ Sharing. ``We still don't know enough about it with other organs.'' Dr. Ronald Lieberman, who directs an FDA team studying the drug, said approval will probably take at least two years. In studies on liver transplant patients, the university reported: _Eighteen percent of those taking FK-506 developed high blood pressure, compared with 60 percent of patients on cyclosporine. _Thirteen percent suffered kidney failure, compared with 26 percent for those on cyclosporine. _Potentially fatal infections occurred less frequently and were less severe in patients taking FK-506.

DOC.HEAD: Hawaiian Airlines Workers Charged With Baggage Theft
DOC.TEXT: Twenty-two Hawaiian Airlines employees have been charged with stealing hundreds of thousands of dollars worth of property from baggage, cargo and mail, federal officials said Monday. A 76-count federal grand jury indictment unsealed Monday accuses the employees of stealing items including cash, jewelry, clothing, televisions, stereo components, cameras and video equipment, U.S. Attorney Dan Bent said. Those charged were responsible for loading and unloading baggage on domestic and international flights, Bent said. ``Sometimes baggage would be purposely broken apart, dropped, etc., so that the contents would be revealed and they could identify that it was something worth stealing,'' said Jim R. Freeman, special agent in charge of the FBI's Honolulu office. ``This would be either stolen by those individuals or they would pass the word to confederates down the line,'' Freeman said. Five of the men were arrested Monday, 16 will appear voluntarily for arreignment and one remained at large, officials said. The total value of items stolen was unknown, Bent said. However, the value of items recovered to date is estimated at $50,000. Bent said the conspiracy was brought to the attention of authorities by the Hawaiian Airlines management. The airline cooperated fully with the investigation, Bent said. The maximum punishment for theft of an item worth more than $100 from baggage of cargo or possession of the stolen items is 10 years in prison and a $250,000 fine. Theft from mail or possession of items stolen from mail carries a maximum sentence of five years in prison and a $250,000 fine.

DOC.HEAD: Saddam Keeps Low Profile, But Reported Still In Command
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Tuesday AMs report.
DOC.HEAD: With PM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Saddam Hussein appears to be keeping a low public profile as Iraq's confrontation with the United States intensifies. But Arab diplomats and other knowledgeable sources agree that he's firmly in control in Baghdad. The last time he was seen by the outside world was Aug. 14, when Iraqi's state-run television showed him greeting King Hussein of Jordan, one of his closest allies, at Baghdad Airport. The Jordanian monarch was in Iraq for talks on the crisis following Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait. Saddam, 54, has made several important statements over the last few days, but these have been read on Iraqi television and radio by an announcer. The sources, who all spoke on condition of anonymity, dismissed reports in the Arab media that there have been attempts to assassinate Saddam and his senior aides in recent days. One well-informed source declared: ``He's very much alive. These reports are groundless.'' The source said the Iraqi capital was ``calm, but naturally a little tense'' as Iraq builds up its forces in Kuwait and the United States strengthens its military contingent in Saudi Arabia. Official sources in Cairo reported Monday that the Foreign Ministry received a report from Sayed Abu-Zaid, the Egyptian ambassador in Baghdad, that made no mention of any attempts on Saddam's life. There have been several reported assassination attempts against Saddam since he took power in 1979. Baghdad Radio reported that Saddam met Monday with Indian External Affairs Minister Indir Kumar to discuss ``bilateral relations.'' The meeting was attended by Iraqi Foreign Minister Tariq Aziz, it said. It also reported that the president sent a close confidant, Saadoun Hammadi, to Moscow on Monday. Hammadi is a member of the ruling 11-man Revolutionary Command Council headed by Saddam. A senior military source in an Arab capital said Monday that he was in daily telephone contact with Saddam and that the Iraqi leader was clearly in control in Baghdad. ``We know how President Saddam is doing because we're in touch with him constantly by telephone,'' said the source, who spoke on condition that his name and nationality were not disclosed. He told The Associated Press: ``We talk to him all the time.'' This source said Saddam is ``living with his in-laws in Baghdad. He's not hiding out in a military base as everyone thinks.'' He gave no other details. Nor did he explain why the president should be living with his wife's family and not in his heavily guarded palace on the banks of the Tigris River, or in his command bunker. But if the report is correct, it could be that Saddam is concerned about the possibility of a U.S. air or missile strike against the palace or other buildings he is known to frequent. Egypt's Middle East News Agency last week quoted a Palestinian official as saying he met Saddam at a military complex outside Baghdad, where the Iraqi leader, ``haggard and pale,'' was protected by heavy security following a reported assassination attempt. During the 1980-88 war with Iran, Saddam was often not seen in public for periods of up to two weeks. But the state-controlled media bombarded Iraq's 16 million people with photographs and television footage of their leader in uniform with his troops or meeting commanders.

DOC.HEAD: Heat, Fear of Chemical Weapons, Dominate Life in Desert
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Tuesday AMs report.
DOC.HEAD: With PM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: By midday Monday, the temperature in the Saudi desert was probably 130 degrees. But Lt. Col. Jim Mattis wouldn't know _ his thermometer only reaches 120. The desert is a cruel place, as the Marine platoon in the hills several miles from the nearest road is finding out. By 8:30 a.m. Monday, the sun was so hot a group of Marines in a mortar unit gladly remained hidden under their camouflaged tents. ``We just try to rest when we can and stay cool when we can,'' said one. In line with Defense Department rules, neither he nor any of the enlisted men could give their names, and the location of their unit could not be disclosed. The Marines' tents _ covered with camouflaged netting _ were so well concealed that only their vague outline could be distinguished in the brown sand. A group of Marines relaxed on tarps under one big tent, while smaller numbers manned the mortars and served as lookouts. The Marines have trained in the Mojave Desert, but the United States has not been involved in a desert campaign since the United States and Great Britain joined together to defeat the Germans in North Africa in 1943. Because of the heat, the men usually keep watch just two hours at a time. In their off hours, they sleep, eat, bone up on desert warfare tactics and perform chores such as cleaning their guns. All Marines are issued three packages of food _ MREs for Meal Ready to Eat _ daily. Each package contains about 3,000 calories in the form of crackers, a beef or chicken meal, cheese, cookies and dehydrated fruit. Water is one of the biggest challenges in the desert; Marines are told to drink five gallons a day, which is brought in by ``water buffalo,'' or military trailers used to haul water. To ward off the sun, they cover their skin, use sunscreen and wear hats and sunglasses. Even so, they are only kept out in the desert for three days before rotating back to the makeshift barracks, usually big air-conditioned rooms. While the heat is overpowering, several Marines said their biggest fear is the threat of chemical weapons. Each Marine has a gas mask, plus three vials of Atropen, an antidote to nerve gas. Should a Marine be exposed to the gas, he must inject himself with the agent. For the Marines, one of the biggest frustrations is being out of touch with world events. Even. Maj. Gen. John Hopkins, head of the 7th Marine Expeditionary Brigade, said he had no time to listen to the radio to find out what the reaction in the United States was to the deployment.

DOC.HEAD: Refugee Flow at Border Slowing; Life in Kuwait Growing More Dangerous
With PM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Scores of Arabs have fled Kuwait into Saudi Arabia by walking across the desert or slipping past Iraqi soldiers by car, but now only a few Western refugees are making the run. Three Britons who made it across the border on Sunday were the last reported Western escapees along that route, border area residents said Monday. One Saudi resident, speaking in a telephone interview, said fewer Kuwaiti families were arriving but that dozens of Egyptians, Pakistanis and Indian workers were walking part of an 80-mile stretch to reach Saudi Arabia. ``The ones coming in just look very confused,'' said the resident, who could see the refugees at the Saudi Arabian border checkpoint at Khafji. ``The ones who go on foot seem to just move through the dense Iraqi troop movements on the other side,'' he said, speaking on condition of anonymity. ``But the cars do not seem to be coming across now as they used to do in earlier days.'' Some travelers said Iraqi troops and tanks were apparently cutting off open border areas which hundreds of Westerners and Kuwaitis have fled across since Iraqi President Saddam Hussein ordered his troops into Kuwait on Aug. 2. Attempting a border crossing can be a deadly maneuver, refugees said. ``They shoot at any approaching car,'' said a traveler who arrived in Khafji late last week. ``The (soldiers) fired at a car behind me and injured a 37-year-old woman in her right thigh.'' Life inside Iraqi-occupied Kuwait is also growing more dangerous. Iraqi television, which is now broadcast in Kuwait, announced last week that anyone hoarding food would be executed. One traveler told the Khafji residents that the Sultan Center, a large grocery store in the Kuwait city suburb of Salmiya, was completely out of provisions. But Kuwaitis say their families usually have large quantities of food stored, usually sufficient for a month. Some Kuwaitis in Saudi Arabia said they contact relatives and friends still in Kuwait by car telephones that work on the other side of the border. Those inside Kuwait say they are not permitted to buy anything in large quantities. Iran's Islamic Republic News Agency quoted Iranians returning from Kuwait as saying foodstuffs were scarce, the city bazaar was closed and the general situation in Kuwait was tense. ``They say Iraqi soldiers are taking position here and there throughout Kuwait and especially in al-Ahmadi port with tanks and armored vehicles roaming in the city streets amid sporadic overnight shooting,'' the agency reported. The agency estimated that 10,000 Iranians of the 100,000-strong Iranian community in Kuwait have returned to Iran. Kuwaitis fleeing their country into Saudi Arabia often arrive disheveled and dejected, their eyes bloodshot. They huddle around transistor radio listening to reports from Free Kuwait Radio that are broadcast clandestinely somewhere in the Persian Gulf. Their newspapers, among the liveliest in the Arab world despite a censorship clamped since 1986, are beginning to emerge in other capitals _ Al-Qabas in London, Al-Anbaa in Cairo and shortly Al-Seyassah in Saudi Arabia. The others have yet to make a comeback. Kuwaiti embassies in gulf countries have been looking after the refugees, arranging accommodations, financial assistance and medical care. The younger men invariably say they have decided on one thing _ to see that their families are settled in safer countries, and then they will join the resistance at home. ``We will fight, win or die,'' said Bandar al-Shallahi, a journalist with the Kuwait News Agency. ``It's pointless to live without a country. And we will reinstate our emir, Sheik Jaber al-Ahmed al-Sabah, whether Saddam likes it or not.''

DOC.HEAD: State Department Assures Worried Callers
DOC.NOTE: Eds: DELETES grafs 7-8 pvs: An administration ... few days. to reflect that State Department does not cally every day, picks up 9th garf pvs, bgng: ``Information that...
DOC.BYLINE: With AM-US-Gulf, Bjt ^By W. DALE NELSON
DOC.TEXT: At a long table in a windowless room in the State Department, U.S. consular officers answer about 4,000 telephone calls a day from worried relatives of the Americans whom President Bush described Monday as hostages in Iraq and Kuwait. ``It was heavier in the beginning and it seems to kind of go in cycles, depending on events,'' said Judy Baroody, press officer for the special task force set up by the department to deal with the crisis in the Persian Gulf. Ms. Baroody said from 60 to 80 officers staff the telephone bank 24 hours a day, in shifts of 15 at one time. ``They have a system of data banks in which they keep names and information about American citizens to provide to relatives,'' Ms. Baroody said. At all times, one officer is detailed to handle special cases such as those with particular medical needs or small children. She said this officer also deals with the families of those in Iraqi custody, such as the 12 the department said were taken from hotels in Kuwait's capital and moved to undisclosed locations. ``Information that might be given out would be what kind of advice is being provided to Americans in Kuwait and Iraq, whether the borders are closed and whether it is safe to cross by a land route,'' the press officer said. She said they also provide information on food supplies available, curfews and problems involving exit permits. Ms. Baroody described the room as a typical office with fluorescent lighting in the ceiling, like others in the State Department. It is an interior room with no windows. There are more than 3,000 Americans and thousands of other foreign citizens now under Iraqi control. The administration had been reluctant to call them hostages, saying no demands had been made as conditions for their release. Bush, addressing the national convention of the Veterans of Foreign Wars in Baltimore, demanded the release of the foreigners and said that ``whatever these innocent citizens are called, they are in fact hostages.'' Iraqi leader Saddam Hussein said in Baghdad Sunday that he would free the foreign nationals if Bush withdrew U.S. forces from Saudi Arabia and if a worldwide trade embargo against Baghdad were lifted.
Eds: The number for the 24-hour telephone bank is (202) 647-0900.

DOC.HEAD: Research Monkeys Wreak Havoc on Sensitive Islands
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Tuesday AMs report.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto MH1 sent Aug. 20.
DOC.TEXT: Residents of the Florida Keys are fed up with Bausch and Lomb's monkey business. The vision-care giant put thousands of monkeys on two small, deserted islands more than a decade ago to breed, offering a steady supply of laboratory animals to biomedical researchers. But people who live near the islands where the rhesus monkeys have been allowed to run free, fouling the water and turning lush mangrove trees into useless skeletons, object to what they deem needless environmental destruction. ``It looks like a war zone right now. Just like Vietnam,'' said James McElroy, who's part of a grass-roots anti-monkey campaign. The rhesus monkeys have been good business since they were first brought over from India 18 years ago. Handlers regularly dispense monkey chow and capture more than a thousand each year, generating more than $1.5 million in annual sales. The breeding colonies became more important to U.S. researchers after India, Pakistan and Bangladesh banned monkey exports in the late 1970s, said Dr. Joseph Held, vice president for primate research at Charles River Laboratories, the division of Bausch and Lomb that runs the islands. And because they are untainted by Herpes B virus and other infections from the outside world, they are much more valuable than other primates destined for the nation's laboratories, Held said. ``It's the cleanest, healthiest commercial production colony in the world,'' Held said. Most of the animals are sold to labs doing advanced neurological research; none are used for eye-care tests, the company says. More than 1,900 breeding animals and several thousand of their offspring roam on 300 acres of partially submerged wetlands on Key Lois and Raccoon Key, another company-owned island several miles away. Even Charles River Laboratories, which is under a consent agreement to replace damaged trees and reduce the population, agrees that the monkeys have made a mess of things. The rhesus stripped the leaves from thousands of red mangroves, a protected species, and now struggle to find shade in the Florida sun. Their waste has fouled the waters, leaving a band of yellowish-brown algae that chokes out marine life. ``They weren't too noticeable until the vegetation began disappearing. That's when people became alarmed,'' McElroy said. Even armed with the necessary permits from pro-growth Keys officials, humans could never get away with such destruction, said Curt Kruer, a biologist and Audobon Society leader who has studied Keys wetlands for 13 years and can see Key Lois from his backyard. ``You could take all the mangroves destroyed for condo projects in the Keys in the past 10 years and it wouldn't come close to this,'' Kruer said as he poled his boat in for a close look at Key Lois last week. ``Where's it all going to end?'' The state owns everything below the high-water line, including the area where most of the mangroves have been destroyed, and environmental officials ordered the company to clean up those grounds years ago. Charles River Laboratories fenced in and replanted some trees, but disputed the boundary and sued the state in 1986. Nothing much changed until the two sides quietly agreed to a settlement in May that would allow the company to phase out the monkeys over 20-30 years. McElroy, Kruer and other Keys activists raised a ruckus. Gov. Bob Martinez and the Florida Cabinet, eager to improve their environmental image in this election year, responded by scuttling the agreement and deciding to go after Charles River for destroying state property instead. ``They just stripped all the state land and left it bare,'' Martinez said at the June 26 cabinet meeting. ``I'd like to see if we can prosecute.'' Ken Plante, general counsel for the Florida Department of Environmental Resources, says the title dispute must be resolved first. A status hearing has been scheduled for Aug. 30. The department is still trying to find surveyors willing to brave the monkeys and measure the property, Plante said. Meanwhile, the company is quietly scouting out alternative sites where the breeding operation can be moved, said Barbara Kelley, a spokeswoman at Bausch and Lomb's Rochester, N.Y., headquarters.

DOC.HEAD: Environmentalists, Consumer Groups Hail Texas Open Records Rules
DOC.TEXT: Texans soon will be able to see previously secret documents stemming from legal battles, including those fought over sensitive environmental and product-liability cases. Civil liberties advocates, good-government groups and media organizations are hailing the state Supreme Court's first-in-the-nation procedural change, which takes effect Sept. 1. ``It's not that we expect, on the first day, a line of people walking into the courthouse,'' said Jim Harrington, Texas Civil Liberties Union legal director. ``But the rules will turn the files there into a public library for our watchdogs.'' Environmentalists and consumer organizations were particularly thrilled by the change, adopted in April at the request of the Legislature. They frequently have won settlements only to have sealed court records keep information on toxic substances and other hazards unavailable. ``If a manufacturer loses a lawsuit, such as exploding gas tanks on an automobile, that information can't be sealed up and filed away in a file drawer someplace,'' said Tom Smith, director of Public Citizen, a consumer rights group in Austin. Maintaining open records ``can do nothing but help protect the public,'' said Mary Kelly, an Austin lawyer and legal coordinator for the Sierra Club in Texas. But Dane Harris, president of the Texas Association of Business, said the rule could hurt businesses that may become targets of lawsuit-minded attorneys on ``fishing expeditions.'' ``We feel like it opens up the opportunity for people to become aware of sometimes competitive, trade-sensitive information. We think it invites needless litigation,'' said Harris, whose organization urged the justices not to adopt the rule. ``We feel like just having these records available for whoever wants to go on a fishing expedition is not conducive to a pro-business climate that will maintain and create jobs.'' Some defense lawyers also have claimed the threat of publicizing court documents would hurt their chances of obtaining settlements. The rules, adopted by a 5-4 vote, say no court order or opinion may be sealed. Other records are presumed open and can be sealed only by showing a ``serious or substantial interest.'' The new rules open ``discovery'' documents _ those exchanged by opposing lawyers before trial _ if they contain information that could affect public safety or governmental operations. ``It is extremely important in that some of the best information on hazardous chemicals has been developed through litigation,'' said Ms. Kelly. ``In litigation, everyone is motivated to find out as much as they can through discovery. A lot of information on the hazards of asbestos was blown open through litigation.'' The rules do not cover divorce records and other family matters, some monetary amounts in settlements and pretrial matters involving trade secrets. Madelyn Applebaum, spokeswoman for the Association of Trial Lawyers of America, said Texas was the first to adopt the rules, although Florida has since adopted such a policy and efforts are under way in New York to release records. She said two weeks ago the Rhode Island governor vetoed a bill that would have adopted similar rules.

DOC.HEAD: Mystery Safe Opened; No Hidden Treasures
DOC.TEXT: A old safe found in a creek was cracked open before a crowd of onlookers, revealing no gold, jewels or cash _ just mud and rust. A locksmith and his son pried open the door of the two-ton, 6-foot safe Monday, prompting a cheer from the crowd. Inside the rusty iron box were empty shelves coated with silt and mud from Mill Creek, where it was thought to have been dumped after the old state Capitol burned in 1935. ``Have you seen Geraldo?'' state Treasurer Tony Meeker joked, referring to Geraldo Rivera's much-ballyhooed TV program on the opening of Al Capone's vault in Chicago. Like Salem's safe, Capone's vault was virtually empty. Since no one knew for sure that Salem's safe was only heavyweight litter, the opening was awaited with hope of finding valuables or historical artifacts. James Jones, coordinator of the state Historical Properties Commission, said it wasn't a total loss _ the safe has historical value and could become a museum piece.``I'm just glad it's in such good shape inside,'' he said. Jones and about 100 volunteers had removed the safe from the creek last week and set it up on the sidewalk in front of his office.

DOC.HEAD: USS Eisenhower's Surveillance Planes Fly Around the Clock
With PM-Gulf-Cheney Bjt
DOC.TEXT: One man who acts as America's electronic eyes and ears over a good part of Saudi Arabia says the skies are filled with a constant stream of U.S. aircraft from Operation Desert Shield. ``There's just a whole ton of people up there,'' said Lt. Mark Smith, a Navy radar officer aboard the surveillance aircraft E-2C Hawkeye. A bit clumsy in appearance but more high-tech in performance, Smith's twin-engine turboprop is adorned with a flat radar disk similar to the much larger AWACS (Airborne Warning and Control System) planes that also have been deployed to Saudi Arabia's defense against a possible Iraqi invasion. Smith and his colleagues fly high above northwestern Saudi Arabia to search out any possible threat from the air or the ground to the battle group of the carrier U.S.S. Eisenhower, sailing far below in the Red Sea. Because the crew _ with what its men call their ``electronic goodies'' _ can peer far into the skies, they provide the battle group with a large envelope of security. They can warn the ships of any missiles, aircraft or vessels that might appear beyond the horizon undetected by the ships' own radar systems. And today in the skies above Saudi Arabia, tension and activity are high. U.S. aircraft are appearing ``about every 30 miles or so in a constant stream _ either inbound or outbound,'' Smith said. The crew might have 30 to 40 such friendly targets to follow at a time. Some of them most probably are the C-130 transport aircraft recently allowed to operate out of the United Arab Emirates. The federation of sheikdoms on the southern edge of the Persian Gulf has now joined Saudi Arabia in openly granting access to U.S. forces to its strategic territory. Squadrons of F-16s, F-4s and F-15E jet fighters, A-10 bombers and the F-117A stealth fighter-bombers are packing the skies. The Pentagon has pressed so many transport aircraft into service for the Saudi operation that they've even turned to the Civilian Reserve Air Fleet for the use of some U.S. commercial aircraft. ``As far as I can tell, the Iraqis are staying on their side, and we're a long way away from them. That suits me just fine,'' Smith said. Because of the heightened state of activity, Smith said the carrier's two Hawkeyes must be in the skies 24 hours a day. ``We're flying around the clock and we don't stop any more,'' said Smith during a 5:30 a.m. breakfast break on the carrier. The Eisenhower and its air wing had been scheduled to return stateside next month until the Persian Gulf crisis diverted them to the Red Sea. ``We're racking up a lot of flight hours now that we normally wouldn't at the end of a deployment,'' Smith said, adding that each crew takes to the skies twice a day, sometimes six to eight hours at a time. The flying isn't the high profile fly-boy job held by the carrier's jet fighter and bomber pilots, but the role is just as vital. And despite their grueling schedule, the crews must fly with a high degree of alertness. Should an enemy aircraft appear, their warning from the Hawkeye might be the first to alert fellow seamen manning the battle group's air defense weapons. ``If we make an error, a lot of people pay a big price, if we don't find somebody or something that's on the way in,'' Smith said.

DOC.HEAD: Wheat Surplus; French Thirst for Fruit Juice; Wheat, Czechs?; Braille Guide
DOC.TEXT: World wheat production in 1990 is at record levels and expected to exceed consumption, leading to the lowest U.S. prices in two years, according to the Agriculture Department. The report, released Monday, says U.S. wheat supplies are forecast up 18 percent from last year to 3.3 billion bushels, with consumption up only 8 percent _ enough to use 2.4 billion bushels. This will lead to farm prices of about $1 per bushel less than last year's $3.72, USDA says. ``Record 1990 wheat crops are forecast in Kansas and North Dakota, the two largest producing states, pushing U.S. production over 2.7 billion bushels for only the third time,'' said the USDA. ``Despite the large U.S. crop and lower prices, slack world imports and increased competitor supplies will lead to lower U.S. exports this year,'' said the department. However, those losses are expected to be more than offset by greater feed use domestically. The general trade embargo against Iraq, sponsored by the United Nations, is expected to cut about 3 percent from U.S. wheat and flour exports, according to the department. That country, opposed by the United States for its invasion of Kuwait, has been the eighth largest importer of U.S. wheat. It has been the seventh largest importer of wheat from overall world sources.

Health conscious French are beginning to turn from wine to fruit juice, with Made in the U.S.A. on many of the labels. ``U.S. juice sales to France during 1985-88 jumped nearly 40 percent to $10.7 million,'' said Edwin Porter, the U.S. agricultural attache in Paris. Porter co-wrote an article on the subject for the Agriculture Department's AgExporter Magazine with Martine Brunet, a marketing specialist. They said an increasing demand for healthy food and a decline in alcoholic beverage consumption are driving the fruit juice market in France. Orange juice is the favorite, with the French preferring their juice in glass containers rather than paper ones. American grapefruit juice also is popular, said Porter and Martine. The French import nearly all of their fruit juices. ``In 1988, the United States shipped to France 10,798 tons of fruit juices and concentrates, worth $11.2 million, of which orange juice and orange concentrate accounted for $7.95 million,'' Porter and Martine said.

A U.S. agricultural trade and development mission will be visiting Bulgaria, Czechoslovakia and Yugoslavia next month to expand sales of American products. ``These countries imported more than $200 million in U.S. agricultural commodities last year,'' said Richard Crowder, agriculture undersecretary. ``In addition, these markets represent good opportunities for increased U.S. exports, particularly for bulk commodities such as grains and soybean meal.'' The trade mission is tentatively scheduled for Sept. 15-29. It will include officials from the departments of agriculture and state and the U.S. Agency for International Development.

The Agriculture Department will be releasing its first Braille publication this week as part of an effort to diversify its work force. The document is called ``Framework for Change: Work Force Diversity and Delivery of Programs.'' It describes a 10-year plan to expand job opportunities within the department to more people with disabilities.

DOC.HEAD: VOA Beams Worlds of Cautions to Americans in Kuwait
DOC.TEXT: U.S. citizens who want to escape from Kuwait by crossing the desert receive daily words of caution by radio from the State Department. The messages, beamed by the Voice of America and also carried by the British Broadcasting Corp., change daily but in general advise Americans to know the hazards of setting out across the desert. The VOA carries the messages hourly during the morning and evening hours in which the Voice of America is beamed into the Arab world. The message being carried late Monday said: ``The U.S. State Department advises American citizens that the situation at this time in Baghdad and Kuwait is unclear. Iraqi officials have reinforced their statement that Americans will be gathered and moved. Our embassies are in contact with American communities . . . and advising them to stay in their homes. We have had reports of individuals who have been able to cross the border without incident, but there can be no guarantee for the safety of those attempting to cross. We are aware that American citizens may be considering departure from Kuwait via the desert. We advise Americans who are considering this route that there is a confirmed report that at least one person has died attempting to cross the desert. There are also unconfirmed, repeat unconfirmed, rumors that others may have died attempting this route. We believe American citizens should be aware of this information before attempting any overland travel out of Kuwait.''. The report referred to as confirmed involved a British national. About 500 Americans already have been able to sneak into Saudi Arabia, penetrating lax Iraqi security, but a caravan of others who tried to flee were forced to beat a sweltering retreat. The clandestine departures reduced the number of civilian Americans in Kuwait to 2,500, according to State Department figures. Also stranded are 500 to 600 Americans in Iraq.

DOC.HEAD: Ambassador Says Poland Needs Debt Relief
DOC.TEXT: Poland's move to democracy and a market economy is threatened by its foreign debt of nearly $41 billion, at least part of which should be forgiven, says the country's new ambassador to Washington. ``If there would be danger of the Polish reform breaking down because of debt, that would have consequences in Europe and maybe beyond,'' Ambassador Kazimierz Dziewanowski told a U.S. Chamber of Commerce gathering Monday. The Bush administration has opposed debt forgiveness in principle but there is some sentiment for it in Congress. About $3 billion of the debt is owed U.S. creditors. The new government feels justified asking some debt forgiveness because the money ``was taken by the former regime, and we do not know exactly what was done with it,'' said Dziewanowski, who was a writer and journalist during the communist era. The Gulf crisis has complicated matters, he said, but Poland is both optimistic and patient about prospects for obtaining ``at least some rescheduling of our debt payments.'' He said it was an odd twist that Iraq, the target of a worldwide trade embargo ``during this difficult period of our economic reform... is one of those few countries which owes us money,'' about $500 million. While taking issue with a report that the Iraqi debt to Poland was $3 billion, the ambassador did not dispute that part represented arms shipments. Poland stands to lose another half billion dollars as a result of cuts in supplies of once-subsidized Soviet oil, he said. Dziewanowski, in Washington less than a month, told the Chamber that Poland is framing new lenient regulations for foreign investment under which ``we will try to meet (foreign investors) at least half way, or maybe the greatest part of the way.'' He said the new rules will provide for unlimited transfer of profits abroad, end pre-screening of investments in all but the most strategic industries, allow up to 100 percent foreign ownership, use of Western accounting methods, and simplify income tax at a 20 percent rate, half the former level. The $50,000 minimum investment requirement will be dropped, opening the doors to small Polish-American businesses, the ambassador added. An American Chamber of Commerce will be opened in Poland by November, it was announced.

DOC.HEAD: 10 Dead in Mudslide
DOC.TEXT: A mudslide rolling down a mountainside buried part of a remote hamlet in the southern state of Oaxaca, killing 10 people and injuring five, the government news agency Notimex reported. Notimex said Monday that another four people, believed to be children, were missing from the mudslide Sunday night. State district attorney Benito Caballero Julian was quoted by Notimex as saying the tragedy caused by heavy rain occurred in the small village of La Luz, high in the Juarez mountain range 270 southeast of Mexico City. It said none of the five hurt were in serious condition.

DOC.HEAD: Families Get Confirmation of Worst Fears: Relatives Are Mideast Hostages
With PM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Americans held by Iraq aren't the only hostages. Mothers and fathers, sons and daughters, and husbands and wives seeking word from those trapped overseas are captives in a waiting game that began when Iraq invaded Kuwait early this month. President Bush's decision Monday to label the estimated 3,000 Americans in Iraq and Kuwait hostages confirmed waiting families' worst fears. ``I've felt all the time that they were hostages,'' said Marjorie Walterscheid of Jacksboro, Texas. Her husband, Rainard, 52, is among 35 Americans moved from a Baghdad hotel to an undisclosed location. Iraq announced that some Westerners have been placed near military targets as shields against U.S. attack, heightening fears among relatives. ``What happens if there's a shooting war?'' asked the Rev. Edwin Davis of Koran, La. ``I'd like to be over there with them ... hold my daughter's hand.'' The 68-year-old minister said he's haunted by visions of the ordeal facing his daughter, Kuwaiti son-in-law and their two teen-age children. When he tries to sleep, he imagines the Middle East heat and hears the helicopters that buzzed in the background the last time his daughter called home, the night Iraqi tanks swarmed into Kuwait. Since the invasion, little news has reached relatives in the United States. State Department officials have contacted some families. Others simply wait. ``It scares me to death ... that (the Iraqis) would try and use them as bargaining chips,'' said Kitty Dooley of Hopkinsville, Ky. She last heard from her 40-year-old son hours after Iraqi troops arrived in Kuwait City, where he managed several fast-food restaurants. Jean Pryor is one of the lucky ones. After a roundabout trip, a message from her daughter in Kuwait made it home to Pelham, Ala., last week. It said: ``I'm fine. I don't think I'm in danger. They have moved me from the city to another province.'' Pryor, who isn't sure who ``they'' are, said the brief reassurance answered her prayers, but it is now more than a week old. Persian Gulf tensions have escalated. ``I get up very early in the mornings so that by the time the news goes off at night, my body goes to sleep,'' said Pryor, whose daughter moved to Kuwait three years ago. ``But my heart is still awake. It never sleeps.'' Iraq's official news agency said Monday that Westerners would be used to shield military targets against American attack. The government also has warned that those who hide foreigners will face the ``severest punishment.'' Later, Iraq said the Westerners would be freed only if the United States withdrew all troops and lifted an international trade embargo. ``We have been reluctant to use the term hostage,'' Bush told the Veterans of Foreign Wars in Baltimore. ``But when Saddam Hussein specifically offers to trade the freedom of those citizens of many nations he holds against their will in return for concessions, there can be little doubt that ... they are in fact hostages.'' Laureen Utz Aljazireh, an American visiting relatives in Minnesota when Iraq invaded Kuwait, awaits news of her Palestinian husband who worked in Kuwait. ``The way things are going, I don't think the outcome is going to be very good,'' she said. ``We live by the TV now,'' said Lynda Parker of Vidor, Texas. ``I live with a telephone in one hand and the remote control in the other.'' Her husband, Bobby, 49, is a Kuwait Petroleum Co. worker missing since the invasion.

DOC.HEAD: Announced Tactic of Using Civilians as Protection Sets Precedent
With PM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The tactic of putting civilians in harms' way to deter attack has been used in 20th-century combat by Germany, Britain and the Viet Cong, but scholars say Saddam Hussein is the first leader to announce it as a tactic. The Iraqi president said he would prevent more than 11,000 Westerners from leaving Iraq and Kuwait until the United States withdraws from the Persian Gulf and lifts the blockade against his country. They will be deployed at strategic military and industrial points in Iraq to deter assault, Baghdad Radio said. Over the weekend Saddam said, ``the presence of the foreigners with Iraqi families at vital targets might prevent an attack.'' U.S., British and other forces have been massing in the gulf since Iraq invaded Kuwait Aug. 2 and annexed it. Adam Roberts, professor of international relations at Oxford University, said Hussein's public announcement was not only highly irregular, it was illegal in terms of the 1949 Geneva Convention IV on international rules in time of war. Iraq signed the convention. Although the international force in Saudi Arabia is not at war with Iraq, the Westerners were detained as a result of Iraq's invasion. Clause 28 of the convention reads: ``The presence of protected persons may not be used to render certain points or areas immune from military operations.'' Protected persons in this context, Roberts said, means civilians, both local and foreign. But he said there were several instances of countries using foreigners and civilians in this way. The most recent was during the Vietnam War. Early in the war, he said, the communist Viet Cong insurgents in South Vietnam forced local civilians to march ahead of its troops to try to prevent enemy troops from opening fire. During World War II the Germans placed Allied prisoners of war on rooftops in occupied Holland to deter Allied bombers. Another case of human shields was disclosed by old official documents declassified last year. This was Britain's ``minesweeping taxi,'' used during the Arab rebellion in 1939 during the British mandate over Palestine. The documents showed that taxis owned by known Arab troublemakers were commandeered with their drivers and put at the head of British convoys in case the road was mined. Lord Dufferin of Ava, who was then parliamentary undersecretary at the Colonial Office, commented at the time: ``British lives are being lost and I don't think we ... can protest squeamishly about measures taken by the men in the front line.'' B. J. Bond, a professor of war studies at London University, said he knew of no official ``human shield'' threat by a national leader in modern times. Donald Watt, professor of international history at the London School of Economics, said he believed there were cases during World War II where the Germans used civilians to drive over mine fields. ``But as for using hostages as a kind of shield as an instrument of state policy, you would have to go back an awfully long way,'' he said. Watt said there had been a medieval custom whereby a person signing a treaty gave the other party a close relative as a hostage, ``a guarantee of your word.'' David Capitanchik, senior lecturer in politics at Aberdeen University, Scotland said the human shield idea ``is standard practice for terrorist groups who take hostages. They always place the hostages near the bombs. ``But is it not easy to think of a case in this century of a government using human sandbags in this way. It is not easy to recall a case where this is implemented as an act of state policy.''

DOC.HEAD: Tourists Flock Back to Yosemite After Fires
DOC.TEXT: John and Linda Disosway say whenever they plan to visit a national park on their vacation, it catches fire. The Atlanta couple and their three children were among the thousands who flocked to Yosemite Valley on Monday when roads reopened after two lightning-caused fires forced an 11-day closure and scorched more than 36 square miles. The 1,130-square-mile park in California's Sierra Nevada had closed Aug. 9 for the first time in its 100-year history. The fires were among 1,300 lightning-caused blazes this month that have burned more than 420 square miles throughout the state, which in its fourth year of drought. ``We were in Yellowstone right after it burned,'' Mrs. Disosway said Mpnday, referring to major fires in that park two years ago. ``Our timing's off.'' They had worried that the park wouldn't reopen in time for their one-day visit to see such landmarks as El Capitan, a 7,564-foot sheer rock face and Half Dome, a rounded granite peak that broke in half. Yosemite Falls, the tallest in North America with a drop of 2,425 feet, is another attraction. Vehicles stretched for 1{ miles as people waited for rangers to open the entrance to the valley floor. Most campsites there and all rooms in Yosemite Lodge were filled in advance. The fires contained over the weekend left hills and bushes blackened, but they did not penetrate Yosemite Valley, thanks to thousands of firefighters. Park officials prepared colored maps to indicate where the fires burned. Newlyweds Tim and Erika Dallacqua of Ventura County were honeymooning in Yosemite. They had switched their wedding to a campground higher up after learning that the valley floor was closed. ``We were married right on the riverbed,'' said Erika. ``It was gorgeous.'' Linda Nadel of Ridgway, Colo., said she would have found another vacation site had Yosemite remained closed. ``But I wanted to come, so I'm glad it's open,'' she said.

DOC.HEAD: Right-Wing Legislator Proposes Using Palestinians As `Shields'
With PM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: An extreme right-wing member of Parliament has proposed that Palestinians be used as ``human shields'' against an Iraqi attack, much as Iraq's Saddam Hussein plans to use Westerners to deter a U.S. assault. ``We should take them (Palestinians) and put them in front of the invading Arab forces,'' lawmaker Rahaman Zeevi told Parliament's foreign affairs and defense committee on Monday. Iraq repeatedly has threatened to attack Israel if the Jewish state moves against it. Saddam has warned that he will use chemical weapons to destroy half of Israel. Zeevi denied in an interview on Israel's army radio that his proposal was comparable to the Iraqi president's threat to move Westerners to Iraqi military and industrial sites as shields against an American air attack. ``We cannot be compared with Saddam Hussein,'' said Zeevi, who founded the extreme right-wing Moledet Party and was assistant army chief of staff during the 1973 Middle East war. ``He grabs peace-minded citizens and turns them into a military operation,'' Zeevi said. ``I am talking about a hostile population that has proved their hostility to us with everything they can for the past 33 months.'' It was a reference to the Palestinian uprising against Israeli occupation of the West Bank and Gaza Strip, launched in December 1987. An estimated 1.7 million Palestinians live in the occupied territories. Zeevi's Moledet, or ``homeland,'' Party advocates the transfer of all Palestinians from Israeli-occupied lands. It has two seats in Israel's 120-member Parliament and is not a member of Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir's Likud coalition.

DOC.HEAD: A Soviet in Suburbia: Condo Prototype for Moscow Project Gets Rave Reviews
DOC.TEXT: Will a luxurious condominium project lose anything in translation when builders try to duplicate its design near a lake outside Moscow? Victor Malnev thinks not _ even though wood will be replaced by concrete and steel. ``Maybe it will even look nicer than here,'' he said as he toured the Four Beaches condominium development on Long Island Sound. Malnev is chairman of the Soviet farm collective Zavet Ilyicha, which jointly developing the suburban Moscow project with Senie Kerschner International Housing Ltd. of Westport. The 1,000-member collective will not only lease the land for the project but also provide produce for those living in the complex, the first of its kind in the Soviet Union, Malnev said. Groundbreaking for the $130 million townhouse community, designed to house foreign businessmen, is scheduled for the end of September. The first of 528 units, to be built a Finnish company, are expected to be ready by next July. The international residential community, to be named Rosinka, is modeled on Four Beaches, a 135-unit condominium community consisting of three-story, wood-frame buildings and a network of wooden promenades and decks. Rosinka's three-story buildings will also have New England-style architecture, but without wood because the building code does not permit flammable materials, said Dick Williams, project manager for Kerschner. Instead, Rosinka will be constructed of concrete with a steel molding designed to look like the cedar clapboard on the condos at Four Beaches, Williams said. The stairwell towers will be built of glass and concrete rather than pressure-treated wood. Since the project was announced in April, at least 18 companies from the United States, Western Europe and Japan have reserved units, said Christopher Senie, secretary of the Senie Kerschner International. Apartment sizes at Rosinka will range from 1,248 square feet to 2,712 square feet for a two-story townhouse. Annual rents will range from $45,000 to $82,000.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Tourist, Guide Killed In Matterhorn Fall
DOC.TEXT: A U.S. mountain climber and his Swiss guide have fallen to their deaths on the Matterhorn, police said. Another American, 31, was flown to a hospital with serious injuries after the three-member party tumbled 240 feet Monday while climbing down the Swiss Alps peak, officials said. The group was at a height of 13,000 feet, about 1,700 feet below the summit, when they fell. The summer's death toll on the Matterhorn rose to 11. Police said the dead were a 37-year-old American and Zermatt mountain guide Hans Perren, 39. The identity of the U.S climbers was withheld pending notification of relatives.

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
Security Council Members Meet, Consult on Joint Military Action
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 11 grafs to UPDATE with council adjourning, Yemen agreeing to turn away Iraqi tanker. Pickup 11th pvs, `The United...'
DOC.TEXT: Yemen on Tuesday agreed it would turn away an Iraqi oil tanker expected to arrive within hours. The agreement followed an emergency Security Council meeting called on the matter. U.S. Ambassador Thomas Pickering said the United States requested the emergency council meeting after it received information of the imminent arrival in Yemen of the tanker, which defied a U.S. warship that fired across its bow Saturday. ``In the course of the evening, the Yemeni permanent representative, told the council that Yemen would adhere to the sanctions'' on Iraqi goods imposed after Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait, Pickering said. Yemen, the 15-member council's only Arab member, had abstained from the sanctions vote but had joined with the council in declaring the Iraqi annexation of Kuwait ``null and void.'' Yemen had also abstained from an Arab League vote on sanctions. Diplomats said the tanker would arrive in Yemeni territorial waters within hours. Pickering said the council also accepted a U.S. draft resolution that asked the United Nations to define what force it would take to back up its embargo. The British ambassador, Sir Crispin Tickell, also said the Yemeni representative agreed to turn away the tanker. The council agreed to convene at an ``early'' date to consider the resolution. Pickering said the adjournment was to allow each of the 15 Security Council members to consult with their governments before the final vote. A formal meeting was possible today or Wednesday to adopt a resolution calling for international military action against Iraq, diplomats said. The draft proposal that called for members to take ``all necessary action'' to enforce the U.N. embargo against Iraq. It would authorize the deployment of maritime forces and the use of ``minimum force as may be necessary to verify the cargoes and destinations of all ... shipping and to ensure the strict enforcement'' of the embargo. The Cuban delegation also presented a separate proposal calling for the exclusion of foodstuffs, medicine and medical assistance from the U.N. embargo. The United States has been criticized by some countries for policing the U.N. embargo without council approval. France and the Soviet Union are believed to be supportive, while China is said to be wary but unlikely to block an enforcement resolution with a veto. There is no exact precedent for the loose international military action currently contemplated. Diplomats close to the negotiations described the talks as complicated and requiring legal research. The diplomats emphasized that the United States and Britain were not seeking to invoke Article 42 of the U.N. Charter, providing for a U.N.-sponsored blockade to enforce sanctions. That article has never been invoked. The last U.N. enforcement action was launched in Korea in 1950. That operation, however, was placed under a U.S. command and was not organized under Article 42. Neither the United States nor Britain, they said, wanted a U.N. commander to organize their national military actions. Even a U.N. flag could imply some unacceptable U.N. supervision, they said. The only precedent for U.N. enforcement of sanctions came in 1966 when the Security Council called upon Britain to prevent, by force if necessary, oil shipments to white-ruled Rhodesia, which later was the object of a broad embargo. On Aug. 6, the Security Council adopted sweeping economic sanctions against Iraq to punish the Baghdad government for invading and occupying Kuwait on Aug. 2. The Security Council last met Saturday night to condemn Iraq's holding foreigners against their will. It demanded their immediate release. Under Chapter 7, Article 42 of the U.N. Charter, the Security Council is empowered to take military action to enforce its sanctions. The charter provies that the council ``may take such action by air, sea or land forces as may be necessary to maintain or restore international peace and security.'' Such action, it says, may include a blockade.

DOC.HEAD: Stocks Down in Tokyo
DOC.TEXT: The Nikkei Stock Average closed at 26,297.84, down 192.63 points, or 0.73 percent on the Tokyo Stock Exchange on Tuesday.

DOC.HEAD: Ann Richards, Trailing in Governor's Race, Is Hopeful
DOC.TEXT: Outspent, out-advertised and trailing in the polls, Ann Richards says her bid for governor is doing just fine. ``I've really felt up in about the last two weeks,'' the Democratic nominee said. ``We're running on target, except we've raised more money than I thought we would.'' During those last two weeks, her Republican opponent, oilman-rancher Clayton Williams, has been thrown on the defensive by news reports questioning his business acumen. And Richards has pounced on the issue. A hard-hitting TV commercial that began airing Friday portrays multimillionaire Williams as a troubled businessman who misused employees, is mired in debt and lawsuits and wants to keep it all secret. ``Let's look behind the screen on Claytie TV,'' the ad says. The commercial was Richards' first post-primary television ad and came after weeks of battering from Williams' TV commercials. Williams' aides called the 30-second spot mudslinging and a sign of desperation. ``The farther she falls behind in the polls, the more bizarre a sideshow her campaign is becoming,'' said Gordon Hensley, Williams' press secretary. ``Mr. Williams is a man of honesty and integrity and the polls are showing that the voters of Texas believe this to be the case.'' Williams on Friday countered with his new 30-second spot, which accuses Richards of wrongdoing in the savings and loan debacle. The commercial suggests Richards, as state treasurer, assisted S&L executives in getting state deposits, accepted their political contributions and then destroyed records showing where state money was deposited. Richards said the ad is ``totally false ... and Clayton Williams and his campaign staff know it.'' Richards, who gained wide recognition with her caustic keynote address at the 1988 Democratic National Convention, survived a brutal primary and runoff but has trailed in the few polls made public since. The most recent, a survey of 821 Texans taken Aug. 5-8 for several TV stations, showed Williams ahead 49 percent to 38 percent. No margin of error was given. The Democrat said she isn't bothered by such numbers. She said that the numbers are holding, even though Williams has been on television almost continuously since June. But the polls also show a small number of undecided voters, around 13 percent. And some Texas Democrats have said privately they are worried. With Williams and the well-funded Sen. Phil Gramm atop the Republican ticket, those Democrats are wondering just which of their candidates down the ballot could be the ``stopper'' to a GOP sweep. Williams has raised some $13 million and spent $11.3 million, more than $6 million of that his own money, according to July 1 campaign finance reports. Richards reported raising and spending just under $6 million. Karl Rove, a Republican consultant, said Richards has failed to offer any message beyond her ``New Texas'' slogan. ``She's determined to run a vacuous campaign,'' he said. ``She's not going to talk about substance or issues.'' Richards aides dispute that. Campaign consultant Glenn Smith said Richards is exposing the real story behind Williams' TV image. Early in the race, Williams drew the wrath of women's groups when he likened bad weather to rape. ``If it's inevitable, just relax and enjoy it,'' Williams said. Later, he admitted visiting prostitutes as a young man. For her part, Richards, a recovering alcoholic, was dogged during the primary by allegations of drug use. She repeatedly refused to say whether she had ever used illegal drugs. The focus turned to business after newspaper reports Aug. 5 said that Williams' net worth has fallen by almost two-thirds since 1982, when he estimated it at $300 million, and that a researcher hired by one of his primary opponents said half the 26 companies he founded had been sold or dissolved. ``I am not backing up one bit on my business record,'' Williams countered. ``I've had companies that broke even that I didn't keep and some that were extremely successful.''
