The Democrats have paired the attack on his business dealings with a demand that he make public his tax returns, something he has refused to do. Williams recently said it would ``take a Mack truck'' to carry his returns. Richards quickly sent a Mack truck to his headquarters.

DOC.HEAD: Air Force Plane Crashes, 18 Senior Military Officials Feared Dead
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout to UPDATE with plane splitting into two, report of explosion. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: A Taiwanese air force plane carrying 18 senior military officers crashed near a village today and all the passengers were feared dead. A spokesman for the Defense Ministry said the plane, a personnel transport craft, was taking the officers, including several major generals, to an important meeting when it crashed in Yunlin, a village 150 miles south of Taipei. The air force said the plane was in two parts after plowing into a sugar cane field in the central part of Taiwan. Taiwan's official Broadcasting Corp. of China said the aircraft was broken into two following an explosion. A part of the plane fell on the suger cane field and the rest was scattered in small pieces, it said. The Defense Ministry spokesman, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said everyone on board was feared dead. Rescue crews were at the site, the air force said, but so far no survivors have been found.

DOC.HEAD: Pilot of Overloaded Plane May Have Tried to Beat Deadline
DOC.TEXT: The pilot of an overloaded plane that crashed, killing all seven family members aboard, may have risked flying in stormy weather to earn more flight time before a midnight deadline, authorities say. The victims were all members of a Hmong refugee family attending the birthday party of the pilot's daughter. The single-engine plane crashed in a corn field late Saturday and was discovered the next morning. Pilot Jay Her, 31, of Watertown, was trying to earn flight time required for his license while treating family members to a ride, Sheriff Keith Mueller said Monday. ``I understand that pilots are required to certify themselves every 90 days or else they have to be recertified,'' Mueller said. ``I understand that that's what this person was doing, and I also understand that it had to be done before midnight on Saturday.'' The rented Piper Lance was designed to carry a pilot and five passengers, but Her squeezed two children into one seat, officials said. Severe thunderstorms drenched the area Saturday night, but officials were uncertain if bad weather caused the crash. The cause of the crash was under investigation by the National Transportation Safety Board. Jeff Baum, manager of the Watertown airport, said Her was a veteran pilot and it was ``inconceivable'' why he was flying with an extra passenger in a storm. ``What went through his mind to leave in those weather conditions and put seven people into a six-passenger plane I don't know,'' Baum said. Besides Her, the victims were: Her's children, Amy, 7, and Tom, 3; his brother, Yuayia Her, 47, of Sheboygan; Yuayia Her's son, Dani, 11; another brother, Vang Neng Her, 45, of Watertown, and nephew Vang Yang, 13, of Milwaukee. Relatives said the group was celebrating Amy Her's seventh birthday, and partygoers went for the plane ride during a break in the rain. The Hmong family fled their native Laos to Thailand at the close of the Vietnam War and made their way to Florida before resettling in Wisconsin. The airport was unattended when Her took off, but Baum said pilots are authorized to use the small airstrip after hours. A search was launched after Her's wife telephoned authorities Sunday morning to report her husband overdue.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar, Stocks Fall in Tokyo
DOC.TEXT: The dollar fell against the yen Tuesday, while share prices on the Tokyo Stock Exchange suffered a moderate decline. The Nikkei Stock Average of 225 selected issues lost 192.63 points, or 0.73 percent, to close at 26,297.84. The index shed 296.25 points on Monday. The dollar closed at 146.55 yen, down 0.92 yen from Monday's finish. After opening at 146.30 yen, the currency ranged between 146.10 yen and 147.08 yen. In bond dealings, the No. 119 10-year Japanese government bond was quoted at 83.11 points as of 3 p.m. (2 a.m. EDT), down from the previous day's close of 83.33. The yield stood at 8.08 percent, up from 8.03 percent. Currency dealers said the dollar's retreat followed its similar downswing against the yen in New York overnight, though it was mostly higher against other major currencies. ``There was dollar-buying by traders who considered the dollar's downswing had been excessive,'' said Shigeto Yanase, a dealer with Dai-Ichi Kangyo Bank. Yanase said the dollar was hovering ``around 146.70-146.80 yen'' following a report from New York that the United Nations's Security Council was debating a measure to use armed forces in the Middle East, where tension remains high after the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait. Meanwhile, Persian Gulf oil prices remained slightly higher. Dubai Fateh crude for October delivery was valued at about $25.70-$25.80 a barrel, slightly higher than late Monday New York levels.

DOC.HEAD: Earthquake Jolts Northern Iran
DOC.TEXT: An earthquake today jolted the city of Rudbar in northern Iran, where a devastating quake killed 40,000 people in June, Iran's official Islamic Republic News Agency reported. Today's temblor measured 5 on the Richter scale and had an epicenter 120 miles northwest of Tehran in the province of Gilan, Tehran University's Geophysics Center told the news agency. The agency, monitored in Cyprus, said there was no report of damage or casualties. Since the June 21 quake, which measured more than 7.3 on the Richter scale, the region has been rocked frequently by minor and severe tremors and aftershocks. Tens of thousands were injured and half a million people were left homeless in June in the provinces of Gilan and Zanjan. The Richter scale is a gauge of the energy released by an earthquake, as measured by the ground motion recorded on a seismograph. Every increase of one number means that the ground motion is 10 times greater. A quake of magnitude 5 can cause considerable damage in populated areas.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Signs Trade Bill Affecting Northwest Logging, Duty-Free Imports
DOC.TEXT: President Bush has signed legislation restricting state and federal log exports in an effort to save thousands of timber jobs and extend federal protection of the northern spotted owl. Bush said in signing the bill Monday that there was ``no doubt that high levels of export of unprocessed timber have contributed to the decline in habitat'' that caused the northern spotted owl to be listed as threatened. ``While I am supporting this provision because it assists in the preservation of critical habitat, I also note that it will ease the economic transition in areas affected by the listing of the spotted owl,'' Bush said. The log measure is intended to preserve the Pacific Northwest's dwindling timber supply for domestic mills along with enough old-growth stands to save the northern spotted owl from extinction. The bill makes permanent what had been a year-to-year ban on the export of raw logs from federal land and imposes a new ban on state lands in California and Oregon. Exports from state-owned land in Washington would be reduced but not halted.
DOC.HEAD: Government Cites UPS for Job Safety Violations
DOC.TEXT: The federal government wants to fine United Parcel Service $200,000 for alleged violation of laws requiring that job-related deaths and injuries be reported. The Occupational Safety and Health Administration said Monday the alleged violations took place at the company's Watertown, Conn., facility. UPS, the nation's largest package delivery company, was cited for failing to notify OSHA about a job-related death and failing to record more than 100 other injuries and illnesses. The company also failed to record the number of lost workdays caused by the injuries, the agency said. John Flick, a spokesman for the company based in Greenwich, Conn., said there would be no immediate comment because lawyers had not reviewed the allegations, which were issued late in the day.
DOC.HEAD: Plastic Decals on Baby Walker Pose Choking Hazard
DOC.TEXT: Delta Enterprise Corp. wants consumers to remove and discard plastic labels and decals from its Delta Luv Pop-Corn Baby Walker because they pose a choking hazard. The walkers have been associated with five incidents of choking, the Consumer Product Safety Commission said Monday. All occurred when children pulled off the decals on plastic toy dials on the walker trays and placed them in their mouths. The six colorful round decals, which measure about 1{ inches in diameter, should be removed immediately if they can be easily dislodged, the commission said. Labels that are firmly stuck should be checked periodically and removed if they become loose, the commission said. Adults should also remove the plastic-coated ``Delta Luv'' label with surrounding stripes found on the front of the tray, although no complaints have been received about these labels, the commission said. The paper warning label located under the tray should not be removed. Approximately 100,000 of the walkers have been sold nationwide since 1984. Owners with questions may write to Delta Enterprise Corp., 49 Junius St., Brooklyn, N.Y. 11212. The company can also be reached by phone at 718-385-1000 between 8 a.m. and midnight EDT.

DOC.HEAD: Tough Cop Named Police Chief in Atlanta
LaserPhoto AX1
DOC.TEXT: A bust-heads, tell-it-to-the-judge cop survived two demotions to become police chief in the city with the nation's highest crime rate. Mayor Maynard Jackson appointed Eldrin Bell on Monday, declaring, ``Eldrin Bell is exactly what the doctor ordered.'' Despite reservations by some city officials about Bell's alleged lack of respect for the law, the City Council, meeting minutes later, dispensed with the usual confirmation process and unanimously approved the appointment. ``We don't need to be messing around,'' said Council President Marvin S. Arrington. ``We need to put him on the job.'' Bell, one of three deputy chiefs on the 1,600-member force, takes over a police department with a big job in this city of about 445,000. In 1989, Atlanta reported 210 serious crimes for each 1,000 residents _ worst among U.S. cities with a population of 300,000 or more, according to the FBI. It was the second straight year Atlanta posted the worst crime rate. ``Let the word go forth,'' the 54-year-old Bell said at a news conference. ``Lawlessness and drug trafficking and gangs are not welcome in Atlanta. Atlanta will not tolerate this kind of lawlessness.'' Bell, who succeeds retiring Chief Morris Redding, stands to become the city's most powerful police chief in nearly 16 years. The mayor eliminated a commissioner post superior to the police and fire chiefs earlier this year. Bell, who has what the mayor called ``a well-deserved reputation as a tough cop,'' got little support from the man he replaced. Redding, who served eight years as chief, rated Bell's ``dependability and moral standards as low,'' although he said Bell is a hard worker. Randolph W. Thrower, who heads the city Ethics Board, said Bell ``does not reflect great respect for ethical considerations.'' Hilary L. Chiz, executive director for the Georgia chapter of the American Civil Liberties Union, said she had some concerns, but the ACLU wanted to work with the new chief ``on developing ways to deal with the very serious issues of crime without encroaching further on individual freedom.'' Bell, 54, has served on the force for 29 years and twice was demoted from deputy chief. In 1979, he was busted to major because of an investigation of police protection for gamblers at fairgrounds where Bell did security work. No charges were filed and he was reinstated. In 1985, he was again demoted, to lieutenant, after he was among patrons at an Italian restaurant where invited guests were targets of an FBI drug sting. It was determined that Bell hadn't been invited and wasn't under investigation. Bell once reportedly picked up a billy club, phoned for an ambulance, entered a crowded bar and fought seven suspects into submission. He was investigated in 1984 for pistol-whipping a motorist he had stopped, but a civilian panel, police board and a federal court cleared him of using excessive force. As commander of a crime-ridden section of the city, he was known for patrolling streets himself in the middle of the night and popping in unannounced at headquarters to make sure the night shift was answering calls promptly. Bell also was questioned in a 1975 promotion exam cheating scandal. Investigators concluded he wasn't involved but may have known about the cheating. Thrower, who headed the investigation, said Bell's evasiveness and failure to cooperate ``thwarted justice.''

DOC.HEAD: BlackOut Leaves Capital Without Electricity For 10 Hours
DOC.TEXT: A blackout left much of the capital without electricity for 10 hours, and the government said it suspected sabotage by striking electric workers. Four of the five transmission lines that serve the city of 1 million were not functioning early Monday because of damaged equipment, an official said. Renato London, head of operations at the state electric company, said 80 percent of Brasilia was without power from 6 a.m. local time to 4 p.m. Also hit by the power failure was Goiania, 130 miles southwest of the capital. Presidential spokesman Claudio Humberto Rosa e Silva said equipment at two power stations had been damaged by gunfire. ``This is an affront to society, to schools, industries, and we will seek stern punishment for those responsible,'' Silva said. But Antonio Rodrigues do Amaral, president of the Brasilia Electric Workers Union, blamed the government for the blackout, which he said was caused by a ``lack of maintenance.'' ``The government is to blame because they are not negotiating in good faith,'' he said. Electric workers began a nationwide strike three weeks ago to demand a 256 percent pay increase to cover losses to inflation.

DOC.HEAD: Court Refuses to Halt Wisconsin School-Choice Program
DOC.TEXT: A Wisconsin appeals court has cleared the way for the start this fall of a program that pays poor Milwaukee children state money to attend private school. Several groups, including the state's biggest teachers union, had sought an injunction blocking the program while they appeal a Dane County Circuit Court decision earlier this month that ruled it constitutional. But the Court of Appeals on Monday refused, saying there was no evidence any irreparable harm would occur if the program went into effect. The program, the first of its kind in the United States, offers $2,500 in tuition assistance for up to 1,000 poor pupils to enroll in private school. It is scheduled to start when fall classes begin in about two weeks. Supporters and opponents of the program have 19 days from Monday to file briefs in the appeals case. At the hearing, Charles Clausen, representing the Wisconsin Education Association Council and the other groups, said the program was unconstitutional because the Legislature failed to pass it as a separate bill. It was an item in the budget bill. But attorneys for the state, six private schools and families who support the program defended the Legislature, arguing it acted decisively to improve the quality of education in urban areas. About 400 pupils have been accepted by 10 private Milwaukee-area schools participating in the program, which won legislative approval in April.

DOC.HEAD: Government Nearly Doubles Reward Offered For Cartel Chief
DOC.TEXT: The government has raised the reward for the capture of the reputed leader of the Medellin cocaine cartel to nearly $1 million, the army says. Thousands of handbills offering the doubled bounty were dropped from army helicopters over the weekend in Medellin, according to a statement Monday by Gen. Harold Bedoya, the commander of the army brigade based in the city. Photographs of reputed cartel leader Pablo Escobar and other cartel leaders appeared on the handbills, offering 500 million pesos, nearly $1 million, for information leading to Escobar's capture. Escobar, wanted in the United States on drug trafficking charges, is also accused of masterminding several assassinations in Colombia, including the August 1989 killing of Sen. Luis Carlos Galan. Galan, a leading presidential contender, was gunned down at a political rally outside of Bogota. After Galan's death, the government began extraditing trafficking suspects and seizing their properties. The cartel responded with a series of terrorist attacks that killed some 500 people before the organization declared a unilateral cease-fire last month. This is the second time the government has raised the reward for Escobar since it intensified a crackdown on the cartel. At the end of 1989, the army announced it was increasing the bounty to $500,000 from $250,000. The handbills also offered a reward of nearly $500,000 for Jorge Luis Ochoa, considered by authorities to be the cartel's second-in-command. The latest increase seemed to reaffirm the government's decision not to deal with traffickers. Last week Justice Minister Jaime Giraldo Angel said there would be no government negotiations with organized crime despite the cartel's truce. But the minister added that an end to terrorism would allow the government to end the extradition of accused drug traffickers. The government has extradited 22 drug suspects since implementing the policy last year. The Medellin cartel, which has been able to avoid Colombian justice by bribing, threatening and killing judges, has tried both to force and to coax the government into abandoning extradition. Security forces have continued to pursue the cartel's members. Those killed in shootouts with police include Gonzalo Rodriguez Gacha, called the most violent cartel figure, John Jairo Arias, the leader of the organization's gunmen, and Gustavo de Jesus Gaviria, Escobar's first cousin and right-hand man.

DOC.HEAD: `Exorcist III' Spins Heads at Box Office; `Two Jakes' Dies
LaserGraphic
DOC.TEXT: The ``Exorcist III'' and ``Ghost'' conjured up a lively audience, but ``The Two Jakes'' appeared to be D.O.A. at the box office. The latest sequel in the ``Exorcist'' series made $9.3 million for the No. 1 spot in its debut weekend with a tale about a string of priest murders. ``Ghost,'' an afterlife romance starring Patrick Swayze and Demi Moore, materialized in second place with $8.4 million and will pass the $100 million mark this week, according to figures Monday from Exhibitor Relations Co. In third was another morbid exercise, ``Flatliners.'' The movie about medical students flirting with near-death experiences made $7.1 million. Meanwhile, the private eye thriller ``The Two Jakes'' fell to 13th in its second week, making just $1.8 million. The sequel to ``Chinatown'' stars Jack Nicholson. In fourth with ticket sales of $6.2 million was ``My Blue Heaven,'' starring Steve Martin and Rick Moranis as a mobster and an FBI agent. ``Wild at Heart,'' a psychodrama from director David Lynch, finished 10th in its first weekend. The violent, disturbing work made $2.9 million playing on 532 screens. Here are the top movie ticket sales for Friday through Sunday as tallied by Exhibitor Relations, with distributor, weekend gross, number of theater screens, average per screen, total gross and number of weeks in release. Figures are based on a combination of actual box-office receipts and studio projections where actual figures are not immediately available. 1. ``Exorcist III,'' 20th Century Fox, $9.3 million, 1,288 screens, $7,230 per screen, $9.3 million, one week. 2. ``Ghost,'' Paramount, $8.4 million, 1,766 screens, $4,736 per screen, $99.2 million, six weeks. 3. ``Flatliners,'' Columbia, $7.1 million, 1,424 screens, $4,956 per screen, $23.1 million, two weeks. 4. ``My Blue Heaven,'' Warner Bros., $6.2 million, 1,859 screens, $3,339 per screen, $6.2 million, one week. 5. ``Presumed Innocent,'' Warner Bros. $6.1 million, 1,423 screens, $4,288 per screen, $51.9 million, four weeks. 6. ``Air America,'' Tri-Star, $4.7 million, 1,902 screens, $2,490 per screen, $17 million, two weeks. 7. ``Taking Care of Business,'' Disney, $3.6 million, 1,074 screens, $3,371 per screen, $3.6 million, one week. 8. ``Problem Child,'' Universal, $3.3 million, 1,640 screens, $2,020 per screen, $37.2 million, four weeks. 9. ``Young Guns II,'' 20th Century Fox, $3.1 million, 1,461 screens, $2,135 per screen, $37.2 million, three weeks. 10. ``Wild at Heart,'' Samuel Goldwyn, $2.9 million, 532 screens, $5,477 per screen, $2.9 million, one week.

DOC.HEAD: Zairean Students End Weeklong Occupation of Embassy
DOC.TEXT: About 40 Zairean students today ended a weeklong occupation of their embassy in Beijing after getting assurances from their government that it would send promised living allowances and plane tickets home. The students began returning to their schools after holding their ambassador and his staff hostage in the walled compound since Aug. 15. The decision to leave was made after a 30-minute phonecall from the Zairean ambassador in Belgium, Kimbulu Moyanso, who assured the students that approximately $187,500 in unpaid living allowances would be forwarded to Beijing within 10 days, said Qinghua University graduate Ngolo Kilubisha. Government funds from Zaire, a former Belgian colony, are first transferred to banks in Belgium before being disbursed overseas. Most of the more than 80 Zaire students in China have not been paid since June 1989, with some going without their Zaire government subsidies for two years. The students also get $54 per month from the Chinese government. The students today received a telex from their education minister asking for a breakdown of money owed to each student and other details of their complaints. The students said the head of Zaire's Culture Center in Belgium, which is responsible for its students studying overseas, is to come to Beijing on Thursday to talk with the students. Kilubisha said the students regarded these moves as signs the government was prepared to resolve their problems, which also included failure to provide promised plane tickets home for graduates after five-year stays in China. It was the second consecutive year the students have protested over the same problems. Last year, they occupied the embassy for 10 days until the Zaire government refused to resolve the problems unless the students withdrew. Kilubisha said the students voted Monday night to retreat, but warned, ``If we don't get any solution (based on) what they've said, we might come back.'' The students had secured the gate of the walled embassy compound with a bicycle lock, refusing to allow the ambassador or his staff out or the Chinese staff in. Kilubish said the lock was removed and the embassy was operating normally today. The Zaireans are one of the largest groups of African students in China. Under friendship agreements signed in the 1960s, China gives scholarships to students from many African countries to complete entire degree programs in China, usually in the sciences.

DOC.HEAD: Leftist Guerrillas Attack Barracks, Five Civilians Hurt
DOC.TEXT: Leftist guerrillas attacked an army barracks in the capital across the street from President Alfredo Cristiani's residence. Five people were wounded in the battle, the military said. The military sources, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said the rebels used bombs hurled from homemade catapults and also mortars in the attack late Monday, but none of the rounds hit the barracks. The barracks houses a military communication unit on the south side of the capital. Hundreds of army troops, backed by helicopter gunships, immediately cordoned off the area and exchanged automatic rifle fire for about 30 minutes with the rebels before the attackers withdrew shortly after nightfall. The guerrillas also dynamited a half-dozen electrical towers, leaving large areas in the southern part of the city without power. Radio stations reported that Cristiani's residence was hit by a mortar explosion, but an official there denied this. Cristiani ``was not here at the time of the attack. They did not attack the presidential house,'' the official, who also spoke on condition of anonymity, said in a telephone interview. ``This was an attack mainly against the civilian population,'' one of the military sources said. Journalists who toured the area after the fighting saw at least three houses in the neighborhood damaged by guerrilla mortar fire. Red Cross volunteers at the scene said they picked up five civilians wounded by shrapnel fire and rushed them to hospital. The guerrilla attack came as peace talks in San Jose, the capital of neighboring Costa Rica, stalled Monday over rebel demands that the army be abolished and officers be punished for politically motivated murders. Oscar Santamaria, justice minister and head of the government delegation, described the addition of new guerrilla demands since the July round of talks as a setback. He said the new demands were ``not in accord with the seriousness of the peace process.'' The rebel Farabundo Marti National Liberation Front submitted an 18-point document. Its first demand calls for ``the total demilitarization of society, by means of disappearance of the two armies.'' The rebels, in previous rounds of talks, had demanded trial and punishment of officers implicated in four noted human rights cases, including the 1980 assassination of Archbishop Oscar Romero and last November's massacre by army troops of six Jesuit priests, their housekeeper and her daughter. The new document adds demands for punishment of those responsible for two other cases, as well as ``the murders, massacres and bombardments of civilians that have occurred during the negotiations.'' The document also demands investigations to determine responsibility for 20 other specific crimes in addition to ``all the crimes, murders, disappearances and massacres committed since 1979.'' More than 73,000 people have been killed since the war began in October 1979, the majority of them civilians.

DOC.HEAD: Share Prices Down; Dollar Also Down
DOC.TEXT: Continued uncertainty over the Middle East sent share prices falling for the fourth consecutive trading day in Tokyo today, and the U.S. dollar fell against the Japanese yen. The Nikkei Stock Average of 225 selected issues gained moderately in the morning but dropped in light afternoon trading, closing at 26,297.84 points, down 192.63 points, or 0.73 percent. The index fell 296.25 points on Monday. Yoshihide Koyama, an analyst with Nikko Securities, said share prices moved up because of purchases by investment trust funds in the morning, but suffered from sporadic arbitrage selling in the afternoon. ``The index was easily affected by a thin trading volume,'' Koyama said. A total of 280 million shares changed hands on the market's first section, up slightly from Monday's slim 206 million shares. The Nikkei index has lost a total of 4,540.15 points, or 14.7 percent, since its closing of 30,837.99 on Aug. 1, the day before the Middle East crisis began with Iraq's invasion of Kuwait. In currency dealings, the dollar closed at 146.55 yen, down 0.92 yen from Monday's finish. It opened at 146.30 yen and ranged between 146.10 yen and 147.08 yen. Currency dealers said the dollar's retreat followed its downswing against the yen in New York overnight, although it was mostly higher against other major currencies. ``The sentiment toward the dollar basically remains weak in relation to the yen, with the day's trading mostly focused on cross trading,'' in which traders sell European currencies to buy the yen, said Masahiro Yanagida, a dealer with Sanwa Bank. Yanagida said the dollar could be affected either way by developments in the Middle East. On the bond market, the price of benchmark No. 119 10-year Japanese government bonds closed at 83.22 points, down from their 83.33-point closing Monday. Their yield stood at 8.060 percent, up from 8.030 percent. Meanwhile, Persian Gulf oil prices moved slightly higher. Dubai Fateh crude for October delivery was valued at about $25.70-$25.80 a barrel, marginally higher than late Monday New York levels. Prices for October delivery of North Sea Brent were $27.70-$27.85 a barrel, higher than the $27.40 quoted late Monday in New York.

DOC.HEAD: Voters Nominate Gubernatorial Candidates in Wyoming
DOC.TEXT: The rancher daughter of a former Wyoming governor faced a state lawmaker today for the GOP nomination for her father's old job. Gov. Mike Sullivan had only token opposition on the Democratic side. Mary Mead and 12-year Rep. Nyla Murphy seemed to agree more often than not. They are pro-choice on abortion, favor the death penalty, oppose other states dumping garbage in Wyoming and fault Sullivan's running of the economy. ``Wyoming is on the skids. He's had four years to turn it around, and it hasn't changed,'' said Mead, daughter of Cliff Hansen, a former governor and U.S. senator. Sullivan has largely ignored his race against Ron ``Suds'' Clingman, a motorcycle repairman who wants to return the drinking age to 18, legalize gambling, decriminalize drugs and cut the salaries of public officials. Clingman also believes murderers facing execution should have the option of turning their living bodies over to medical experimentation. Also on the primary ballot are Republicans U.S. Sen. Alan Simpson and U.S. Rep. Craig Thomas. Simpson faced two political unknowns for a third term. Thomas, appointed to fill Dick Cheney's term when he was named defense secretary, is unopposed. His Democratic opponent, Pete Maxfield, also is unopposed.

DOC.HEAD: 18 People, Including Three Generals, Killed in Military Plane Crash
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout to UPDATE with 18 killed, identification of generals. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: A Taiwanese air force plane carrying three top military officers crashed and exploded on a sugar cane field in heavy rain today, killing all 18 people on board, the Defense Ministry said. A ministry statement said the Beech-1900 turboprop transport craft was carrying three major generals and their aides on an ``inspection mission'' when it crashed in Yunlin, a village 150 miles south of Taipei. Three crew members also died in the crash. The generals were identified as air force deputy chief of staff Lin Lung-hsien, air force operations director Ning Chien-chuang and Combined Services Forces' Ordinance Director Tsao Yao-yi. Biographical information on the three was not immediately available because is considered a military secret in Taiwan. The mass-circulation China Times Express said the officers were on their way to inspect a military airport being built in central Taiwan in Chiayi, near Yunlin. The newspaper said the aircraft hit the ground and exploded. The force of the blast split the aircraft in two, burying the cockpit in the muddy field and scattering the rest of the plane in pieces, the paper said. The Defense Ministry said it was investigating the cause of the crash. Officials said the aircraft was bought from the U.S. Beech Aircraft Corp. in 1988.

DOC.HEAD: Doctor: Florida Gubernatorial Candidate's Depression No Disability
With PM-Texas Governor, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Former U.S. Sen. Lawton Chiles, his campaign for governor dogged by questions about his mental health, released medical records that said he never contemplated suicide during his bouts with depression. Chiles, 60, released the inch-thick collection of records Monday after calls for disclosure from his opponent. At a news conference at which the records were released, Chiles' physician, Dr. Karl Hempel, said the former senator has been treated for depression since 1987. The condition, which afflicts an estimated 4 percent of the adult U.S. population, can be debilitating and lead to suicide, but Chiles is less severely affected, the doctor said. ``He's never been suicidal from the very start,'' said Hempel. ``I would definitely not tell him to retire. He doesn't have anything that is even close to being disabling.'' Chiles is running against U.S. Rep. Bill Nelson, 47, for the Democratic nomination in the Sept. 4 primary. Nelson's running mate, Tom Gustafson, suggested Chiles could be suicidal as governor but later apologized for the remark. Campaigning on Monday, Chiles said the records ``should put an end'' to questions about his mental and physical health. Republican Gov. Bob Martinez and Chiles' Democratic opponent had earlier released complete medical records, and Nelson repeatedly urged Chiles to do the same. ``I think that my health is perhaps a legitimate issue,'' Chiles said, adding that his daily campaigning shows that he is fit. He had his first episode of depression following open-heart surgery in 1985, but that was brief and resolved without treatment, Hempel told reporters. The medical documents dating to 1966 showed that in 1987, Chiles complained of insomnia and loss of appetite and sex drive _ common symptoms of depression. He was treated with the anti-depressant doxepin. A month later, Chiles made the surprise announcement he wouldn't seek a fourth Senate term. In the evaluation, Dr. R.J. Pentzien, a psychiatrist at Bethesda Naval Hospital, wrote: ``There was no history of suicidal ideation, plan or intent.'' Chiles was switched to the popular new anti-depressant Prozac in 1989 by Hempel. The drug's makers deny claims in several lawsuits that it can spur suicidal tendencies. Hempel said Chiles would be fine as long as he monitors his condition, which is being treated with anti-depression drugs to correct a chemical imbalance in the brain. Chiles, who served in the Legislature in a political career dating to 1959, said he released the records because he didn't want to appear to be hiding anything.

DOC.HEAD: EAST BERLIN: said today. De Maiziere said Parliament will meet on Oct. 9 to confirm that unity will take place five days later. Oct. 14 is the date East Germany holds elections for the five state governments that the nation will become in a united Germany. It is also the anniversary of a massive demonstration in Leipzig that helped to bring about the downfall of the Communist government. MORE
Philadelphia's Mayor Pleads For Action on Fiscal Crisis
DOC.TEXT: Mayor W. Wilson Goode says Philadelphia is not bankrupt and can avoid a disastrous $206.4 million deficit if the state and City Council work with him to raise taxes and cut spending. ``These actions may be painful,'' he said Monday. ``But had they been taken in the past, as I recommended, they would not be necessary now. To avoid tough times ahead, we cannot avoid tough choices today.'' Goode urged the Legislature to give the city power to raises taxes by $150 million, to be spread among consumers, homeowners and businesses. He also called for a freeze on hiring and a cut in all non-essential services, which he did not list. And he proposed the lease or sale of Veterans Stadium, where the Philadelphia Phillies and Eagles play, and of other city assets, including the Water Department. Goode's call for action came as his administration announced plans Monday to borrow $400 million in temporary loan notes within the next two weeks. Without the notes, the city would be out of cash by late September, according to a report by City Finance Director Betsy Reveal. Even with the notes, the city will be out of cash by May unless short- and long-term measures are taken, the report said. Goode accused previous administrations of taking stopgap measures to avoid crises. He pointed to federal grants that have dried up and the recession gripping the Northeast. But he reserved the largest share of blame for the state. ``The root of our dilemma is that Philadelphia's fiscal problems are primarily structural _ they are built into the state system,'' he said. Gov. Robert P. Casey defended his administration, saying he has ``substantially increased the state's financial contribution to the city.'' Goode also blasted the City Council, noting it has repeatedly thwarted his attempts to raise taxes over the years.

DOC.HEAD: EAST BERLIN: Communist government.
DOC.TEXT: East German leaders have been bickering about when to enact a clause in the West German constitution that will allow the nation to accede to its Western neighbor. The left-leaning Social Democrats, who left de Maiziere's broad coalition government on Sunday, had said they would seek to have unification take place on Sept. 15 because of the nation's serious economic problems. De Maiziere told reporters about the agreement following a meeting with the leaders of the parties in Parliament. It appears now that the timetable for German unity is now almost solidified. Elections for a united German government have been tentatively set for Dec. 2. The timing and pace of unification, and feuding among politicians who essentially are campaigning to lead the new German nation, has virtually decimated the East German government.

DOC.HEAD: Lawmen Identify Mystery Cowboy Accused of Theft
DOC.TEXT: A mysterious phony cowboy suspected of stealing and selling horses and saddles across the country has a name _ and it's not Slim, Tex or Buffalo Bill. The alleged thief had been using the name of a man who died in January, and authorities say he used as many as 35 aliases in the last seven years. He used so many false names that officers who arrested him earlier this month couldn't determine his real identity. That changed when an anonymous caller who had seen his picture in a newspaper fingered him, Sheriff Jerry Cox said Monday. The mystery man known for wearing outlandish cowboy outfits and calling everybody ``pardner'' was identified as John Richard Brink, a 39-year-old native of Quincy, Ill., Cox said. Cox said that after Brink learned his cover was blown, he admitted to the name changes. ``He said, `I've done this for the last six or seven years,' '' Cox said. ``He said this was the first time he had gotten caught and wanted to know how I had done it.'' Brink is in jail on $160,000 bail on burglary and theft charges. He also faces charges in Indiana and two other Missouri counties, Cox said. Authorities in Tennessee and Pennsylvania want to question him. Investigators believe he traveled from New York to Texas, stealing horses, riding tack and other goods to sell further down the road. He was captured after he allegedly took part in a burglary near here. Two alleged accomplices led authorities to Brink, known for wearing gaudy lizard-skin boots, a black Stetson hat and silver belt buckle. After his arrest at a Springfield motel, law officers found stolen saddles and other riding equipment in a storage locker he had rented.

DOC.HEAD: Report: Bankruptcy Courts Under Investigation
DOC.TEXT: Federal prosecutors say they have launched a criminal investigation of Northern California's bankruptcy courts. U.S. Attorney William T. McGivern Jr. confirmed the probe, the San Francisco Daily Journal, a law publication, reported today. ``Over the last several months, matters involving the practice of bankruptcy law in general have been referred to this office ... and are under investigation by the FBI and this office,'' McGivern said. McGivern declined to comment further, but an assistant U.S. attorney told the journal that the probe began at least three months ago at his instance. ``I see obstruction of justice, I see violations of bankruptcy statutes ... bankruptcy fraud,'' the unidentified prosecutor was quoted as saying. ``I am seriously concerned about the bankruptcy system.'' The prosecutor said complaints in the past year came from debtors, creditors and attorneys. Most of the cases involved Chapter 11 reorganizations, in which attorneys and trustees often have wide discretion over assets. ``There is a club,'' the prosecutor said. ``If you are on the right side of the club, you seem to win in the bankruptcy court. If you are on the wrong side, you seem to lose in the bankruptcy court. ``It was my opinion that the little people were the ones that were getting the short end of the stick; the people who couldn't afford to hire lawyers, go in with some high-priced legal talent, weren't getting a fair shake.''

DOC.HEAD: Rain in the East Early Today, Clear Skies Elsewhere
DOC.TEXT: Rain fell over much of the East early today, while the rest of the nation had mostly clear skies. Showers were expected to continue in the East today, with rain developing over Virginia, Maryland, New York, Pennsylvania and the Great Lakes region. New England was expecting clear skies while much of the South was looking for continued sunshine and hot weather, with highs in the 90s. Thunderstorms were possible along the border of Georgia and Florida and were also forming in Missouri, Illinois and Indiana. Sunshine and highs in the 80s were expected throughout the Great Plains. Showers were possible in the Dakotas and a large storm system was developing over Idaho, Montana and Washington. The Southwest was expecting sunshine with highs reaching the 100s in Southern California and Arizona. Tenperatures were expected to be in the 70s in the Northeast and along the Pacific Coast, the 80s in the Northwest and much of inland California and in the 100s in Texas and Oklahoma. The high temperature for the nation Monday was 104 degrees at Meridian, Miss., and Waco, Texas. DOC.HEAD: Dollar Higher, Gold Slips
DOC.TEXT: The dollar settled in today at generally higher levels set in overnight trading, and regained some lost ground against the Japanese yen. Gold prices were lower in what dealers described as a nervous market. A trader for an Italian bank in Milan said the dollar seemed to have settled in a narrow range, but was likely to resume its upward correction later in the day. ``If the dollar breaks above 1.5720 marks, it could go sharply higher to 1.5750 marks or 1.58 marks before the end of the day,'' he said. In Tokyo, the dollar closed at 146.55 yen, down 0.92 yen from Monday's finish. Later in London, the dollar was quoted at 146.71 yen. Currency dealers said the dollar's retreat in Tokyo followed a similar drop in Europe and New York on Monday. ``There was dollar-buying by traders who considered the dollar's downswing had been excessive,'' said Shigeto Yanase, a dealer with Dai-Ichi Kangyo Bank in Tokyo. Other dollar rates at midmorning compared with late Monday: _1.5675 West German marks, up from 1.5625 _1.299 Swiss francs, up from 1.294 _5.27 French francs, up from 5.2375 _1.7660 Dutch guilders, up from 1.7585 _1,159.50 Italian lire, up from 1,151 --1.1415 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1437 In London, the British pound was quoted at $1.9105, compared with $1.9185 late Monday. Gold dealers in London fixed a recommended price of $407.85 a troy ounce Monday morning, down from $409.75 bid late Monday. In Zurich, the bid price was $408.45, down from $409.75 late Monday. Silver traded in London at a bid price of $5.13 a troy ounce, down from Monday's $5.14.

DOC.HEAD: Nike Executives Refuse Meeting With Black Boycott Group
DOC.TEXT: Operation PUSH brought its war of words against Nike to the athletic shoe company's doorstep _ but wasn't allowed into enemy territory. Nike executives on Monday refused to meet with members of the Chicago-based civil rights group, continuing its defiance of PUSH's call for a national boycott of Nike products. PUSH leader the Rev. Tyrone Crider said the group was in Oregon for a meeting with Nike brass, but company spokeswoman Liz Dolan said earlier that Nike informed PUSH by telephone on Friday that executives would not meet with Crider. Nike security chief Patrick McElroy turned the group away at the door. The PUSH delegation remained outside the building, demonstrating for an end to what they call discriminatory business practices by Nike. Protesters wore T-shirts that read: ``Say No to Nike.'' ``We will not rest until we bring Nike down to its knees,'' Chicago city Alderman Dorothy Tillman said after being turned away from Nike offices. Two weeks ago PUSH called for the national boycott, saying Nike denies blacks adequate employment and business opportunities. Nike says its minority policies and programs could serve as industry models. Its sneakers are promoted in television commercials by black sports stars like Michael Jordan, Bo Jackson and David Robinson, as well as black filmmaker Spike Lee. PUSH has succeeded in winning ``covenants'' promising blacks greater opportunities from companies such as Coca Cola and Burger King. Nike executives met once in Chicago with PUSH leaders. PUSH demanded that Nike increase black employment and direct more of its business to black-owned banks and advertising agencies. Another meeting was set in Beaverton, but Nike cancelled it. Nike executives claimed that their chief competitor, Reebok International Ltd., engineered the dispute in hopes of boosting sales. PUSH stands for People United to Save Humanity. The group was founded by the Rev. Jesse Jackson.

DOC.HEAD: Iraqi Forces Near Kuwaiti Border in Disarray
With PM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.NOTE: EDITOR'S NOTE
DOC.TEXT: The following dispatch is from pool reporters for The Associated Press, Reuters and Press Association, Britain's domestic news agency.

Iraqi forces near the Kuwait border are in disarray, reduced to stealing water and siphoning gasoline from civilian cars, British intelligence sources have said. The sources, speaking on condition of anonymity, said Monday that capabilities of the 120,000-member force have been exaggerated. They believe Iraqi re-supply lines are so inefficient that a full-scale invasion of Saudi Arabia is all but impossible. Some Iraqi soldiers are as young as 16. Air Vice Marshal Sandy Wilson, commander of British forces in Saudi Arabia, said: ``There is a danger of giving too much credit to Saddam's capabilities.'' Wilson said, however, he did not underestimate the professionalism of Iraqi pilots. The Iraqis have a small number of Soviet Mig-29 and French Mirage F1 fighter aircraft. Britain's 12 Tornado F3 fighters are flying regularly with U.S. and Saudi warplanes. The planes have made radar contact with Iraqi aircraft, Wilson said, but refused to give any details. Wilson said an integrated command structure has been established for the U.S., British and Saudi air forces, although each remains under national command. During flights, the planes are co-ordinated and controlled by U.S. and Saudi Awacs _ airborne early warning radar aircraft. The multinational military build-up continues at Dhahran, in the kingdom's northeastern corner, and every day the air defense shield is strengthened, the sources said. ``It is a comfort to me that, as a result, the Iraqis' ability to get chemical weapons through is increasingly reduced,'' Wilson said. He described the shield as not invincible but ``pretty capable.'' Rapier anti-aircraft missile batteries sent from Britain were being held in Cyprus because the British had decided the air defenses provided by the United States and Saudi Arabia were more than adequate, Wilson said. British intelligence sources, meanwhile, described most of the Iraqi troops dug in 10 to 15 miles behind the border as young and ``shaky.'' ``Their re-supply lines are a shambles, and they have been reduced to stealing water and siphoning petrol from civilian vehicles,'' one intelligence source said.

DOC.HEAD: Leaders Plea For End to Violence; Toll Rises to 399
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 17 grafs to UPDATE with toll rising to 399, leaders appealing for peace. Pickup 14th pvs, `The ANC...'
DOC.TEXT: Government and black leaders pleaded today for an end to tribal violence that has killed at least 399 people, and they urged the warring factions to work together for peace. Foreign Affairs Minister Pik Botha met Zulu leader Mangosuthu Buthelezi and Gen. Bantu Holomisa, leader of the predominantly Xhosa homeland of Transkei, to discuss fighting in black townships around Johannesburg between Zulus and Xhosas. ``The need, whatever the cause is, is to put an immediate end to the bloodshed. All political leaders have a responsibility in this respect which they must accept by putting aside political objectives,'' the leaders said in a statement. They also called for church leaders to oppose the violence. But the African National Congress was not represented at the 45-minute meeting in Pretoria. Zulus loyal to Buthelezi's conservative Inkatha movement and mostly Xhosa followers of the ANC have been fighting since Aug. 12. Buthelezi was to meet later with President F.W. de Klerk. ``Not only must the bloodshed cease, the war of words must cease,'' the statement said. ``This has often been interprteted at grassroots level as license for violence.'' The Zulus and Xhosas _ _ the country's two largest black tribes _ have battled with guns, machetes, spears, clubs and axes in the worst township violence in years. A police spokeswoman said two cars and a house were burned today in the KwaThema, while police disarmed bands of Zulus and Xhosas who had gathered in Tembiza. Groups continued to gather in Tembiza, Lt. Ida Van Zweel said, but no new violence there was reported. Also Tuesday, a bomb exploded in a car at a Johannesburg hotel believed frequented by ANC supporters. The blast broke several windows, but nobody was injured, police said. The bomb, made of commercial explosives, appeared similar to weapons used by extreme right-wing whites opposed to government moves toward sharing power with the black majority. De Klerk met last week with ANC deputy president Nelson Mandela to seek a halt to the violence. Buthelezi and Mandela have made separate calls in the past for an end to the violence, but their followers have continued to fight. Police figures today raised the overall death toll in township violence to 399 since Aug. 12, including 120 in Tokoza, 112 in Soweto, 56 in KwaThema, 42 in Katlehong and 38 in Tembiza. Police said they found more bodies overnight. The Johannesburg clashes marked a spread of the political violence from eastern Natal Province, where Inkatha-ANC fighting has killed some 5,000 blacks over the past five years. The ANC has rejected a direct meeting with Buthelezi since fighting began in Johannesburg. Mandela previously canceled a meeting with Buthelezi earlier this year, reportedly because of pressure from ANC leaders in Natal. But Buthelezi claimed today he had met with what he called top ANC officials in recent weeks to discuss the violence. He would not identify them. He also criticized Mandela for refusing to meet previously. The ANC contends Buthelezi is trying to broaden Inkatha's constituency beyond Natal by instigating violence against ANC backers in the Johannesburg area townships. It also claims meeting with him would reward such a strategy by giving the Zulu leader legitimacy as a power broker in the black opposition movement. Buthelezi and other Inkatha leaders contend the ANC is not willing to tolerate rivals and seeks to monopolize political power. Inkatha says it must be included in negotiations between the government and the ANC on ending white-minority rule. Both the ANC and Inkatha oppose apartheid, the system of racial segregation that allows 5 million whites to maintain political and economic control over 30 million blacks. But the two groups differ over tactics and plans for a future South Africa.

DOC.HEAD: Mubarak Urges Saddam To Abandon Kuwait, Avoid ``Destructive War''
With PM-Gulf-Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: President Hosni Mubarak urged Iraqi President Saddam Hussein today to withdraw his forces from Kuwait to avoid ``a destructive war that will devour everything.'' Mubarak said he was timing his appeal ``at these critical, decisive and difficult hours.'' Announcers read Mubarak's statement on the state-owned national television and Cairo Radio. It was preceded and followed by nationalist songs and martial music, with film clips emphasizing Arab unity showing Mubarak and Arab leaders, including Saddam. The president said he was making his appeal ``in the name of everything sacred on our Arab soil ... in the name of Islam, the religion of peace ... in the name of Arab nationalism ... in the name of every man, woman and child on our Arab land.'' In urging an Iraqi pullout from Kuwait, conquered on Aug. 2 and annexed six days later, Mubarak also asked for restoration of the ousted government of Sheik Jaber al-Ahmed al-Sabah. The president expressed confidence that if Saddam did as he asked, the Arabs would be able to settle the Iraq-Kuwait dispute peacefullly. ``In the name of light, good and right, I appeal to President Saddam Hussein to save both man and entity in our Arab world from a destructive war that will devour everything,'' Mubarak said. ``God only knows what the terrifying outcome will be if war begins, or how much damage there will be if the fire erupts, taking us backward into total darkness and loss. ``I appeal to President Saddam Hussein to make the decision to withdraw Iraqi forces from the land of Kuwait so that conditions there would return to what they were.'' Mubarak said Arabs everywhere look to Saddam to ``take this initiative, which would be appreciated in the Arab world and the whole world west and east, north and south.''

DOC.HEAD: Iraq Moves Missiles to Kuwait, Jane's Editor Says
With PM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 6 grafs to clarify that Dodds unsure whether missiles are Scuds or al-Husayns. Pick up 4th pvs, `Obviously that...'
DOC.TEXT: Iraq has moved as many as 800 Soviet-built or Iraqi-modified ballistic missiles into Kuwait, the editor of Jane's Soviet Intelligence Review said today. Henry Dodds said he had learned from a Saudi Arabian source Monday that up to 36 missile launchers and as many as 800 missiles are in Kuwait. It was unclear, he added, whether the missiles were the Soviet Scud B, which has been sold to Iraq, or the al-Husayn, a longer-range Iraqi version. ``There are 36 launchers in Kuwait and they seem to be Scud launchers,'' Dodds said in a telephone interview. ``But there are also missiles being moved about on flatbed trucks. Unless you can get close enough to measure, there is no way of telling the difference between Scuds and al-Husayns.'' Dodds said the Al-Husayn is based on the Soviet Scud B, but its range of 400 miles is more than double the range of the Soviet version. ``Obviously that will make a tremendous difference to the targets that the Iraqis could hit if they decide to fire those missiles from Kuwait,'' Dodds said. He said the reported deployment was large, ``but it obviously is not all the missiles the Iraqis have got. ``They would be foolish to move everything they have up into Kuwait. So one must only assume that they have possibly at least the same number again, possibly more, somewhere in Iraq,'' he said. The American, British and Saudi air forces based at Dhahran, about 250 miles from Kuwait, would be well within the missile's range. Iraq first demonstrated its longer-range missile capability on Feb. 29, 1988 when a missile struck the Iranian capital of Tehran, about 400 miles from the Iraqi border. In its May issue, Jane's Soviet Intelligence Review said 189 such missiles were fired at Iranian cities in the seven succeeding weeks during the so-called war of the cities. The Soviet Union first supplied Scud B missiles to Iraq in the early 1970s and delievered hundreds during the Iran-Iraq War, Jane's said. According to Iranian reports, the al-Husayns achieved their longer range partly by reducing the explosive payload _ from 1,650 pounds for a Scud B to 418 pounds for an al-Husayn. Many of the warheads used against Iran were defective and did not explode, Jane's said, adding that the missile did not appear to highly accurate.

DOC.HEAD: Czechoslovaks Mark First Free Commemoration of 1968 Invasion
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS thruout to UPDATE with ceremonies, Soviets who protested invasion honored; sirens howl at noon, quotes, other details. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Sirens howled today to commemorate the 1968 Warsaw Pact invasion on the first anniversary that Czechoslovaks were able to mark without fear of police retaliation. In Prague, Mayor Jaroslav Koran honored seven Soviets who protested the invasion that ended the ``Prague Spring'' of liberalization and replaced it with more than two decades of hard-line Communism. Making the Soviets honorary Prague citizens, Koran told them their demonstration in Moscow's Red Square on Aug. 25, 1968, ``salvaged the conscience of their silent country.'' ``They protested against the ... shameful treason committed by the tyrants of the day on a small friendly country,'' Koran declared. The mayor, acting on a city council declaration last week, also formally stripped Soviet dictator Josef Stalin of honorary citizenship, along with Czechoslovakia's first Communist president and Gustav Husak, the Communist Party leader installed by Moscow in the wake of the invasion. Present at the ceremonies was Yelena Bonner, the widow of Soviet dissident Andrei Sakharov, who criticized the invasion. Bestowing the keys of the city to Ms. Bonner, Koran declared: ``She's always had the key to our hearts.'' Among the dignitaries gathered for the ceremony at City Hall were Soviet Ambassador Boris Pankin and Alexander Dubcek, the reformist Communist Party leader who engineered the 1968 reforms only to see them crushed by the invading tanks. Dubcek, 69, who came back from more than two years of official disgrace to become speaker of the nation's first free Parliament since 1948, chatted affably with Pankin. Their rapport was a striking example of the new reality in Eastern Europe, where democracies have replaced monolithic Communist rule in many countries. Just one year ago, riot police waded into thousands of protesters commemorating the Soviet-led invasion and those who had fought it and calling for democracy. Less than three months later, even larger protests led to the resignation of Czechoslovakia's Communist government and subsequent free elections. Earlier today a T-55 tank appeared in Wenceslas Square, where weeping Czechoslovaks pelted Soviet armor with rocks and garbage 22 years ago. This time, the spectators cheered. The Soviet-made tank was tipped onto its side by a crane and will be left standing through Sept. 6. Its belly bore the logos of Solidarity, the trade union movement that spearheaded democratization in Poland, and Civic Forum, President Vaclav Havel's political movement that guided Czechoslovakia's peaceful democratic revolution late last year. At daybreak, costumed members of the ``Jester Society'' student group swarmed through subway stations in a mock invasion of the city. It was a normal working day, and most people went about their morning business. Near Wenceslas Square, only a few craned their necks to listen to a two-minute cacophony of sirens at noon. But some took time to reminisce. Marie Kratochvilova related that she awoke Aug. 21, 1968 to a commotion in a neighboring apartment. She complained and found the neighbors making plans to flee the country. ```You're snoring away happily and don't realize that the Russians are occupying our country,''' the 56-year-old vendor recalled her neighbors as saying. On Monday, Civic Forum condemned domestic Communist leaders said to have invited foreign troops into the country in 1968. ``We continue to support the demand that these people who committed high treason and are guilty of opposing peace be put to trial,'' said a Civic Forum statement. No charges have been lodged against any of the deposed leadership for their role in the invasion, partially because of lack of evidence.

DOC.HEAD: Three-Time Loser: Thieves Take $1 Million in Jewelry from Oil Heiress
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Donn is cq in 5th graf
DOC.TEXT: Someone has made off with more than $1 million in diamonds and pearls from oil heiress Carolyn Skelly's mansion, the third time in seven years that her Bois Dore estate has been hit by jewelry thieves. In 1982, she also was robbed at gunpoint of $1 million in jewelry in New York City. Mrs. Skelly, believed to be in her 80s, said the jewelry taken in the latest heist Friday was not insured and she may just sell what's left. ``I stopped insuring my jewelry years ago. It got to be so expensive,'' she told The Providence Journal-Bulletin in an interview published today. Police had some suspects, said Lt. Donn Woods, but he did not elaborate. The investigation would include questioning all the guests at a champagne dinner dance Mrs. Skelly held a few hours before the theft, he said. Among the 75 to 100 guests was Columba Bush, President Bush's daughter-in-law, who was also a houseguest at the mansion for the night. Mrs. Skelly said she wore the jewelry during the party, then took it off before going to sleep at 1:30 a.m. The three rings, a diamond necklace, a diamond bracelet and a string of pearls were missing from her jewelry chest when she awoke at 8 a.m. She estimated she slept less than 15 feet from the unlocked jewelry chest, but ``I didn't hear a thing.'' In 1982, Mrs. Skelly was abducted at New York's LaGuardia Airport and robbed of $1 million in jewelry. Two years later, a former maid was arrested on charges of stealing more than $2 million in jewelry while Mrs. Skelly was away. In August 1986, she was confronted in her bedroom by a knife-wielding robber who stole a pillowcase full of jewelry valued at between $3 million and $5 million. It never was recovered. ``The world is getting scary today with all of these criminals,'' she said.

DOC.HEAD: Man Credited With Inventing Deep-Dish Pizza Dies
DOC.TEXT: Ike Sewell, the restaurateur credited with inventing ``Chicago-style,'' deep-dish pizza, has died at 87. Sewell died Monday of leukemia at Northwestern Memorial Hospital. Sewell's first love was the Mexican food he grew up on in Wills Point, Texas. But his partner in an early restaurant venture didn't like it, so they hit upon the idea of pizza. Sewell decided he he wanted something more filling than regular pizza. The pair began experimenting and hit upon the deep-dish style. They opened Pizzeria Uno in 1943, and their deep-dish pizza made in an oversized pie tin became one of Chicago's culinary trademarks. The popularity of the restaurant led Sewell to open Pizzeria Due down the street in 1955. Eight years later, he opened Su Casa, heralded as Chicago's first upscale Mexican restaurant. Sewell eventually agreed to allow others to franchise his pioneering pizza concept, and there are now more than 50 ``Original Chicago Pizzeria Uno'' restaurants across the nation. ``Chicago-style and deep-dish pizza are interchangeable terms,'' said Pizzeria Uno manager Page Townsley. ``It began here in 1943. It began right here in this restaurant, in this kitchen.'' Survivors include Sewell's wife, Florence Davis, and a niece. Services are scheduled for Wednesday in Chicago.

DOC.HEAD: Lawyer Indicted in Serial Killing Case
DOC.TEXT: More than two years after the first of nine murdered women was found near here, a serial murder case involving drugs, prostitution and now politics finally has its first official suspect. A Bristol County grand jury Monday charged lawyer Kenneth C. Ponte, 40, with the April 27, 1988, murder of Rochelle Clifford Dopierla. Ponte said he was innocent but he welcomed the indictment because his name circulated publicly for months. ``Mr. Ponte recognizes the fact that he has a very, very strong case before a trial jury,'' his defense attorney Kenneth Reddington said at Monday's bail hearing in Bristol County Superior Court. ``He needs a trial to clear his name.'' Dopierla was one of nine murder victims whose bodies were found along wooded roadways near this old whaling port city in southeastern Massachusetts between July 1988 and April 1989. Two other women are missing and presumed to be victims. All had histories of drug abuse and some were prostitutes. Bristol County District Attorney Ronald Pina portrayed Ponte as an unstable, cocaine-addicted man with violent tendencies. Pina said Ponte used prostitutes or women with histories of drug involvement to buy drugs, and Dopierla was preparing to expose him. ``The victim was going to come forward and be a witness against attorney Ponte,'' Pina told Superior Court Judge George Hurd during the arraignment and bail hearing. ``He began a pursuit of her. The record will show he tried to prevent her from testifying. He threatened to kill her.'' Pina was careful not to link Ponte to the other killings. But Ponte's lawyer said his client has been smeared in a guilt-by-association prosecution. ``This man has been under more intense pressure for the past six months than anyone I can imagine,'' Reddington said. ``His law practice, as you can well imagine, your honor, has been ruined.'' At arraignment, Ponte pleaded ``absolutely not guilty,'' in a loud, clear voice. Hurd set a $50,000 cash bail, and Ponte was released after his mother posted her house as security for bond. After the hearing, Ponte said his indictment was ``simply political showmanship on the part of Ron Pina.'' Pina, seeking re-election to a fourth term, faces a Sept. 18 Democratic primary challenge by lawyer Paul F. Walsh Jr., who has accused Pina of political motivation in his handling of the case. Pina denied any political motive in the timing of the indictments, saying of the grand jurors, ``They don't work for me.'' The 21-member panel began meeting in March 1989. It was Pina who in 1984 prosecuted the widely publicized Big Dan's tavern gang rape trial. Four were convicted; two were acquitted of charges they cheered during the attack.

DOC.HEAD: Iraqi Paper Warns of Harsh Winter for West
With PM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: An Iraqi newspaper warned today of a harsh winter for western nations and suggested the United States might face economic collapse because of its involvement in the Persian Gulf. The Baghdad-based Al-Iraq said fuel shortages would result from a U.N. embargo and the U.S.-led naval blockade against Iraq following its Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait. The paper was quoted by the official Iraqi News Agency. ``The daily said George Bush's crime against the Iraqi people led to cutting down the virtual supply of oil and the rise of its prices, the matter which predicts that the United States and the West would see besides the harsh winter, severe reductions and a fierce shock in the trade balance that might lead the American economy to total collapse,'' said the agency, monitored in Nicosia. It said the presence of U.S. troops in Saudi Arabia had already cost the United States $1.2 billion. It predicted the total by the end of the year would be $200 billion, and warned ``the American people that they would face acute economic and financial hardhips as a result of their president's rash adventure,'' INA said. In another editorial, the government newspaper Al-Thawra said the Iraqi decision to ban foreigners from traveling ``aims in its essence to avert big harm by the lesser harm,'' INA said. It said Al-Thawra praised the decision as one expressing the ``will of the Iraqi people and their natural and legitimate right for self-defense...'' Officials in Baghdad say they are moving citizens of ``aggressive countries'' to areas at risk of attack by U.S.-led military forces sent to Saudi Arabia to defend that oil-rich kingdom from Iraq.

DOC.HEAD: Pakistan To Extradite Soviet Hijackers
DOC.TEXT: Eleven prisoners from a Siberian labor camp who hijacked a jetliner to Pakistan will be extradited to the Soviet Union, Tass reported today. Soviet law officers will travel to Karachi to escort the prisoners home, the official news agency said, quoting Gulyam Aliyev, deputy KGB chairman in the Uzbekistan republic. Aliyev did not say when the extradition would occur. The Aeroflot Tupolev 154 jetliner, with 29 passengers and nine crew members, returned to the Uzbekistan capital of Tashkent on Monday night, Tass said. The prisoners, armed with guns and homemade explosives, overpowered their guards in midair on Sunday and hijacked the plane to Pakistan. The plane landed at Karachi International Airport on Monday with less than 15 minutes of fuel remaining. Airport officials said the hijackers surrendered about two hours after landing and sought political asylum. There have been at least 13 hijackings or attempted hijackings of Soviet aircraft since late May _ mostly by Soviet teen-agers or young men who said they wanted to live in Western countries. The latest incident began Sunday, when 15 prisoners were being transported from Neryungry, 3,100 miles east of Moscow, to the nearby city of Yakutsk in eastern Siberia. They forced the plane to return to Neryungry, where their labor camp was located, officials said. Six prisoners and 41 women and children passengers left the plane there, but two more convicts joined the hijackers, said Soviet Interior Ministry spokesman Yuri I. Arshenevsky. The plane then flew west to Krasnoyarsk in Siberia, where authorities negotiated with the hijackers for two hours and allowed the plane to refuel. The next stop was Tashkent, where a new crew came on board and the hijackers demanded to leave the country. Officials negotiated with them overnight before allowing the plane to take off for Pakistan. The independent news agency Interfax said the hijackers promised to free the hostages on arrival. Kadyr Atabayev, inspector of Uzbekistan's Civil Aviation Department, told Tass the convicts ``thoroughly searched the new crew before they could enter the plane.'' ``The criminals were nervous, fearing possible tricks'' from the authorities, Atabayev said. Tass quoted Deputy Interior Minister Ivan Shilov as saying there would be an investigation into how the convicts managed to commandeer the plane. The news agency said one of the prisoners apparently smuggled weapons onto the plane in an artificial limb.

DOC.HEAD: Current Quotations
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 1st quote to CORRECT typo in `President.'
DOC.TEXT: ``There's recognition of the fact that now demands are being made for the release of people, and that, I think, is the definition of hostages.'' _ President Bush, explaining why he finally started referring to the thousands of Westerners trapped in Iraq and Kuwait as ``hostages.''

``It's kind of hard to keep a good pilot on the ground. That's kind of like asking Picasso if he were going to paint again.'' _ Joseph Balzer, one of three former pilots convicted of flying a jetliner while under the influence of alcohol, saying he will fight to regain his license.

``We were just hoping the valley would open back up before we got here; it worked out.'' _ Linda Disosway of Atlanta, one of many tourists who returned to Yosemite Valley after being kept away for 11 days by wildfires.

DOC.HEAD: Forty-nine Rescued From Oil Rig
DOC.TEXT: Forty-nine men jumped from a drifting, waterlogged oil rig into the stormy North Sea at dawn today and were rescued by Danish ships, navy and oil company spokesmen said. The men wore survival suits when they plunged in 46 mph winds into waves of 26 to 33 feet. Lifeboats transferred them to two vessels bound for the western Danish port of Esbjerg. The Danish navy said no one was injured among the 46 Norwegians, one Briton and two Dutch citizens. Rescuers said the rig had begun to take on water and was in danger of capsizing. The Norwegian rig, named West Gamma and chartered by Phillips, served as a floating hotel for oil workers at North Sea stations. It was being towed between stations Monday when the towline broke in a storm. Danish navy spokesman Sven Voxtorp said the rig ran aground early today in about 100 feet of water 54 miles west of the West German island of Sylt.

DOC.HEAD: Pentagon Reports Copter Crash in Saudi Desert; No Injuries
DOC.TEXT: A U.S. Army helicopter crashed during a nighttime training flight in northwestern Saudi Arabia on Monday, resulting in no injuries to the crewmen aboard the aircraft, the Pentagon said today. The OH-58 Kiowa scout helicopter was flying in an unpopulated area about 22 miles northwest of Dhahran, the main Saudi air base at which U.S. forces are arriving for Operation Desert Shield, according to a statement by U.S. Central Command in Dhahran released here. The command is responsible for U.S. operations in the Middle East. No other details were provided. The cause of the accident is under investigation, the statement said.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Hears Arguments on How to Consider Sexually Explicit Pictures.
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 5 grafs to recast, clarifying that hearing Monday was on prosecution motion, not on defense motion. Picks up 6th graf pvs, `They are...'. Note contents of 5th graf.
DOC.TEXT: Whether Robert Mapplethorpe's sexual photos should be considered on their own or in the context of his other works was the question at a hearing on obscenity charges against a museum and its director. Municipal Judge David J. Albanese considered arguments Monday on a prosecution request to limit the case to five pictures identified in the indictment against the Contemporary Arts Center and its director, Dennis Barrie. Defense lawyers earlier had asked Albanese to dismiss the misdemeanor charges of pandering obscenity, contending that the 175-picture exhibit seen as a whole could not be considered obscene. Albanese ended the hearing Monday without issuing a ruling on either request. The photographs in question Monday depict homosexual sex acts. One shows a man urinating into another man's mouth; others picture objects inserted into men's anuses. But other photos in the exhibit are close-ups of flowers. ``They are difficult images, but they are important to understanding the artist's approach,'' said Martin Friedman, director of the Walker Art Center in Minneapolis. Friedman testified for the defense that each picture in the exhibit had to be considered as part of the entire show. He said the Cincinnati gallery's contract required it to show all the pictures. ``The whole purpose of an exhibition is to set up context,'' Friedman said. ``You can't isolate some of the pictures and talk about the exhibition.'' The judge asked a defense witnesses whether sexually explicit pictures were required as part of a survey of the late Mapplethorpe's life. ``Is there some danger'' if the gallery ``was just a vehicle for exhibiting erotic photographs for people who wanted to see erotic photographs?'' Albanese asked Evan Turner, director of the Cleveland Museum of Art. ``I don't think any of the photographs in this exhibition fits that definition,'' Turner replied. Judith Reisman, a communications consultant who said she has studied sexually explicit photographs for the Justice Department, testified that photographs viewed individually would have affected visitors. ``But I go in to see the exhibit as a whole, don't I?'' asked defense lawyer H. Louis Sirkin. ``Absolutely not, absolutely not,'' Ms. Reisman said. ``There are people who walked in and saw one picture and left.'' The judge earlier ordered Barrie and the gallery to stand trial Sept. 24 on one count involving pictures that show nude children. The charge of using children in material involving nudity and the other of pandering to obscenity each would carry a maximum penalty of six months in jail and a $1,000 fine for Barrie. The gallery could be fined $5,000 on each charge. Albanese has not determined if the obscenity pandering count will be tried, or whether the five photos can be judged separately from the rest in the show. The Mapplethorpe exhibit closed in Cincinnati on May 26. It then moved to Boston, where it opened Aug 2. at the Institute for Contemporary Art.

DOC.HEAD: Cruise Ship's Lifeboat Dumps Crew Members Into Skagway Harbor; Two Dead
DOC.TEXT: A winch holding a cruise ship lifeboat broke during a safety drill, dumping several crew members into the frigid waters of Skagway Harbor and drowning two of them, police said. Twelve people were pulled from the water after Monday's accident, and rescuers tried unsuccessfully for more than an hour to revive the two victims on the dock, said Chris Kirk, a reporter for public radio station KHNS who was at the scene. Police officer Eric Sauer said identities of the dead and the survivors were unavailable. Officials had not confirmed how many people were in the lifeboat when it fell, and it was uncertain whether more bodies might still be in the water, he said. The accident occurred Monday afternoon as the cruise ship Regent Sun was docked at Skagway, Fire Chief Carl Mulvihill said. No passengers were in the lifeboat. Several of the survivors were treated at the Skagway clinic, and two were flown to Bartlett Memorial Hospital in Juneau. Nursing supervisor Nina Rajala identified the two as Jorge Henriquez, 38, and Juan Matute, 23. Their hometowns were unavailable. Henriquez was treated and released, and Matute was held Monday night for observation, Rajala said. The Coast Guard and Skagway police were investigating the accident. The two victims apparently were trapped under the boat when it fell on top of them, said Jeff Brady, publisher of the Skagway News. All the crew members were wearing life jackets, Brady said. When the winch broke the lifeboat flipped and fell into the water, Brady said. ``One man told me he just saw bodies flying out of the thing,'' he said. A similar accident occurred last summer in Juneau when eight crew members of the cruise ship Daphne fell into Gastineau Channel during a drill. None was seriously injured.

DOC.HEAD: In Syracuse, N.Y., Man Convicted Of Assaulting Jogger
DOC.TEXT: A prosecutor says she will ask for ``as much prison time as possible'' for a 23-year-old man convicted of leaving a jogger staked to the ground to die after raping and assaulting her. ``This is one of the most heinous crimes ever committed in this county,'' Onondaga County Assistant District Attorney Mary Felasco said Monday after jurors found Erwin Williams guilty. Williams, of Syracuse, was convicted of second-degree attempted murder, rape, sexual abuse, unlawful imprisonment, assault and weapons possession. Felasco said she would seek consecutive sentences on the rape and attempted murder charges when Williams is sentenced by state Supreme Court Justice Walter Gorman on Sept. 5. ``The evidence showed Williams attempted to murder her after he raped her because she could identify him to police. To me, those are two separate crimes,'' she said. Both charges carry sentences of 8 and one-third to 25 years. Defense attorney William Rose argued before the jury Monday that discrepancies in testimony raised a reasonable doubt about his client's guilt. The jury took just 2{ hours deliberating. Rose said Williams' admission to authorities was the most damaging piece of evidence, even though he later refused to sign the statement. Defendants' admissions similarly helped bring a conviction two days earlier in a 1989 rape and assault of a jogger in Manhattan's Central Park. That case attracted national publicity attributed by many to the victim's status as an investment banker who fell prey to youths engaged in a rampage they called ``wilding'' in Central Park. The 43-year-old suburban Syracuse woman was attacked by two men four years ago in Onondaga Lake Park. She was beaten, choked and stabbed 11 times, and then shoelaces were used to tie her hands to sticks that were thrust into the ground. But she managed to pull free and walk more than two miles with a knife protruding from her neck for help. She recovered from her injuries and testified in a closed session of the trial. Also testifying against Williams were his ex-wife, Gwendolyn Williams, and co-defendant Ronald Jock, 32, of Brasher.
