Rose pointed out that Jock testified as part of a deal in which he pleaded guilty to attempted murder last month in exchange for prosecutors' agreeing to recommend a 7- to 14-year sentence. The defense attorney noted that Ms. Williams came forward earlier this year only after authorities ``very conveniently'' set aside charges of child endangerment against her. ``It's kind of incredible that she waited four years to tell her story to police,'' he added.

DOC.HEAD: Saudi Youths Respond to King's Call to Defend Country
With PM-Gulf Roundup
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 3 grafs to UPDATE with thousands of volunteers sighted at military centers. Picks up 3rd graf pvs: `On Monday . . .'
DOC.TEXT: Young Saudis massed in front of military centers throughout the nation today in response to King Fahd's call for them to volunteer to protect the country, residents and officials said. Residents in the capital city of Riyadh said they could see large groups of volunteers at the various military posts around the sprawling city. The numbers were estimated to be in the thousands. On Monday, the king ordered the opening of recruitment and training centers to strengthen the armed forces against the threat posed by Iraqi troops massed in Kuwait near the Saudi border. ``There has been a very positive and gratifying response to King Fahd's call,'' said Lt. Col. Ibrahim Y. Baqi, the commander of civil defense in Jiddah. He said that in his area alone, thousands of Saudis had rushed to sign up even before the king's appeal. Saudi Arabia does not have a draft, but the issue has been under consideration by the Council of Ministers for years. ``I admire the good response and high spirit of Saudi citizens who have shown heartening readiness to join the armed forces in order to defend their homeland and the holy places,'' King Fahd told the council. Preachers at mosques all over the country also have asked Saudis to volunteer for military duty, telling them in sermons to ``be ready for a period of Jihad (holy war).'' The call for Saudi volunteers comes as tens of thousands of foreign troops are arriving in Saudi Arabia as part of a U.S.-led buildup of a multinational force to defend the kingdom against Iraq. Iraq, which invaded Kuwait on Aug. 2 and declared it had annexed it four days later, has massed troops along the Saudi border. Before the king's order, Saudi volunteers had to go to military camps or civil defense departments to enlist. Now, the Council said, all concerned government departments have been ordered to take steps to set up training centers to register volunteers for the various sectors of the armed forces. ``We will not be surprised like the Kuwaitis,'' Interior Minister Prince Naif was quoted as saying during a recent meeting in Jiddah with some Saudi officials, journalists and intellectuals. Baqi said civil defense volunteers will undergo crash courses in first aid, ambulance duties, firefighting and rescue operations. King Fahd also used Monday night's regular council session to allay fears of any shortages in foodstuffs, money liquidity or any other commodities. ``The government has taken all steps to maintain the stability of the market,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Army Sets up Special Mail System for Operation Desert Shield
With PM-Gulf-Bush, Bjt
DOC.NOTE: EDs: SUBS 9th graf, 3rd Armored... to CORRECT address, inserting dropped `New York'
DOC.TEXT: The Army says it has set up a special mail address system to speed delivery of letters to GIs now operating in Saudi Arabia. Mail for members of the seven Army units now in Saudi Arabia as part of Operation Desert Shield should be addressed with the following New York Army Postal Office numbers: _101st Airborne Division: APO New York 09309. _82nd Airborne Division: APO New York 09656. _24th Mechanized Infantry Division: APO New York 09315. _1st Corps Support Command Fort Bragg: APO New York 09657. _197th Infantry Brigade: APO New York 09315. _11th Air Defense Artillery Brigade: APO New York 09656. _3rd Armored Cavalry Regiment: APO New York 09209. Mail directed to soldiers' home stations will be redirected to their Saudi location, the Army said. The Pentagon says only the Army has set up a special postal system for troops in Saudi Arabia. For members of other services deployed there, mail should be addressed to the U.S. base from which they deployed. The mail will be forwarded.

DOC.HEAD: African Soldiers Board Warships, Preparing to Sail to Liberia
DOC.TEXT: A West African task force to halt the fighting in Liberia boarded warships today, and diplomats said the hundreds of soldiers were ready to sail for the besieged capital of Monrovia. Soldiers, tanks and other weapons boarded the ships after rebel leader Charles Taylor refused to go to a meeting he had earlier agreed to attend to discuss a cease-fire with Gambian leader Sir Dawda Jawara. Jawara is current chairman of the Economic Community of West African States. The six-nation army was expected to leave Wednesday or Thursday from Freetown, the capital of Sierra Leone which neighbors Liberia, according to African and Western diplomats. Taylor has threatened to attack any foreign troops that intervene in Liberia's bloody 8-month-old war. African leaders have ordered their soldiers to fight, if necessary, to force a truce in the three-sided conflict. On Monday, President Samuel Doe's soldiers and a rival rebel faction under Prince Johnson, which controls most of Monrovia, announced a truce. Johnson has pledged to hold Monrovia's port for the arrival of the African force, which Doe also has welcomed. Soldiers loyal to the two men told a diplomat who ventured into the streets of Monrovia on Monday that they were prepared to join forces to resist any attack by Taylor's men. They said they welcomed the West African intervention and would not fire on the task force. Taylor has the largest army in the country, around 10,000 men, but most are ill-trained peasant recruits and young boys. For weeks, Doe's soldiers have kept them at bay 4 miles east of the clifftop presidential mansion. Johnson's and Doe's men have fended off several attacks from Taylor, who last week launched a last-ditch bid to oust Doe and capture the port before the West Africans arrive. The war began with a Dec. 24 invasion from the northeastern border with Ivory Coast by 200 rebels, who accused Doe of corruption and tribalism. Thousands of civilians joined their ranks, seeking vengeance against government soldiers who were unable to hold back the rebels and instead killed thousands of peasants. Johnson split with Taylor in February to form a rival faction. Monrovia has been besieged by the three armies since the end of June, when water supplies, electricity and telephone communications were cut. Those who have not fled or been evacuated have been without fresh food supplies for weeks in the city, where bodies rot in the streets and no hospitals are operating.

DOC.HEAD: Summer Holiday Drivers Create Japan's Longest Traffic Jam Ever
DOC.TEXT: A powerful typhoon combined with the summer holiday rush to create the longest traffic jam in Japan's history _ an 84-mile-long highway mess, the Japan Highway Corp. said Tuesday. ``It is the longest traffic jam on record, and it was basically caused by bad luck,'' corporation spokesman Katsutoshi Furuya said. ``Many drivers were on the road that day because the typhoon had kept them off it the day before,'' he said. ``Everything just seems to have come together in the worst way.'' About 15,000 vehicles were involved in the traffic jam, which occurred Aug. 12, he said. Japanese generally take holidays from Aug. 10-19, to mark ``O-bon,'' or the Festival of the Dead. It is a time when families gather to pay respects to their ancestors. Typhoon Winona had caused highway officials to close several sections of roads across the country just as the holiday season was beginning. The record-setting traffic snarl occurred on a highway between Hyogo and Shiga prefectures in western Japan.

DOC.HEAD: Basque Separatist Killed When Bomb Goes Off Early, Police Say
DOC.TEXT: A man believed to be a Basque separatist was killed Tuesday when a bomb he was going to plant outside a supermarket blew up, a government spokesman said. The blast took place just outside the Mamut supermarket in the San Sebastian suburb of Oyarzun, said the provincical official, who was not identified. He said the dead man, 23-year-old Jose Maria Aranzeistrouqui of the nearby town of Usurbil, triggered the explosion while handling the bomb he had placed under a seat of his car. Police believe he was attempting to take the bomb out of the car and place it near the supermarket. The supermarket has been the target of previous attacks by ETA, a Basque separatist organization. ETA seeks independence from Spain for the three-province northern Basque region. Since taking up arms in 1968, ETA has claimed responsibility for killing more than 600 people, mainly police, military and Civil Guard officers. ETA is an acronym standing for homeland and liberty in the Basque language. So far this year, the group has claimed responsibility for the deaths of 13 people.

DOC.HEAD: Iraq Offers to Negotiate, But Not Withdraw From Kuwait
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Combines pvs, ADDS more from Saddam, Aziz. TRIMS. No pickup.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos NY5,9,13,15,BX4
DOC.TEXT: Iraq said today it is willing to negotiate a settlement to the Persian Gulf crisis but did not offer to withdraw its troops from Kuwait and said that if a war breaks out, ``America will lose and be humiliated.'' ``We are ready to talk,'' Iraq's foreign minister, Tariq Aziz, said at a news conference in Jordan. ``My president made proposals that we are ready to put all the cards on the table'' at a U.N. Security Council meeting. However, Aziz said all regional issues, including Israel's occupation of the West Bank and Gaza Strip, must be settled according to the same principles. When a reporter asked Aziz if Iraq was prepared to discuss withdrawing from Kuwait, which Baghdad invaded on Aug. 2, he did not directly reply, saying only that all issues in the Persian Gulf must be discussed. In a statement on Iraqi television directed to President Bush, Iraqi President Saddam Hussein said today that foreign detainees are being treated well and are only being held to prevent an attack by U.S.-led forces. The detention of the foreigners is a ``product of aggression against the Arab nation and Iraq,'' Saddam said. ``President Bush is the one carrying out that aggression along with his allies.'' Iraq has begun rounding up the thousands of foreigners in Iraq and Kuwait and placing them around military installations. Saddam insisted that ``what happened to the Americans so far is the lightest possible treatment that is dictated by necessity, even by American standards'' of human rights. He said the presence of U.S. troops in Saudi Arabia violates holy Moslem sites there, and that if a war occurs: ``You are going to lose and you will be defeated and we will be the victors with the help of God.'' Saddam's statement was read on television by an unidentified announcer and was translated by Cable News Network. Aziz said he had carried a message from Saddam to Jordanian officials, but he declined to provide details. Iraq has been pressuring Jordan to continue to allow Iraqi goods to pass through Jordan's Red Sea port of Aqaba. The port has been a key loophole for Iraq in its effort to break the embargo. Aziz denied that the foreigners were hostages, calling them ``guests,'' and warned against any attack on Iraq or Kuwait. ``The Americans have prepared the ground for a war of aggression. If the Americans think this is a vacation like they had in Panama and Grenada, this will be a bloody conflict and America will lose and be humilitaed.'' Earlier today, Egypt urged Saddam to withdraw Iraqi troops from Kuwait or face a war ``that will devour everything,'' and Britain said the West must strangle Iraq economically despite its threats against foreign hostages. President Bush planned to order thousands of military reservists into active duty as early as today to bolster U.S. forces depleted by the massive deployment of troops to protect Saudi Arabia from a possible Iraqi attack. In another sign of growing Arab support for the U.S.-led multinational force in Saudi Arabia, Syria confirmed today that it was contributing troops. ``Syria began today sending its military forces to participate in the defense of Saudi Arabia,'' an official source said on condition of anonymity. In the Persian Gulf, Defense Secretary Dick Cheney met with Saudi officials to share military intelligence and to discuss the possible sale of additional F-15 fighters and heavy tanks to bolster the kingdom's defenses. The international economic embargo against Iraq got a boost from Yemen today when that country assured the U.N. Security Council it would turn away an Iraqi oil tanker that had ignored warning shots fired by U.S. warships. But two Iraqi oil tankers that had been turned away from Saudi Arabia last week were seen docked in Yemen's port of Aden today, raising new questions about Yemen's commitment to the embargo. A port official said the Al-Fao and the Al-Qadissiyah tankers were docked when he arrived at work today. Diplomatic sources, who also spoke on condition of anonymity, said the tankers may have arrived before today's U.N. session. The Security Council deferred action on a proposal that multinational forces be allowed to use force to back up U.N. sanctions. Bush has already authorized U.S. ships to use minimum force to interdict Iraqi vessels. At the first major European gathering to deal with the Persian Gulf crisis, the nine-nation Western European Union decided today to send forces to the gulf, and urged the Security Council to take measures to enforce the embargo. The union effectively gave the go-ahead to three nations _ Belgium, the Netherlands and Italy _ to commit naval forces to the tense region. A Spanish official at the meeting said his nation will send four ships to the gulf. Iraq, meanwhile, has moved 800 ballistic missiles into Kuwait in addition to the tens of thousands of troops and hundreds of tanks massed on the Saudi border, the editor of Jane's Soviet Intelligence Review said in London today. The editor, Henry Dodds, said some of the missiles have a range of 400 miles, or far enough to hit U.S. troops and major Saudi cities. With the United States building up its armed forces in Saudi Arabia and blocking Iraqi ports with an armada of ships, Iraq has moved to use Westerners stranded inside Kuwait and Iraq as human shields. For the first time, Bush on Monday publicly referred to the 21,000 Westerners, including 3,000 Americans and 4,500 Britons, as hostages and demanded their release. Egypt's Hosni Mubarak, who has rallied Arab opposition to the invasion, today urged Saddam, Iraq's president, to withdraw his forces from Kuwait. In a statement read on state-owned TV and radio, Mubarak said he was making his appeal ``in the name of everything sacred on our Arab soil ... in the name of Islam, the religion of peace ... in the name of Arab nationalism ... in the name of every man, woman and child on our Arab land.'' ``In the name of light, good and right, I appeal to President Saddam Hussein to save both man and entity in our Arab world from a destructive war that will devour everything,'' Mubarak said. ``God only knows what the terrifying outcome will be if war begins, or how much damage there will be if the fire erupts, taking us backward into total darkness and loss.'' In London, Mrs. Thatcher said today that she will not negotiate to secure the release of the British citizens detained by Iraq. ``As President Bush pointed out yesterday, Saddam Hussein is trying in his tactics to hide behind Western women and children and use them as human shields and use them as part of his negotiations,'' she said at a news conference. She called for another U.N. resolution to authorize the use of military force to make the international embargo against Iraq work.

DOC.HEAD: City Pet Store Features Exotic Animals For Display
DOC.TEXT: Leopards and llamas and doves. Oh my. Those are among the exotic denizens of Animal Kingdom, a pet store that serves as a zoo for urban children and home for show business animals. In addition to the usual assortment of puppies, kittens, reptiles and fish, the store has a leopard that stars in commercials, a duck that used to appear on a children's program and an organ grinder's monkey that shares his cage with a toy fox terrier. ``We have one rule about our exotic animals _ they have to be able to work,'' said general manager Steve Maciontek. ``That way they aren't just sitting in their cages all the time. That's not good for them.'' So Joshua the llama pulls a cart at parades, Luther the leopard appears in commercials, and the 30-odd doves in the store are rented out for weddings, serving as centerpieces at the bride and groom's table. Maciontek said the 10,000 square-foot store has a special exhibitor's license that allows it to house and display the 35 exotic animals it rents out, but never sells. When they're not earning their keep, the store's animals serve as entertainment for customers and school children who visit the store for free tours. ``When I get an inner city kid that's never been to a zoo, and I see his eyes light when he sees the leopard, it makes it all worthwhile,'' Maciontek said. The store on the city's north side averages at least two tours a day during summer. Maciontek said the purpose is not only to expose children to animals, but to teach them about caring for pets and exotic animals. Twice a month, employees take animals to hospitals and nursing homes, offering ``pet therapy'' to patients, Maciontek said. ``What we're trying to get across with our store is that animals are only as wild as we make them,'' he said. ``People are shocked when we go right into the cages to clean the animals, and the leopard or the tiger licks our hands.'' Only one of the store's animals is endangered, a rhinoceros hornbill named Harriet. The 10-pound black-and-orange horned bird is similar to a toucan. Federal officials inspect the store every year, checking to see that the animal cages are large enough and that they're being fed the right diet. Maciontek said the store occasionally gets complaints from animal rights activists who don't think traditionally wild animals should be in captivity. But he contends that the animals are well-cared for and fare better than they might if they were in the jungle.

DOC.HEAD: Syria Sending Troops To Saudi Arabia
DOC.NOTE: Eds: RECASTS to clarify Syria sending troops to bolster Arab forces. No pickup.
DOC.HEAD: With PM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Syria, Iraq's main Arab foe, said today it was sending troops to Saudi Arabia to help defend the kingdom against a possible Iraqi attack. ``Syria began today sending its military forces to participate in the defense of Saudi Arabia should the kingdom be exposed to an external aggression,'' a government statement said. Saudi official sources sid last week that more than 1,000 Syrian soldiers already had already arrived in the kingdom. Damascus would not comment on the earlier report. Today's government statement was carried by state radio and the official news agency. It did not say how many soldiers would be sent to the kingdom. It said Syria was ``complying to the Arab decision taken at the last summit conference in Cairo which provides for fulfilling Saudi Arabia's request for assistance in defending itself.'' At the summit in Cairo earlier this month, 12 of 21 Arab League members resolved to send forces to Saudi Arabia and other Persian Gulf countries requesting help in defending against a possible Iraqi attack. The three other factors which prompted the decision, the Syrian statement said, were Syria's ``readiness to defend Islam's holy shrines; its belief that the Gulf region should not be left to the foreigners and that Arab troops should replace these foreign forces there; and its conviction that the move constitutes a national duty that prevente division in Arab ranks.'' Syria has been a chief critic of Western policy and especially U.S. policy in the region. Its agreement to send troops may improve its relations with the West, especially with Britain, which severed ties with Damascus in 1987 over alleged Syrian involvement in an abortive attempt to blow up an Israeli jetliner at London's Heathrow Airport. Syria also is condemned by the U.S. State Department as one of the countries that sponsor terrorism.

DOC.HEAD: U.S., Western Countries Consult About Persian Gulf Crisis
With AM-US-Gulf, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: There is plenty of consultation, but the United States and other Western countries are stopping short of all-out coordination of their responses to Iraqi initiatives in the Persian Gulf, administration officials said Tuesday. ``It is not that we sit down and say, `Let's make sure that we do exactly the same thing','' said one administration official, who asked not to be identified. The same official said there have been instances where American diplomats planning to meet with the Iraqis had been told by their British and French counterparts, ``You can speak for us, too.'' Another example was the administration's rejection Sunday of Saddam Hussein's suggestion that he would free foreign nationals in Iraq if President Bush withdrew U.S. forces from Saudi Arabia and a worldwide trade embargo against Baghdad were lifted. ``I can't tell you specifically how we discussed that over the weekend,'' State Department spokesman Richard L. Boucher said. ``But all throughout this crisis, we've been in very close touch with other countries both at the United Nations, in capitals, and in Washington. ``There are a variety of countries whose citizens are in similar circumstances. And, of course, we have approached the Iraqis jointly as well as consulted amongst ourselves.'' The five permanent members of the United Nations Security Council _ the United States, China, Britain, France and the Soviet Union _ are discussing the possibility of a joint military operation under U.N. auspices. When asked whether there were discussions about the Iraqi demand that the embassies in Kuwait be closed, Boucher said, ``We have discussed this clearly with other governments ... and of course we work with other governments at the United Nations. But I'm not going to speculate at this point on what will happen either by the Iraqis or what our reaction might be.'' Boucher also said that the Iraqi announcement had ``absolutely no legal standing'' and that the United States would hold Iraq accountable for its treatment of American diplomats. Britain and other European countries also said they rejected the Iraqi demand. In Paris, where the nine-nation Western European Union decided Tuesday to send forces to the Persian Gulf, the organization's secretary general, Willem van Eekelen, said, ``We in Western Europe see the need to act so that the United States is not left to have to do the job alone.''

DOC.HEAD: Gasoline Prices Up on Wall Street, at the Pump
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New throughout to UPDATE with prices moving higher today. A version also moved on financial wires.
DOC.HEAD: With LaserGraphic
DOC.TEXT: Wholesale unleaded gasoline prices hit a new high on the New York Mercantile Exchange for the fifth day in a row today, crude oil prices were up and a nationwide survey showed retail fuel prices rising quickly. ``The market's very concerned about possible military escalation, which of course implies possible damage to the Saudi oil supply,'' said Ann-Louise Hittle, a senior oil analyst with Shearson Lehman Brothers Inc. In early trading this morning, the price of unleaded gasoline shot up to $1.06 per gallon for September delivery, 4{ cents higher than a record Monday at the Merc. The exchange is a crucial market for petroleum and a pacesetter for retail prices. After peaking at $1.015, unleaded gasoline closed at $1.003 per gallon Monday, 4.28 cents over Friday's late price, part of a series of record unleaded gasoline futures prices that began last Wednesday. The September contract price of benchmark light sweet crude oil rose 14 cents per 42-gallon barrel to $28.70 by midmorning today after dipping 7 cents on Monday. Contracts for later months all rose, suggesting that traders believe a long siege in the Persian Gulf will cause major supply problems. The market was responding partly to President Bush's declaration on Monday that Americans held in Iraq and Kuwait are ``hostages'' and that the United States holds Iraq responsible, traders said. ``More players think the crisis is going to last longer,'' Hittle said. Anxiety over supplies also pushed up gasoline prices at the pump. The American Automobile Association said its nationwide check of unleaded self-serve regular averaged $1.237 a gallon Monday, up 2.1 cents from a week earlier. The average is 16.2 cents higher since the crisis began with Iraq's invasion of Kuwait on Aug. 2, the AAA said. Home heating oil for September delivery closed Monday at 82.96 cents per gallon, up 2.42 cents from Friday's close. The price of natural gas stayed sluggish Monday, falling from $1.440 to $1.417 per 1,000 cubic feet for September delivery. In early trading today, home heating oil was up 3.69 cents to 86.65 cents per gallon, while natural gas dropped to $1.415 per 1,000 cubic feet at today's opening.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS Livingtson, Mont.-dated 3rd item in rdp to add that judge decided not to issue arrest warrant; lawyer posted bond
DOC.TEXT: Actor Dennis Quaid, accused of making false statements to obtain a Montana resident fishing license, failed to appear in court. His lawyer, Joe Swindlehurst, said Quaid simply forgot to show up Friday. Quaid, the star of such movies as ``Great Balls of Fire,'' ``The Right Stuff'' and ``The Big Easy,'' keeps a home near here. He was accused Aug. 13 of falsely stating that he is a Montana resident on a license bought May 19. Swindlehurst said the charge amounted to a difference of opinion. ``Dennis has property here and calls this place home,'' he said. ``I'm sure he considers himself a resident.'' Justice of the Peace Deanna Egeland said she did not sign an arrest warrant for Quaid after he failed to show because Swindlehurst posted $115 bond Monday. Swindlehurst also entered an innocent plea on behalf of his client. The $115 bond is the amount of the fine for a first-offense conviction, Egeland said.

DOC.HEAD: Europe Decides To Send Forces To Persian Gulf
With PM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS thruout to UPDATE with decision to keep embassies in Kuwait open, recasts, trims. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: The nine-nation Western European Union decided today to step up and coordinate military operations in the Persian Gulf and urged the U.N. Security Council to take added measures to enforce sanctions against Iraq. The union, the only European forum dealing with security and defense, effectively gave the go-ahead to three nations _ Belgium, the Netherlands and Italy _ to commit naval forces to the tense region. Foreign and defense ministers warned Iraq of ``serious consequences'' should foreign nationals trapped in Iraq and Kuwait be harmed. The meeting, the first major European gathering to deal with the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait, was followed by a working lunch of the 12 European Community foreign ministers. The ministers rejected an Iraqi ultimatum to close foreign embassies in Kuwait by Friday. Diplomats are to ``remain in place as representatives of our governments,'' Italian Foreign Minister Gianni de Michelis announced. He said, however, that diplomats are not to use force to keep the missions open. Western Europe initially offered an array of cautious responses to the Persian Gulf crisis, but Iraqi President Saddam Hussein's plan to turn foreign nationals into Iraqi hostages has drawn Europe toward a tougher response. French Foreign Minister Roland Dumas opened the meeting by calling the trapped Westerners hostages, saying their plight ``revolts us.'' It was the first time France, which has the second largest military force in the gulf after the United States, referred to the Westerners as hostages. An estimated 560 French nationals are in Iraq and Kuwait. The ministers stressed their wish for a solution with Arab nations, ``the first concerned'' by the crisis. The military forces will remain under their respective national commands. Coordination is to extend to zones of operation, task sharing, logistical support and information exchanges, according to a final communique. Armed forces chiefs are to meet Friday to work out details. The union also wants to cooperate with the large U.S. forces in the gulf, the communique said without elaboration. ``Automatically, there will be a need for coordination,'' Belgian Defense Minister Guy Coeme said after the meeting. Coeme said there was no explicit decision on the use of force by European vessels to enforce the embargo. The Western European Union's members are France, Britain, West Germany, Italy, Belgium, the Netherlands, Luxembourg, Spain and Portugal. France, Iraq's largest arms supplier in the West, has reacted cautiously but made a military commitment. Paris sent eight warships and 3,800 men. But to placate the Arab world, France also dispatched a fleet of diplomats to explain its position and seek an Arab solution. On Sunday, Paris said it would respond with ``firmness'' to possible violations of the U.N. embargo against Iraq. It did not elaborate. Despite a strong start in sending naval and air force units to help defend Saudi Arabia, Britain only belatedly joined the United States in decreeing Saturday that shots could be fired to enforce the embargo.

DOC.HEAD: Last U.S. Network Crew Leaves Baghdad
DOC.TEXT: CBS anchorman Dan Rather and eight CBS staffers, the last U.S. network crew still in Iraq covering Persian Gulf crisis developments there, were ordered out of Baghdad and left today, CBS said. The CBS contingent, which includes correspondent Allen Pizzey, now are in Amman, Jordan. They had been in Baghdad since last Wednesday, arriving a day after an ABC crew led by ``Nightline'' anchorman Ted Koppel. Koppel left Baghdad on Thursday, followed several days later by his ABC colleagues. Iraqi officials made no threats to Rather and his CBS crew in ordering them out and just said that the journalists had ``outstayed their welcome,'' CBS spokeswoman Donna Dees said. ``We were told there was a plane out this morning, and we should be on it,'' she said. Despite Iraq's action, officials at NBC News and Cable News Network said they would continue trying to get their reporters into Iraq.

DOC.HEAD: Some US Troops Lack Anti-Chemical Gear, Want It Badly
DOC.NOTE: Eds: The following is based on a pool dispatch
DOC.TEXT: American troops stationed here before the huge buildup of the past two weeks are complaining they have not been issued suits designed to protect against chemical weapons. ``All these guys coming in here get gas masks and the suits but we get nothing,'' one Air Force airman said. ``They are treating us as if we don't count.'' A military spokesman said the shortage was discussed at a command staff briefing Tuesday and more suits are expected to arrive on transport planes in the next few days. Even so, the enlisted men's comments suggest how deep the fear of chemical weapons runs. Such weapons _ and Iraqi President Saddam Hussein's willingness to use them _ are prime topics of discussion among troops here. ``It's as much psychological as anything,'' one of the men, an Air Force master sergeant, said of the protective suits. ``We see everybody else with them and hear everything being said about Iraq's gas and chemicals but we get nothing.'' One Air Force sergeant, stationed in Saudi Arabia the past nine months, went as far as calling a news organization in the United States to voice his complaint. ``I was just fed up with the bureaucracy,'' the sergeant said Monday. ``Why should my guys be left naked?'' Pentagon ground rules prohibit the use of troops' names in news media pool dispatches from Saudi Arabia. In brief interviews with a dozen men stationed here as part of a standing U.S. military training operation, just one said he had chemical gear. ``I scrounged it up by cutting a deal,'' the Air Force sergeant said. The sergeant who called the states to complain said there are about 120 U.S. military personnel stationed at the training mission, most of them Air Force. The men conduct training with the Saudi military and also provide security, communications and other logistical support to a small U.S. compound on a Saudi air base. ``I don't have a suit. I don't have a gas mask. I don't have any of it,'' an Army sergeant said when asked whether he had the protective gear. Both Saudi and American officials have said they doubted Iraq has the capability to successfully use chemical weapons against the base. Iraq's missiles are not considered very accurate at long distances, and the United States has deployed missile-killing Patriot missile systems at strategic areas as a precaution. Also, Air Force officials have predicted U.S. or Saudi fighters could intercept any Iraqi planes that tried to cross into Saudi territory. But the men said they still would feel more comfortable with the anti-chemical gear and had requested it several times. One said he was told gear for the men stationed here full time was aboard a C-130 transport plane that arrived at their air base Monday. But when he went the plane, the man said he was told the chemical suits and gear already had been taken somewhere. ``Somewhere, but not here, not for us,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Official Says U.S. to Bolster Saudi Arsenal
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 2nd graf pvs `The official, ...' with 1 graf to ADD dropped word `no' `... no specific agreements were reached...' ^With AM-US-Gulf, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The United States will upgrade the Saudi military arsenal of U.S. F-15 fighter jets and heavy tanks, a senior Pentagon official said Tuesday as Defense Secretary Dick Cheney concluded a whirlwind Mideast trip. The official, who spoke on condition on anonymity, said no specific agreements were reached during Cheney's visit with Saudi King Fahd and Defense Minister Prince Sultan. But the Iraqi threat to the oil-rich desert kingdom, and the need to upgrade the Saudi arsenal in the face of Iraqi President Saddam Hussein's million-man army, means the Bush administration will consider selling the Saudis high-powered F-15C and F-15D jet fighters as well as heavy tanks, the official said. The official refused to confirm a report that the vastly more sophisticated version of the fighter, the F-15E, was also on the Saudi's ``wish list,'' but he also declined to rule out such a sale. Such weaponry would have to be bought from the Pentagon's present stock to quickly bolster the Saudi arsenal. Cheney, heading back to Washington at the end of a four-day tour of five Persian Gulf states, told reporters traveling with him that the Bush administration also favors increasing aid to Egypt. Noting its ``very close relations'' with the United States, Cheney commended Egypt's active role in the Middle East and said ``President Bush and our government feel very strongly'' about increased military aid. Egypt receives about $1.3 billion a year in such aid. Cheney spoke after a 90-minute meeting with Youssef Sabry Abu-Taleb, Egypt's defense minister. He said he and Abu-Taleb ``compared notes'' on the crisis created by Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion and subsequent annexation of Kuwait. ``We hope that diplomatic efforts through the United Nations and economic sanctions will ultimately force Saddam to have to give up,'' Cheney said. Earlier, Cheney told reporters ``the Saudis are facing a very large tank army just across the border in Kuwait.'' ``We have worked with the Saudis in the past ... and basically what we're doing on a short-term basis is reinforcing their capabilities in these areas,'' Cheney said. He refused to confirm the exact kind of tanks that are under discussion, but noted that the Saudis have ``some substantial air assets'' from the United States, such as the F-15Cs and the F-15Ds. The Saudis earlier agreed to buy $3 billion worth of the Pentagon's most lethal tanks, the M1-A2, but they are not due for delivery until the mid-1990s. In the interim, possible candidates for purchase could be the M1-A1 version or the M-60 tank. The senior Pentagon official, speaking of the F-15s and heavy tanks, said the United States ``will move quickly to consider such requests.'' Bush already has waived a congressional limit to provide 12 more F-15s to the Saudis during the crisis. Cheney termed his swing through the Persian Gulf a successful one in that it had increased cooperation with Arab states with which the United States had rather cool relations in the past. Cheney met with King Fahd in the Saudi capital of Jiddah before flying to Cairo. Pentagon spokesman Pete Williams described the meeting as ``a good, positive discussion.'' Cheney arrived in Jiddah late Monday after a 15-hour swing through five Persian Gulf nations to seek support for the U.S.-led military operation against Iraq's occupation of Kuwait. He also met with the princes and sheiks who rule Bahrain, the United Arab Emirates, Oman and Qatar. On Monday, Sheik Zayed al Nahyan, president of the United Arab Emirates, welcomed the presence in his nation of a squadron of C-130 transport planes and its company of 575 American military personnel. The gesture was an important show of cooperation from a gulf nation that had never publicly acknowledged any major U.S. military presence on its soil.

DOC.HEAD: Cherry WHAT? Yes, Sausage. Cherry Sausage
DOC.TEXT: After following his father into cherry farming, Ray Pleva figures tart cherries are in his blood. They're certainly in his sausage. Pleva is negotiating to go nationwide with his award-winning cherry-pecan pork sausage. Such success, he hopes, could rescue Michigan's tart-cherry industry from doldrums caused by production exceeding demand. Daughter Cindy, the 1987-88 National Cherry Queen, is credited for inspiring the sausage, which prompts most people to make faces _ until they try it. ``We'd be talking about (cherry industry) problems at the dinner table, and she'd say, `Boy it would be nice if we could have something new.' The idea just popped up,'' he recalled. ``I thought about it 7,500 times.'' Finally, he experimented. He hit on the recipe _ 20 percent tart cherries, 4 percent pecans, the rest lean pork and spices _ in February 1988. The former cherry farmer started selling it at Pleva's Meats, a business he and wife Marge run in Cedar, in Leelanau County northwest of Traverse City. He says he is patenting the mixture, which has only a subtle cherry-nut flavor. In 1989, the product received the Michigan New Product Award, was featured on Cable News Network and was honored at the National Restaurant Show in Chicago. He said he has shipped the product to 49 states and is talking with national fast-food chains. ``We think we'll have good news for cherry farmers soon,'' he said, referring to Michigan's 1,100 growers, who produce about three-quarters of the nation's tart-cherry crop. Production of about 275 million pounds of tart cherries in 1987 exceeded national demand by about 55 million pounds, haunting growers for the next two seasons, said Dick Johnston of the Cherry Marketing Institute in Okemos. This season, supply and demand are expected to even out, he said. But products like Pleva's could boost tart cherries' share of the competitive fruit market, he said. Pleva is expanding his cherry-pecan line, making a spicier Italian cherry sausage, cherry pepperoni and cherry sausage snack sticks. He says his links are sources of vitamins A and C, because of the cherry content, and of fiber, because of the nuts. A Grand Rapids laboratory analysis showed his sausage links have 77 calories per ounce, nearly 60 of them from fat. A conventional breakfast sausage has 119 calories per ounce, nearly 95 from fat, said Allison Boomer of the American Dietetic Association. Though Pleva's sausage has lower calories and fat, she said: ``It wouldn't be something I'd eat often. To me, (sausage) is like eating butter.''

DOC.HEAD: Parents Sentenced to Life for Abuse
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 3rd graf, `The Platzes...', to add that the two would be eligible for parole after 10 years. Note contents
DOC.TEXT: A couple accused of torturing and sexually abusing five of their seven children were sentenced to life in prison. Emmet County Circuit Judge Richard Pajtas on Monday sentenced Gerald and Pamela Platz on a total of eight abuse and rape charges. Twelve other counts were dropped when the couple pleaded no contest in July. The Platzes were ordered to serve 16 to 24 months for child abuse, 10 to 15 years for second-degree criminal sexual conduct and life for first-degree criminal sexual conduct. The Platzes will be eligible for parole after 10 years. The former Mackinaw City couple were accused of repeatedly raping their five oldest children _ the oldest was 7. Gerald Platz allegedly cut the youngsters' arms with broken glass and stapled their skin and defecated on their faces, prosecutors said. Authorities said the abuse occurred between 1986 and 1988. All seven of the children, including one born after Mrs. Platz was jailed, have been put in adoptive homes. George Spanos, the defense lawyer for Mrs. Platz, does not have his client's permission to talk to reporters, his secretary said. There was no answer Monday at the phone for Dianne Hoffman, the lawyer for Platz. The Platzes told court officials they were themselves victims of abuse in families with alcoholism problems. But Pajtas was not swayed in his sentencing. ``Gerald Platz has subjected his family to a life of isolation, incest and horrible acts of sexual abuse that can only be described as barbaric, shocking and disgusting,'' the judge said. Prosecutor Diane Smith said the Platzes have ``damaged these children for life.'' ``These parents robbed their children of their innocence. Instead of watching videos of Bugs Bunny and Daffy Duck, they were subjected to `Debby Does Dallas.''' Traverse City police arrested the Platzes in September 1989.

DOC.HEAD: Armenia Considers Declaration of Independence
DOC.TEXT: Armenia's parliament debated a declaration of independence on Tuesday and considered setting up its own army for protection from neighboring Azerbaijan, Soviet media reported. Azerbaijan's president responded by calling for sanctions against Armenia and warning that his republic might be forced to take steps to guarantee its security, the Soviet news agency Tass said. Armenia, a predominantly Christian republic, and Azerbaijan, which is primarily Moslem, have been engaged in bloody conflict for more than two years over Nagorno-Karabakh, an enclave in Azerbaijan with a predominantly Armenian population. The spiral of ethnic violence, mixed with aspirations for independence, has been a major problem for the Kremlin. President Mikhail S. Gorbachev has repeatedly warned that such divisions endanger his program of economic and political reforms. In the latest fighting, Armenian militants marching behind dump trucks attacked and burned the Azerbaijani village of Baganis-Airum on Monday after driving off Soviet troops, Tass reported. One Soviet officer was killed, and four soldiers and four civilians were wounded in the attack, Tass said. On Tuesday, the Armenian Supreme Soviet met in the republic's capital of Yerevan, about 1,200 miles southeast of Moscow, to consider a declaration proclaiming Armenia a ``sovereign, independent and self-governed state,'' the independent news service Interfax reported. One proposed chapter of the declaration calls for establishment of Armenia's own armed forces, interior troops and public security units, Interfax said. The proposed declaration would bar ``any foreign country'' from deploying military units on Armenian territory without permission, Interfax said. This would presumably include the Soviet Union. Soviet Interior Ministry troops are stationed in Armenia and Azerbaijan to try to keep the peace. They have come under fire from both sides. The Soviet officer who was killed Monday, Lt. Alexander Lipatov, had been promoted to deputy chief of staff of his battalion after the previous holder of that post, Capt. Sergei Osetrov, was killed in action. ``Ironically,'' Tass said, ``Osetrov fell protecting an Armenian village from Azerbaijani extremists, while Lipatov was killed by Armenian terrorists attacking an Azerbaijani village.'' Tass quoted Major Gen. Anatoly Kirilyuk as saying the militants who attacked Baganis-Airum were armed with field artillery, mortars, grenade launchers, submachine guns and sniper rifles. ``The gunmen burned down or ravaged every house in the village, but its population had managed to escape in advance,'' Kirilyuk was quoted as saying. The news agency did not say how many people lived in the village. In another clash Monday, Azerbaijani militants fired on two villages in Armenia's Noemberyan region, killing three people and wounding six, Tass said. No details were provided. In a speech broadcast over Azerbaijani radio and television on Tuesday, Azerbaijani President Ayaz Mutalibov accused Gorbachev of foot-dragging on a decree to disband militant groups and confiscate their weapons. Gorbachev issued the decree in July, giving militant groups until Aug. 9 to comply with the order to turn in their weapons and disband. Tass reported Aug. 11 that the deadline had been extended two months. ``The entire course of events demands that real political, legal and other sanctions be finally adopted against the Armenian republic within the powers entrusted to the Soviet president and government, as is the case when the Soviet Constitution is violated,'' Mutalibov said. He appeared to be calling for sanctions similar to the economic embargo imposed by the Kremlin on Lithuania after the Baltic republic declared itself independent in March.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Lifts Execution Sentence and Frees Feline Felon on Death Row
DOC.TEXT: A pet cat named Boogs who faced execution as a dangerous animal has won a court reprieve after his plight became the subject of a letter-writing campaign. A state judge lifted the death sentence Monday but ordered Boogs' owner to keep the cat on a leash and muzzled or in a cage when outside his home, and to keep the cat's rabies shots up to date. About a dozen of Boogs' supporters applauded after Dane County Circuit Judge Susan Steingass announced her decision. ``I'm bitter, but my bitterness is outweighed by the joy of getting Boogs back,'' said Boogs' owner, D.W. Wanberg, a 34-year-old theater lighting designer. The 6-year-old grey and white cat had been on death row at the Dane County Animal Shelter for 15 months. City Health Department officials had ordered the cat put to death for growling at neighbors, eating a neighbor cat's food and nipping an animal control officer who picked him up. Officials also said the cat had menaced and bitten other people. Wanberg said workers at the shelter had denied him the right to visit Boogs. He argued that the city's actions were too extreme. ``Pit bulls can be a danger to life, but not my cat,'' he said. There was no word on Boogs' reaction to being released; Wanberg did not answer his telephone Tuesday. Mrs. Steingass said the stipulations regarding the caging or leashing and muzzling of Boogs were necessary because of ``concerns about the way Boogs has interacted in society.'' The settlement capped a letter-writing campaign to the judge by Boogs' backers, including inmates at the Waupun Correctional Institution and a woman in Puerto Rico. ``We are willing to take Boogs in and make a home for him _ that is if Warden Gary McCaughtry approves,'' said a letter signed by eight inmates at the prison in northeastern Wisconsin. Elba Nieves, who heard of Boogs' situation through news reports, wrote from Puerto Rico that she did not consider Boogs to be a ``menacing cat.'' People suffering from hunger ``sometimes steal to eat,'' she said. ``I'm not justifying this, but give Boogs a chance.'' The city's lawyer, Carolyn Hogg, argued officials were right to confine Boogs because they have a duty to protect residents from dangerous pets. But Boogs' lawyer, John Hansen, said the law does not allow city officials to kill pets simply because the health director decides an animal is dangerous.

DOC.HEAD: Conservative Group Says Souter Should Not Be Treated as a Politician
DOC.TEXT: Supreme Court nominee David H. Souter should not be treated as a politician and asked about his personal views on Supreme Court rulings, a conservative group that backs him said Tuesday. ``We don't think it's proper that Judge Souter act like a congressional candidate and say, `Read my lips. I'll do this,''' said Tom Jipping of Coalitions for America. Jipping said the Senate Judiciary Committee, which is to begin confirmation hearings for Souter on Sept. 13, ``should not demand he bias himself in public'' on issues he would deal with as a high court member. Jipping, author of an analysis of Souter's work as a longtime member of the New Hampshire Supreme Court, said the committee should conduct ``a properly focused investigation'' before confirming his nomination. Liberal groups, especially those advocating abortion rights, have been urging the Senate to grill Souter about his largely unknown views on issues the court is deeply divided over _ such as abortion, church-state relations and affirmative action. But Jipping urged the Senate not to repeat the ``shameless'' treatment in 1987 of failed Supreme Court nominee Robert H. Bork. ``In fulfilling its constitutional role of advice and consent, the Senate in 1987 shifted radically from examining qualifications to checking out a nominee's politics, from conducting a searching inquiry into judicial philosophy to narrowly testing how a nominee would vote once on the bench,'' Jipping said. ``This is not only a dangerous aberration from traditional practice, it directly threatens the independence of the judiciary and literally demands that a nominee bias himself in public on issues that may well come before him as a judge,'' he added.

DOC.HEAD: Plan For Oct. 14 Unity In Danger
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Combines pvs. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: The leader of the second-largest party in the East German Parliament said today he was resigning, and a plan to merge the German states on Oct. 14 appeared in danger. Earlier today, Prime Minister Lothar de Maiziere said the leaders of all the major political parties had agreed that East Germany would unite with West Germany on Oct. 14. Richard Schroeder, leader of the left-leaning Social Democrat faction in Parliament, was among those who agreed to the proposal. But members of his party later balked and said German unity should take place on or before Sept. 15 because of the country's chaotic economic situation. The Social Democrats, who withdrew from de Maiziere's broad governing coalition on Sunday in a dispute over unification, met to discuss what action to take. Before the meeting, Schroeder said he was resigning as chief of his faction in Parliament. ``The opposition needs an opposition leader,'' he said, indicating he was closer to agreement with de Maiziere than with his fellow Social Democrats. The change was yet another example of the chaos in the young, inexperienced democratic government as it tries to deal with mounting joblessness and falling industrial production. Six ministers have resigned or been ousted from the Cabinet in the past week, and the head of the agency set up to sell the nation's ailing enterprises resigned amid criticism of his failure to unload the businesses. After the Oct. 14 compromise was announced by de Maiziere at a press conference, Social Democrat spokesman Juergen Itzfeldt said the date for unity is too far away. Itzfeldt said it was possible the Social Democrats would try to set an earlier date during the Parliament meeting on Wednesday. However, they are not believed to have enough votes to challenge de Maiziere's Christian Democrats. Parliament must approve unification by a two-thirds majority but only a simple majority is needed to set a date. All the major parties are committed to unification, but the debate has been reduced to a political brawl over when it should take place. For weeks, the left-leaning Social Democrats and the conservative Christian Democrats have argued over the date when formal unification should take place. The dispute outraged many East Germans who are more concerned about whether they will lose their jobs and homes, and be able to pay steadily rising food prices caused by the switch to a free market economy. De Maiziere called today's meeting of party leaders in the latest attempt to settle the political brawl.

DOC.HEAD: Border Clashes Continuning, Says Prime Minister
DOC.TEXT: The army on Tuesday dispatched tanks and troop reinforcements to the frontier with Pakistan, where soldiers from the two nations have been fighting recently, officials and witnesses said. Prime Minister V.P. Singh told Parliament that Indian armed forces were ``fully prepared to effectively deal with any eventuality.'' Indian and Pakistani troops clashed in a remote border area in the disputed Kashmir region Monday. Singh, who is also defense minister, said exchange of fire also occurred Tuesday. In Pakistan, a Defense Ministry spokesman, who cannot be identified under briefing rules, said Tuesday that Indian and Pakistani soldiers exchanged artillery fire in the Kel sector along the cease-fire line dividing Kashmir into Pakistani and Indian regions. He said there were no casualties among Pakistani soldiers. The Pakistani official also said that on Monday and Tuesday, Indian soldiers fired on Pakistani civilians traveling on a mountain road, injuring four people. He also said Indian soldiers fired on an ambulance and a bus. There was no report from India on the alleged firing. Despite the tension, officials from both sides said the incidents did not appear to be serious. ``There is no cause for any undue concern since we trust that these localized incidents will be contained and the situation defused,'' United News of India quoted Singh as saying in the Parliament. Singh said directors of military operations from both countries were in touch. He did not elaborate. The Pakistani official said: ``This is not a serious situation. It's just in one sector. It could be just a local incident. We don't know what it will lead to. We'll just have to wait and see.'' India and Pakistan have gone to war twice over Kashmir, in 1965 and 1971. Both sides claim Kashmir, which has been divided into Indian and Pakistani sectors. Tensions over Kashmir flared again this summer. India accuses Pakistan of supporting a Moslem secessionist movement in the Indian sector by providing arms and training to Moslem militants. Pakistan, an Islamic state, denies the charge but says it will back any movement for self-determination by Kashmir's people. Jammu-Kashmir state is the only one of India's states with a Moslem majority. At least 1,034 people have been killed in the Kashmir valley since New Delhi cracked down on the secessionist movement on Jan. 20. Military officials in Jammu, the summer capital of India-held Kashmir, said Tuesday that tanks and troops reinforcements were dispatched to the border areas. At least 20 tanks and 30 trucks with soldiers left their quarters at Kaluchak and Baridrahamna for the frontier, said witnesses, who spoke on condition of anonymity. Indian military officials said the additional troops were sent to Rajauri and Poonch sectors, which were the scenes of fierce battles in the wars of 1965 and 1971.

DOC.HEAD: White House Rejects Latest Proposal From Iraq
DOC.NOTE: EDs: Combines pvs; editing thruout to tighten; no pickup
DOC.TEXT: The White House said today the United States had no interest in negotiating with President Saddam Hussein while Iraq remains in Kuwait. President Bush, meanwhile, awaited paperwork from the Pentagon to activate U.S. military reserves. Saddam's latest message, directed to Bush and read over Iraqi television, was described by presidential press secretary Marlin Fitzwater as ``much of the same rhetoric that we've heard before. Same old litany from Iraq.'' ``At this point, we see very little to talk about when all we get are negative responses,'' Fitzwater told reporters accompanying Bush to a political fund-raising golf tournament. Fitzwater also said there would be no announcement today on the pending call-up of U.S. military reserves. White House officials said earlier in the day the executive order for Bush to sign was making its way through the bureaucracy from the Pentagon. The call-up, which would primarily help fill the ranks of military doctors, cargo handlers and other specialists, could come Wednesday after Bush meets with defense advisers. Asked about Iraq's suggestion for talks, Fitzwater said that many nations of the world ``are willing to talk with Iraq, but only in the context of compliance with the U.N. resolutions,'' which demand a full pullout of Iraqi military forces from Kuwait. ``We demand a complete and unconditional withdrawal,'' Fitzwater said. In Amman, Jordan, Iraqi Foreign Minister Tariq Aziz said ` `We are ready to talk.'' However, Aziz said all regional issues, including Israel's occupation of the West Bank and Gaza Strip, must be on the table. U.S. envoy Joseph Wilson met with the Iraqi foreign ministry on Monday and demanded access to the U.S. citizens who are being held by the Iraqis and ``demanded they be allowed to leave.'' ``Of course, he got no positive response,'' Fitzwater said. Fitzwater said that 18 dependents of American diplomats managed to escape on Monday. Fitzwater also said the United States continues to shadow several ships in the Persian Gulf region to make sure none violates the trade embargo with Iraq. However, he said, one Iraqi tanker was being allowed to dock in a Yemen port based on assurances from the Yemeni government that that country would not unload or use Iraqi oil. That tanker and another were being tailed by the U.S. Navy, which had fired shots across their bow. The second tanker was still being trailed, Fitzwater said. President Bush rebuffed reporters' attempts to question him as he teed off for the golf tournament to benefit the re-election campaign of Gov. John McKernan. However, to underscore that Bush is conducting work during his lengthy vacation in Maine, Fitzwater said the president had spoken by phone this morning with U.N. Ambasssador Thomas Pickering and National Security Adviser Brent Scowcroft. Defense Secretary Dick Cheney, returning from the Persian gulf, and Joint Chiefs of Staff Chairman Gen. Colin Powell were to meet with Bush in Maine on Wednesday, Fitzwater said. The president escalated the verbal war during a trip Monday to Washington, Baltimore and Rhode Island. He used the word ``hostages'' for the first time to describe the 3,000 Americans trapped in Iraq and Kuwait and called Iraqi President Saddam Hussein ``a man of evil standing against human life itself.'' Starting his day with an early morning jog today, Bush kept his distance from watching reporters who wanted to question him about Persian Gulf developments. Bush has grown increasingly distant from news media accompanying him on vacation, saying he does not want to comment on serious world affairs while having recreation time. White House aides had said Monday night the president might sign paperwork as soon as today ordering thousands of military reservists into active duty to bolster U.S. forces depleted by the massive deployment of troops to protect Saudi Arabia from possible attack by Iraq. The White House announced Friday that Bush had decided to use the reserves. Bush returned to Maine on Monday afternoon and was spending much of today in Falmouth. He also planned to attend the funeral in Kennebunkport of his uncle, John Walker, a retired surgeon and investment banker, who died Thursday at 81 after suffering an aneurism. Bush spent part of Monday on the telephone with foreign leaders _ Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher of Great Britain, President Francois Mitterrand of France and Turkey's President Turgut Ozal. He praised all three for cooperating with the United States as it blockades ships that attempt to break the trade embargo against Iraq. He said strategically placed Turkey took a ``courageous stand'' in going against Iraq, its powerful neighbor. Defense Secretary Dick Cheney was returning to the United States today, claiming success after a four-day trip to six Mideast countries seeking their support. The United Arab Emirates agreed to host a squadron of U.S. military transport planes. Bush told a Veterans of Foreign Wars convention in Baltimore that he was holding Iraq ``responsible for the safety of American citizens held against their will.'' ``Today, the outcome is not yet decided. Hard choices remain. But of this we are certain: America will not be intimidated,'' Bush told the veterans.

DOC.HEAD: Solar Powered Plane Crosses Mississippi River
DOC.TEXT: A man trying to become the first pilot to fly a solar-powered plane from coast to coast glided the craft across the Mississippi River, a spokesman said. Eric Raymond landed the Sun-Seeker Monday in a field near Greenville, Ill., about 50 miles from St. Louis, said flight trainer Jack Whitehouse. Raymond flew 141 miles in four hours from Fulton, Mo., he said. That put Raymond 1,620 miles into his trip, which began Aug. 2 in Desert Center, Calif. His destination is Kitty Hawk, N.C., where Orville and Wilbur Wright made the first successful heavier-than-air airplane flight in 1903. Raymond landed in a field because he couldn't reach an airport. A wiring malfunction prevented use of the solar-powered batteries his ultralight glider uses to turn the propeller for takeoffs and landings, Whitehouse said.

DOC.HEAD: Unity Still Too Far Away For East German Workers
With AM Germany-Unification, Bjt
LaserPhoto Available
DOC.TEXT: For many weary East German workers, the Oct. 14 unification date set by their government Tuesday is far too late. ``It should happen more quickly. We all want to work but our government can't do anything,'' said construction worker Horst Schwaebisch. Earlier, Prime Minister Lothar de Maiziere announced that leaders of parliamentary factions had agreed to the Oct. 14 date. However, a political squabble later threatened to torpedo the agreement, and one of East Germany's parties said it would push for earlier unification. From the rusty bridge they were repairing, Schwaebisch and his crew could see the West German flag flutter atop the Reichstag, the historic site of the German parliament. ``Unity Elsewhere in East Berlin, many expressed a similar opinion. But other East Germans questioned at random said things were in fact going too fast, and they criticized the prime minister. ``Everything is happening in such a chaotic way. We could lose our protection if we are just run over by West Germany,'' said Heidi Loll, a nurse attending a protest by health care workers in downtown East Berlin. ``Everything is falling apart. De Maiziere should leave politics to real politicians,'' Ms. Kuhn added. Others expressed similar fears. ``They still have some issues to solve. Like how the economy should be run. It's happening too fast,'' said Frank Stemmler, 27, a former cook who now sells newspapers. Rapid unification delighted citizens of East Germany's Warsaw Pact allies. ``The German nation should be together. The Berlin Wall is now just a souvenir,'' said Alexei Baltyan, a worker from the Ukraine. ``There will be too many conflicts if they don't do it quickly.'' A Ukrainian tourist had similar feelings. ``The quicker the better. After all, they are free now to decide,'' said Vladimir Fedus, a worker from Lvov. One Polish entrepeneur agreed. ``It's very good. What else can I say?'' said the Pole, as he rented hammers to tourists wanting to chip away at what is left of the wall near the Brandenburg Gate.

DOC.HEAD: Dan Rather Leaves Iraq, TV Now Covering Crisis From the Borders
DOC.TEXT: Anchorman Dan Rather and other CBS employees left Iraq on Tuesday under the orders of Iraqi authorities, a spokeswoman said. ``All of the CBS newspeople were politely asked to be out today,'' said CBS News spokeswoman Donna Dees. ``We were staying as long as we could stay and not put anybody's life in danger,'' she said. ``Clearly, we reached almost that point where we might not have gotten out.'' Reporters for The Associated Press and other newsgathering organizations continue to work in Iraq, which invaded Kuwait nearly three weeks ago. The CBS contingent flew to Amman, Jordan, where Rather will continue to cover the story along with correspondents Allen Pizzey and Peter Van Sant. Ms. Dees said she could not say how many CBS staffers are in Jordan. A CBS source, however, said the network is keeping about 30 people in Jordan. The CBS contingent got to Baghdad on Wednesday, 12 hours after an ABC crew led by ``Nightline'' anchorman Ted Koppel. Koppel left Baghdad on Thursday, followed several days later by his ABC colleagues. ``We have been advancing the story of the Americans left there (in Iraq),'' Ms. Dees said. ``It's been our story all weekend.'' CBS correspondents in the region include Bob Simon in Saudi Arabia; Bill McLaughlin in Cairo, Doug Tunnel in Dubai, and Martha Teischner in Tel Aviv. NBC's ``Nightly News'' anchor Tom Brokaw on Tuesday returned to New York City from Saudi Arabia, where he had been anchoring the network's coverage of the invasion. ``Today'' host Bryant Gumbel remains in Saudi Arabia, as does correspondent Arthur Kent. In Amman, NBC's on-air reporting is by correspondents Garrick Utley, Dennis Murphy and Keith Miller. Other NBC correspondents include Tom Aspell in Dubai, Rick Davis and Mike Boettcher in Cairo, Tom Pettit in Iran, and Ike Seamans in Tel Aviv. ``Overall, we have about 70 people involved in this coverage, and that doesn't include translators, drivers and other support staff,'' said NBC spokeswoman Katherine McQuay. ABC's coverage of the Mideast crisis is still being anchored here by ``World News Tonight'' anchor Peter Jennings, who had been the network's Beirut bureau chief and has anchored all special report coverage. Correspondents on the story include Sam Donaldson and Mike Von Fremd in Saudi Arabia; Jim Hickey in Cairo, Mike Lee in Dubai, United Arab Emirates; Peter Collins in Ankara, Turkey. ABC has three correspondents in Amman: Forrest Sawyer, John McKenzie and John Donvan. ABC spokesman Scott Richardson had no exact figures on the number of people covering the story. The Cable News Network kept its anchor, Bernard Shaw, in Washington. ``He's doing what he's supposed to be doing,'' said spokeswoman Eileen Murphy. CNN on Tuesday had three correspondents in Amman: Rich Roth, Jim Clancy and Robert Weiner; Christiane Amanpour and John Sweeney covered the story from Saudi Arabia, where CNN's Carl Rochelle was a Pentagon pool reporter. CNN's Jonathan Mann was shuttling between Tripoli and Cairo, and Doug James was in Dubai. CNN also has between 45 and 50 editorial and technical staffers on duty in the Middle East.

DOC.HEAD: Mayor's Car Stolen During GOP Tour
DOC.TEXT: The mayor may have a tough time convincing GOP officials crime won't be a problem if they hold the 1992 Republican national convention in this city. His car was stolen during their tour. Mayor Robert Ulrich returned from dinner Sunday with the Republican National Committee's site scouting group to find shards of broken glass where his 1980 white Buick had been at the St. Petersburg Hilton. The car was recovered later that night after the driver crashed into someone's front yard. No arrests have been made. The new Florida Suncoast Dome is competing with convention sites in New Orleans, Houston, Cleveland and possibly San Diego. A decision is expected in January.

DOC.HEAD: Stocks Down Sharply in Heavy Trading; Off 50 Points By 2 p.m.
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 8 grafs to UPDATE with later trading. Picks up 5th graf pvs, `Analysts said...'. A version moved on the financial wire.
DOC.TEXT: Stock prices fell sharply in heavy trading today as investors continued to worry about the prospect of war in the Mideast. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrial stocks rebounded somewhat from its morning loss of more than 75 points but was still was down 50.50 points to 2,605.94 as of 2 p.m. In the broader market, declining stocks outnumbered advancing ones by about 6 to 1 on the New York Stock Exchange, with 222 up, 1,403 down and 320 unchanged. Volume on the Big Board came to a strong 154.72 million shares. Traders said the main influence on the market was continuing concern about the Iraqi situation. ``Everyone's just very, very nervous here,'' said Tony Woodruff, a managing director at Kidder, Peabody & Co. In a speech this morning, Iraq's president, Saddam Hussein, said his nation's detention of foreigners was justified given the aggressive response by foreign nations to Iraq's invasion of Kuwait. Saddam also said that if the United States continues its aggression, ``a disaster will take place concerning the whole world.'' Woodruff said the continuing rise in oil prices due to the Mideast tension is of particular concern to the market. Wholesale unleaded gasoline prices hit a new high on the New York Mercantile Exchange for the fifth day in a row this morning. The plunge in the Dow twice triggered one of the NYSE's ``circuit breakers'' designed to prevent a freefall in prices. The mechanism, set off by a 50-point Dow drop, bars a type of computerized program trading related to stock futures until the prices of the stocks involved rise. Analysts said the market was hurt by a decline in the price of U.S. shares on foreign exchanges before the start of New York trading. Stock prices fell sharply in Frankfurt, primarily because of a rumor _ later dismissed _ that a U.S. plane was shot down over Iraq. Share prices also were lower in London trading. Earlier, share prices slipped for the fourth consecutive session in Tokyo, where the key Nikkei index lost 0.73 percent. The U.S. stock market also was hurt by a drop in bond prices this morning, analysts said. But market-watchers said they expected stocks to be most affected by any news from Iraq. The NYSE's composite index of all its listed common stocks dropped 4.80 to 175.62. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index was down 3.92 at 327.37.

DOC.HEAD: People in the News
LaserPhoto NY44
DOC.TEXT: Kathie Lee Gifford admits her on-air campaign to win a ``Most Beautiful Woman on TV'' poll was ``totally, totally shameless.'' But it worked. Gifford, who campaigned good-naturedly and tirelessly on her syndicated show, ``Live with Regis and Kathie Lee,'' far outdistanced such glamorous stars as Jaclyn Smith and Connie Sellecca in voting announced this week in TV Guide. ``There is no accounting for my behavior,'' Gifford said. ``I didn't do anything illegal, though. I didn't steal anything.'' Gifford got 17,796 phone-in votes to Smith's 3,603. Nicollette Sheridan was third with 3,074 votes. Then came Delta Burke, Melissa Brennan, Kirstie Alley, Dana Delany, Connie Sellecca, Stepfanie Kramer, Jasmine Guy, Valerie Bertinelli and Phylicia Rashad. ``It's hysterical,'' Gifford said. ``Of course, I'm not the most beautiful woman on TV _ but for one week, it would be great to think so.'' ``Too bad I don't have a TV talk show to wage a campaign,'' said Holly Robinson of ``21 Jump Street,'' who got 674 votes. Vanna White received 1,291 votes, but her manager said, ``If Vanna had done that for her 20 million viewers, she'd (have blown) Kathie out of the water.''

A performance by comedian Andrew Dice Clay will go ahead Sunday, but without local sponsors. A Dallas radio station became the fifth group to withdraw as a sponsor for the show at the Starplex Amphitheatre. Clay has drawn criticism for offensive references in his stand-up comedy act to women, homosexuals and minorities. KTXQ-FM's action followed the withdrawal of Coca-Cola, Miller beer, WFAA-TV and The Dallas Morning News. The five organizations have been season sponsors of the theater's summer concert series. ``We sponsor hundreds of concerts ever year, and if it's going to alienate people, or offend people, it's not in our best interest to sponsor the act,'' said KTXQ program director Andy Lockridge. Larry Fontana, general manager for Starplex, said the show would go on regardless of the number of sponsors. He said ticket sales were good.

The National Women's Hall of Fame couldn't find a company willing to help fly tennis great Billie Jean King to her induction ceremonies. And that upset the hall's director. Emilie C. Sisson said more than 20 major corporations were asked for a loan of a private jet or donations of $3,000 to $4,000 so one could be rented. ``We're talking some of the big guys, we're talking Fortune 500 companies. . . . They all said no,'' Sisson said. ``It's partly because it's a women's issue. It wasn't in their `interest' to do that _ that was their primary response.'' Sisson declined to list the companies that turned down the hall's request. The hall instead will pay to fly King in, she said. The 47-year-old King, who won 20 Wimbledon titles and dominated women's tennis for years, will be inducted into the hall Sunday along with former U.S. Rep. Barbara Jordan of Texas, tuberculosis researcher Dr. Florence B. Seibert and the late photojournalist Margaret Bourke-White. Neither Jordan nor Seibert can attend the ceremony. King will be in New York City this weekend working as a commentator for the U.S. Open tennis championship. No commercial flights are available after the Sunday night ceremony that would get her back in time for work Monday morning, Sisson said.

County music singer Dottie West has filed for bankruptcy reorganization, citing $1 million in debts. Documents filed Aug. 16 in U.S. Bankruptcy Court showed the singer's biggest debt is a $703,090 home loan from First American Bank. The bank recently foreclosed on the singer's Williamson County house and property and she was ordered to vacate the property. West, best known as one of Kenny Rogers' duet partners, is a member of the Grand Ole Opry and has recorded such hits as ``Country Sunshine'' and ``A Lesson In Leaving.'' Her ``Here Comes My Baby'' in 1964 won country music's first Grammy Award in the female vocalist category. She listed less than $500,000 in assets and more than 20 creditors, including the Internal Revenue Service. In a recent interview with The Tennessean newspaper, West said she was doing fine, although her financial problems had not been easy. ``I'm a survivor. You can knock me down, but you better have a big rock to keep me there,'' she said.

``Cheers'' star Ted Danson was late for an appearance at an American Oceans Campaign benefit because a truckload of tuna overturned on the freeway, backing up traffic for miles. More than 200 partygoers awaited the appearance of Danson, who was stuck on Interstate 5 with thousands of other motorists. ``Here we are at a `Celebration of the Sea' and there are 40,000 pounds of canned tuna on the highway. I think there's some irony in that,'' said Eric Hansen, a benefit organizer. Danson, president and co-founder of the American Oceans Campaign, finally made his entrance Friday 20 minutes before the party's end. The organization is dedicated to the protection and restoration of the ocean. ``I grew up in Arizona, the son of an archaeologist. I was instilled with the thought that there is lots that came before us and lots will come after us. It gave me a sense of stewardship,'' said Danson. ``We thought we'd concentrate all our money, all our energy and all our time into one area and see what kind of impact we can make.'' The benefit also featured appearances by actors John Ratzenberger, Woody Harrelson, Ed Begley Jr., Robert Urich and Peter Weller.

DOC.HEAD: Pakistan Says it Will Try Soviets in Hijacking; Tass Report Differs
DOC.TEXT: Eleven convicts from a Siberian labor camp who hijacked a Soviet jetliner to Pakistan and requested political asylum will go on trial here, the state-run television said Tuesday. However, the Soviet news agency Tass reported that the hijackers would be extradited to the Soviet Union. There was no explanation for the differing the reports. The Soviets surrendered Monday two hours after the Aeroflot Tupolev 154, with 29 passengers and nine crew members, landed in the city of Karachi. The late evening news on Pakistan's official television network said the hijackers were being interrogated and would be put on trial in Pakistan. A Foreign Office spokesman said no formal extradition request had been received from Moscow. Earlier, Tass quoted Gulyam Aliyev, deputy KGB chairman in the Uzbekistan republic of the Soviet Union, as saying Soviet law officers would travel to Karachi to escort the prisoners home. Pakistan has in the past refused to extradite hijackers, preferring to put them on trial here. Palestinian guerrillas involved in a 1986 Pan Am hijacking that ended in Karachi were tried in Pakistan. One was sentenced to death and the others to lengthy prison terms. The death sentence has not been carried out. The Soviet hijacking began Sunday when convicts from a Siberian labor camp overpowered their guards and took over the jetliner as it was flying from Neryungry, where the prison is located, to the nearby city of Yakutsk. The prisoners forced the commerical aircraft back to Neryungry, where six prisoners and 41 women and children left the plane. Two more convicts then boarded, and the aircraft flew west to Krasnoyarsk in Siberia. After two hours of negotiations, the aircraft was refueled and flew to the Soviet city of Tashkent, where a new crew came on board and the hijackers demanded to leave the country. They originally wanted to go to New Delhi but were allowed to land in Karachi because the plane was low on fuel. There have been at least 13 hijackings or attempted hijackings of Soviet aircraft since late May. Tass quoted Deputy Interior Minister Ivan Shilov as saying there would be an investigation into how the convicts managed to commandeer the plane. The news agency said one of the prisoners apparently smuggled weapons onto the fight in an artificial limb.

DOC.HEAD: Jackson Trying to Arrange Trip to Iraq
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs last graf to take out extra word ``held''. ^By JAMES ROWLEY
DOC.TEXT: The Rev. Jesse Jackson said today he is trying to arrange a trip to Iraq as a television journalist to interview Iraqi officials and American hostages for his new syndicated talk show. Jackson told reporters the government of Iraq had indicated that he could interview officials in Baghdad and talk to Americans held hostages in that country. ``The Jesse Jackson Show,'' which is schecduled to begin next month, is syndicated by Time-Warner Inc., which Jackson said would help underwrite the trip.
