Jackson, who previously has played a role as a diplomat in seeking to free an American pilot held in Syria, said the purpose of the trip to Iraq would be purely journalistic. ``Our purpose will be to communicate with high Iraqi officials and to communicate with Americans held hostage there just as various news organizations have sought to do,'' Jackson told a news conference. ``It would not be appropriate to go there as a diplomat,'' he said. ``In this case it would interfere with what is a growing crisis,'' said Jackson, who in 1984 traveled to Syria to gain the release of Lt. Robert Goodman, a Navy pilot who had been shot down. But Jackson indicated that he hoped his trip would help encourage a diplomatic solution. ``Something must happen, hopefully through communications and dialogue, that will help break the cycle that is leading to an impending disaster unless it breaks,'' Jackson said. ``We are not certain just yet as to what our government's plans are for that area,'' Jackson said. ``If on the one hand it is military deterrence and diplomatic initiatives, then communications could facilitate a level of dialogue that appears to be closing.'' ``If in fact, the (American) mission is an offensive military effort, then even communications would be challenged,'' Jackson said. Jackson stressed that the trip would be a news-gathering effort. ``The American people here have a great interest in seeing and hearing from their loved ones who are now held hostage and captive in Iraq and in Kuwait,'' Jackson said. ``We have received communications from the Iraqi government that communicating with high Iraqi officials and the Americans held hostages there would be possible,'' Jackson said.

DOC.HEAD: East Germany Sets Date For Unity, But Social Democrats Balk
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUB grafs 2 and 6 to make clear that Schroeder resigned as leader of faction in parliament, not from party.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto FRA8
With AM-Germany-Chronology
DOC.TEXT: East Germany's unruly political factions briefly put aside their differences Tuesday and set an Oct. 14 date to unify the troubled nation with West Germany. But hours later, the Social Democatic Party said it wanted the date set a month earlier and would challenge the agreement. Richard Schroeder, the Social Democratic leader who had agreed to the Oct. 14 date, resigned as chief of his faction in Parliament. The Social Democrats were meeting to assess whether they could muster the votes to torpedo the Oct. 14 arrangement worked out by Prime Minister Lothar de Maiziere's broad coalition government. De Maiziere is seeking a definitive timetable for the merger of the German states and the dissolution of economically battered East Germany. Under the agreement, the two German states will legally become a single nation Oct. 14. Germans on both sides are tentatively set to elect a common government in December. After meeting with the leaders of other parties in Parliament, de Maiziere said lawmakers would convene Oct. 9 to formalize the unification date. This was before Schroeder announced his move. Oct. 9 is the first anniversary of a large demonstration in Leipzig, East Germany, which fueled other pro-democracy protests. The demonstrations spread across the country, eventually bringing down the Communist regime that had ruled four decades. Alluding to the attempt by lawmakers to capture the spirit of grass-roots solidarity that toppled the old regime, de Maiziere said Parliament will convene under the motto: ``Where we come from, where we want to go.'' De Maiziere's conservative Christian Democrats, the nation's second-largest party, and the left-leaning Social Democrats, who abandoned de Maizeire's coalition two days ago, agreed on the October date. Also agreeing were the former Communists, the third-largest party in Parliament; and the small Buendnis 90 coalition that includes the intellectuals and activists who led last year's revolt. The basic position of the Social Democrats was that unification should take place Sept. 15 because of East Germany's serious economic problems. Christian Democrats in both German states wanted to keep the date of unification and elections for a united Parliament as close together as possible. The Social Democrats said this was because Christian Democrats, including West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl, were trying to win the election before West Germans realized the true cost of bailing out East Germany. Dec. 2 has been scheduled for elections for a united Parliament. Many details remain to be worked out. The fighting between political parties in both Germanys, essentially in the throes of an election campaign, will likely resurface. How to distribute East German property _ some of which is claimed by West Germans who fled the region after the Soviet invasion of World War II _ has been a roadblock to a political treaty that is to mesh the two countries. East Germany became a free market July 1. Joblessness has since skyrocketed as enterprises struggle to compete with Western competition. Regine Hildebrandt, a Social Democrat who resigned as labor minister Tuesday in keeping with her party's decision to leave de Maiziere's government, said 25,000 East Germans are losing their jobs weekly. Unemployment was pegged officially at about 270,000 at the end of July, but more than a million people are being kept on payrolls at reduced hours and wages under a program financed by West Germany. Joblessness is expected to exceed 3 million of the nation's 8.8 million workers. Unrest among workers has been widespread. Sirens screamed around the prime minister's office Tuesday as about 1,000 public employees, including firefighters and ambulance drivers, rallied outside to demand better wages. Bus drivers joined by parking their vehicles for an hour. Several hundred doctors and nurses protested in front of the Health Ministry to demand that their clinics be privatized. Similar protests were held in Cottbus, Dresden and other cities.

DOC.HEAD: State Department Says Some Westerners Moved to Industrial Installations
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Combines pvs with editing.
DOC.TEXT: The State Department said today a U.S. citizen in Kuwait was taken from his home by the Iraqi military, increasing the number of Americans believed under Iraqi control to 54. Some westerners have been moved to Iraqi industrial installations, the department said. Department spokesman Richard Boucher said the unidentified American and eight British citizens were ``rounded up from their homes'' by Iraqi soldiers who apparently forced a Kuwaiti man at gunpoint to identify homes of westerners. Boucher said the American was taken to the Meridien Hotel in Kuwait, where he was seen by U.S. consular officials who said he was ``okay.'' ``We have credible reports that some westerners have been moved to Iraqi industrial installations,'' Boucher said. He said he did not know the number or whether any of them were Americans. Boucher also said the department had confirmed a report that eight American citizens crossed the border from Kuwait into Saudia Arabia on Monday. He said they evidently acted on their own, without any approval from Iraqi authorities. ``The United States will continue to press Iraq by all means available to fulfill its obligation to the safety and welfare of foreign citizens in Kuwait and Iraq by allowing them to leave,'' Boucher said. ``The United States will not negotiate concessions in return for what is an international obligation on the part of Iraq.'' Boucher also said 18 U.S. diplomats had driven across the border from Iraq into Jordan, leaving about 10 in the American embassy in Baghdad. Earlier, Boucher said the United States was protesting the removal of 12 to 14 Americans and other foreign nationals from Kuwaiti hotels to undisclosed locations. Boucher said Monday that at least one family was among the Americans taken from two hotels in Kuwait City. He said he did not know if there were any children. Thirty-five Americans taken earlier from Kuwait and placed in the Rashid hotel in Baghdad were removed last week, and Boucher said they remain unaccounted for despite repeated U.S. inquiries. Six Americans were already living in the hotel, and Boucher said they have not been heard from. An administration official, speaking on condition of anonymity, said at least 12 and possibly 14 Americans were taken from the Hyatt Regency and the Kuwait International hotels. The whereabouts of the Americans was unknown, Boucher said. They are among an estimated 2,500 Americans in the Persian Gulf country that was overrun by Iraqi forces Aug. 2. An additional 530 or so Americans are trapped in Iraq, and Boucher said securing all the Americans' safety was the administration's ``prime concern.'' Iraq announced it had carried out a plan to move Western hostages to vital military installations to deter any U.S. attack. It warned Iraqi citizens not to try to hide any of the thousands of foreigners trapped in the country. President Bush referred to the trapped Americans as hostages for the first time Monday while addressing a Veterans of Foreign Wars meeting in Baltimore. ``Whatever these innocent people are called, they are in fact hostages,'' Bush said. Previously, the administration had avoided using that word. A State Department spokeswoman said U.S. consular officers are answering about 4,000 telephone calls a day from relatives of the Americans. Judith Baroody, press officer for the special task force set up by the department to deal with the Persian Gulf crisis, said from 60 to 80 officers staff the telephone bank 24 hours a day, in shifts of 15 at one time. The telephone number is (202) 647-0900. The State Department also announced that non-essential diplomats and dependents are leaving Jordan, which borders Iraq. The department said there are about 5,000 Americans in Jordan _ 4,700 private citizens and the rest official. Non-government Americans in Jordan were advised to consider leaving. Similar instructions were issued for Yemen, which lies far beyond Iraq on the Arabian Sea.

DOC.HEAD: Former Congressmen Leave Iraq
DOC.NOTE: Eds: CORRECTS spelling of Amman in lead.
DOC.TEXT: Two former congressmen cut short a private fact-finding trip to Iraq today and flew to Amman, Jordan, on a plane carrying CBS anchorman Dan Rather and others. Former Rep. George Hansen, R-Idaho, said he and former Rep. Thomas Kindness, R-Ohio, and an interpreter were in Iraq under the auspices of Hansen's Free America Foundation. Hansen said that he and Kindness were examining U.S. policy in the Middle East, but provided few details beyond that. He said they flew to Amman on an aircraft filled with foreigners, including Rather and a CBS network crew of eight. In a telephone interview from Amman, Hansen said he and Kindness ``went out and tested the water everywhere we could, and we did it substantially alone, and I guess I can't say that it was uncomfortable being there.'' The two tried to find out about Americans who had been stranded in Baghdad after Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait but had only mixed success, Hansen told AP Network News. ``Some of them apparently had made their way home,'' Hansen said. ``Others were still in Iraq but had joined, apparently, some of the others that were also detained there and had been farmed out as quote, guests, end quote, in the smaller villages around some of the defense installations and that type of thing.'' Hansen is a former seven-term GOP congressman who served 11 months in prison after his 1984 conviction on four counts of filing false financial disclosure statements to Congress. He was released from federal prison in October, 1987. Kindness represented the 8th Congressional District in western Ohio for 12 years until 1986, when he made an unsuccessful bid to oust Sen. John Glenn, a Democrat. He became a lobbyist in Washington but ran for re-election to Congress, losing in the Republican primary in May.

DOC.HEAD: Rallies Pro And Con on Middle East Buildup
DOC.TEXT: Supporters of U.S. military action in the Middle East are hanging out flags and baking cookies, and pacifist groups are staging what one termed the opening shots of an anti-war movement. ``It's happening too fast for people to actually comprehend,'' said Doug Rand, a spokesman for the Resource Center for Nonviolence in Santa Cruz, Calif. In Lake Worth, Fla., about 20 self-described ``neo-hippies'' protested the U.S. military action Sunday by walking across the Lake Worth bridge carrying signs saying ``Love Life'' and ``Peace for our Children.'' ``I know it's an unpopular opinion, but it needs to be said,'' said the group's leader, Elizabeth Dick, an editor for the National Examiner. ``Under no circumstances should the United States take military action. ... I think the U.S. is being used to do the world's dirty work.'' A small group of Rhode Islanders took to the streets Monday in Providence. ``U.S. troops out of the Middle East. No war for the oil companies and Wall Street. Money for jobs, homes, schools at home, not war abroad,'' their banner said. ``We're responding like in 1963 when advisers were sent to Vietnam,'' said Bill Bateman of the All Peoples Congress. ``This is the opening shot of an anti-war movement.'' Accompanied by chants and the beating of a Buddhist prayer drum, 16 protesters blocked the main gate of Westover Air Force Base, home of C-5A cargo planes, for about two hours Monday at Chicopee, Mass. ``Those C-5As can carry troops to Saudi Arabia, nuclear weapons and chemical weapons. We want the people flying those planes to think about the decision they're making. It's a moral decision,'' said Renard Thompson of Colebrook, Conn. But in Davie, Fla., a suburb of Fort Lauderdale, Ron Morrison and his neighbors hung yellow ribbons on their houses, trees and cars in honor of the American soldiers, including his son, whose Army unit had left Fort Stuart in Georgia. While convoys of Army equipment headed from Fort Campbell, Ky., to Jacksonville, Fla., during the past week, hundreds of people lined Interstates 24 and 75 in Chattanooga, Tenn., waving flags and holding up signs of support. Georgia residents turned out about 20 at a time at highway overpasses to cheer convoys from the 101st Airborne Division at Fort Campbell, Ky. The soldiers were moving their equipment through the state on their way to Mayport, Fla., for shipment to the Mideast. In southern California, Moreno Valley residents prepared more than 200 dozen cookies for Marines scheduled for deployment to the Middle East. The cookies were baked Sunday by 26 residents and taken to the Red Cross at March Air Force Base. About 50 people tied a red-white-and-blue ribbon around the town flag pole in Naugatuck, Conn., on Sunday. They were led by Eileen Bronko, who wants people to put up the ribbons to show U.S. soldiers that the country cares about them and not just about oil prices.

DOC.HEAD: Hang Gliders Form Aerial Crime-Watching Club
DOC.TEXT: Hang gliders are swooping down over isolated forest areas to report illegal dumping, maverick skeet shooters and possible arsonist activity in aerial spying that has authorities delighted. Members of the Sylmar Hang Gliding Association hope they will deter people from dumping stolen cars over the sides of cliffs and shooting guns illegally in the Angeles National Forest, said group spokesman Rome Dodson. ``I hate to see couches and stoves dumped up here because it's such a beautiful area,'' said member Robert Laukka, 28, of Thousand Oaks. The watch group was started to try to change the image of hang gliders as danger-loving and foolhardy. ``If our watch stops one person from doing something wrong, it will be worth it,'' Dodson said. The club launched its anti-crime effort Friday. Soaring through the air with cameras in hand thousands of feet above the ground, they take pictures of cars in isolated areas with lightweight, disposable cameras, Dodson said. Records of the vehicles will be kept and, if there's a fire, they will report the information to rangers or police. ``I personally think it is a very good idea,'' said Jim Sanchez, chief of air operations for the Los Angeles County Fire Department. ``Whatever these folks can do, we appreciate it.'' Ninety-three fires have burned so far this summer in the 690,000-acre forest, said spokesman Jim Stump. Twenty of those fires were started by arsonists who have not been captured. ``It's been a bad year in terms of number of fires started, but we've been lucky only 1,735 acres have burned,'' Stump said. ``Every little bit the hang gliders can do helps.'' ``Watching out for arsonists will save us sky-bums a lot of grief,'' said Bob Lafay, 56, of suburban Tujunga. The forest launch pads are closed during fires.

DOC.HEAD: Saddam's Foes Stand Tough Despite Hostage Threats
DOC.TEXT: Arab and Western nations toughened their resolve against Saddam Hussein on Tuesday, condemning his threats against the hostages and adding more muscle to the force intended to strangle his economy and drive him out of Kuwait. In an address to President Bush, Saddam defended detaining foreigners and promised ``a major catastrophe'' if fighting breaks out in the Persian Gulf. Iraq's defense minister, Tariq Aziz, called for a negotiated settlement but did not offer to withdraw Iraqi troops from Kuwait and restore its monarchy. Egypt, which has led the Arab opposition to the invasion, urged Saddam to withdraw from Kuwait or face a war ``that will devour everything.'' Syria formally announced that it was sending troops to Saudi Arabia. Yemen promised to turn away an Iraqi oil tanker, but questions about its intentions surfaced when at least two Iraqi oil tankers appeared in its port. Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher refused to negotiate with Iraq to win freedom for Britain's 4,500 hostages, and she urged the United Nations to authorize the use military action to stop Iraqi tankers in the Persian Gulf. ``As President Bush pointed out yesterday, Saddam Hussein is trying in his tactics to hide behind Western women and children and use them as human shields and use them as part of his negotiations,'' she said at a news conference. At the first all-European meeting on the crisis, Spain, Belgium, the Netherlands and Italy said in Paris they were sending warships to the region. To bolster U.S. forces depleted by the massive deployment of troops in Saudi Arabia, Bush planned to order thousands of military reservists into active duty. Administration officials said the executive order would probably be open-ended, allowing the Pentagon to call up reserves as needed. In the Persian Gulf, Defense Secretary Dick Cheney met with Saudi officials to share military intelligence and discuss the possible sale of additional F-15 fighters and heavy tanks to bolster the kingdom's defenses. In the face of all this activity, Iraq's leaders again predicted that Iraq's vast army would decimate the U.S.-led multinational force in a war. ``The Americans have prepared the ground for a war of aggression. If the Americans think this is a vacation like they had in Panama and Grenada, this will be a bloody conflict and America will lose and be humiliated,'' Aziz said. Saddam defended his decision to round up thousands of Westerners, including 3,000 Americans, and use them as a shield around military facilities. In a speech on Iraqi television, the Iraqi president said: ``Banning some foreigners from travel is not motivated by vengeance, but rather a measure to prevent a crime of aggression which President Bush intends to commit against the people of Iraq after his crime of occupying the land of Mecca and the shrine of the prophet Mohammed. If he commits this crime, a major catastrophe will befall not only the region but also the world.'' He denounced the United States for rejecting his offer Sunday to free foreigners if the United States withdraws its forces from Saudi Arabia and guarantees that the economic embargo against Iraq will be lifted. Aziz, who spoke with reporters in Jordan, also said Iraq was prepared to end the crisis through negotiations, but neither he nor Saddam offered to withdraw the Iraqi troops that overran Kuwait on Aug. 2. Iraq had accused Kuwait of depriving it of vital oil revenue by stealing oil from a field that includes land both sides claim, and by cheating on its OPEC production quotas and contributing to the world oil glut. ``We are ready to talk,'' Aziz said. ``My president made proposals that we are ready to put all the cards on the table'' at the U.N. Security Council. Aziz said such a meeting should resolve all conflicts in the Persian Gulf, including the Palestinian uprising in Israel. Although the minister said he had carried a message from Saddam to Jordan's government, he declined to discuss its contents. Jordan, a U.S. and Iraqi ally, has not fully committed itself to the international embargo and Iraqi goods continue to pass through Jordan's port of Aqaba on the Red Sea. Iraq, meanwhile, has moved sufrace-to-surface Scud missiles into occupied Kuwait, increasing the threat of a chemical weapons attack, Brig. Gen. Turki Bin Nassar, a Saudi base commander told reporters in the kingdom on Tuesday. But he said that U.S. and Saudi forces have defenses against the Scuds, including U.S. Patriot anti-missiles in place in Saudi Arabia. In the Persian Gulf, shipping radios crackled with conversation as U.S. and British warships challenged almost every commercial vessel in the southern reaches of the waterway, according to shipping executives in Bahrain. There were more than 25 U.S. warships including three aircraft carriers in the region. Britain, France, the Soviet Union and West Germany also have warships in the area. Belgium and Australia have vessels on the way.
DOC.HEAD: more
Asian Organized Crime Groups Gaining Strength, Senator Warns
DOC.TEXT: Asian organized crime groups are spreading into this country along with a brisk trade in heroin and soon could be double the size of the Cosa Nostra in its heyday, a Senate chairman said Tuesday. ``Asian Triads will be the dominant organized crime force in this country by the middle of this decade,'' Chairman Joseph R. Biden, D-Del., told a Senate Judiciary Committee hearing. He said Triads _ highly secretive criminal societies born in China centuries ago _ could have 9,000 members in the United States in 10 years. That is double the Justice Department estimate of Cosa Nostra strength at its peak in the 1960s. FBI officials confirmed the problem is growing. ``It's coming at us and its coming at us real quick and we better be ready,'' said Robert M. Bryant, deputy assistant director in the FBI's criminal investigative division. Biden and Bryant both stressed that criminals represent only a tiny slivver of the Asian-American community. ``Most Asian-Americans are hard-working, law-abiding, patriotic citizens,'' Bryant said. He also said the problem of Asian organized crime is broader than the Chinese Triads. But he said they were among the most dangerous groups. He said the Triads, with an estimated 80,000 to 100,000 members in Hong Kong plus two large groups in Taiwan, in many ways resemble the organized crime groups that rose to power in America in the bootlegger era. The two are similar in traits ranging from the use of secret signs and oaths to infiltration of legitimate businesses, according to documents released by the committee. Bryant said the success of law enforcement in fighting heroin imported by traditional mobsters from the processing mills of Marseilles has created a market opening for even purer shipments from Southeast Asia. The heroin, much of it coming from a rebel army based in the jungles of Burma, is shipped to Singapore and Taiwan and from there to Seattle and Vancouver, Bryant said. He said most of it goes from there to New York for distribution throughout the country. Since 1985, Southeast Asian heroin as a percentage of all heroin seizures in the United States has increased from 14 percent to 43 percent, Bryant said. He said purity has increased from 3 percent to 5 percent in the early 1980s to 40 percent to 50 percent in major East Coast cities now. The bulk of the heroin enters the United States as seemingly legitimate cargo, FBI officials said. They said the traditional silence of the Triads and the fear of retribution from them has made it hard to gather evidence. But they added that some progress has been made. In one notable case, code named White Mare, a cooperative witness told agents of a New York-based heroin broker. Electronic surveillance turned up five other narcotics organizations, one directly linked to the Shan United Army of General Khnu Sa, based in the Burmese jungle. As a result, FBI agents and New York police in February 1989 seized 850 pounds of 90 percent pure heroin, the largest domestic heroin seizure ever. Twenty-six individuals were arrested in the United States and 18 overseas and $4.5 million in cash was seized.

DOC.HEAD: Jetliner With Faulty Landing Gear Skids to Safe Landing
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 4th graf, `Flight 1257 ...' to INCLUDE that flight origniated in Oakland
DOC.TEXT: A United Airlines Boeing 737 jetliner with 107 people was unable to lock its right landing gear and skidded to a safe emergency landing Tuesday, officials said. The jet's right main gear would not lock and the pilot set the plane down at Los Angeles International on the nose gear, left main gear and the engine under the right wing, said Federal Aviation Administration spokesman Fred O'Donnell. The 102 passengers and five crew members slid down emergency chutes, he said. Flight 1257 from Oakland was approaching Burbank-Glendale-Pasadena Airport at 9 a.m. when a cockpit light indicated an unsafe landing gear, O'Donnell said. The pilot made two low passes over the Burbank tower so officials could see if the gear was extended, O'Donnell said. The jet diverted to Los Angeles International. FAA and National Transportation Safety Board inspectors were investigating. Passengers were bused to Burbank Airport, said United Airline spokesman Alan Wayne.

DOC.HEAD: Woman Killed by Car Driven by 11 Year Old Driver
DOC.TEXT: A woman was killed after being struck and pinned under a car driven by an 11-year-old girl, police said. Janet L. Frederick, 58, of Stamford, died at St. Joseph's Hospital on Monday, three hours after she was hit in the driveway of her home, said Deputy Police Chief Walter Young. Young said the 11-year-old was a relative of Frederick's, but he would not identify the child because of her age. He said another 11-year-old girl was in the car at the time. ``Our concern at this point is the emotional well-being of both girls,'' Young said. Neither girl was charged, he said. Young said a preliminary investigation found there were no mechanical flaws in the car. No other details will be released until an investigation is complete, he said.

DOC.HEAD: Former KGB General Wins First Round of Parliamentary Election, Faces Runoff
DOC.TEXT: A former KGB general who has denounced the secret police's tactics outpolled 20 other candidates, including a cosmonaut, in the first round of elections to represent southern Russia in parliament. The former spy, Oleg D. Kalugin, now faces a runoff election against an agricultural official, Nikolai Gorovoi, the Soviet press agency Tass reported Tuesday. If Kalugin is elected to represent Krasnodar province in the Congress of People's Deputies, he will gain parliamentary immunity, allowing him to continue to criticize the KGB without fear of prosecution. After Kalugin publicly accused the secret police in June of resisting reform and continuing to carry out dirty tricks, he was dismissed and stripped of his rank, becoming an unlikely hero to Soviet radicals. The Soviet prosecutor has been investigating him under a law that prohibits divulging state secrets, but no formal charges have been filed. The 55-year-old former major general, who was a KGB agent in the United States throughout the 1960s, has hurt the KGB's recent effort to improve its image. The secret police _ long associated with purges and repression _ reorganized itself this year, officially eliminating the directorate responsible for harassment of dissidents. It has undertaken a public relations campaign aimed at inspiring trust instead of fear. Kalugin has insisted that the KGB still infiltrates trade unions and the Russian Orthodox Church, taps the telephones of many citizens and engages in dirty tricks abroad. Tass said about 60 percent of the voters turned out for Sunday's election in Krasnodar, a heavily agricultural region along the Black Sea about 750 miles south of Moscow. The runoff election, scheduled Sept. 2, is necessary because none of the 21 candidates won a clear majority of the votes. Interfax, an independent Soviet news service, said Kalugin received 959,082 votes, just under 45 percent of the total number cast. Gorovoi, the next highest vote-getter, received 227,572 votes, or nearly 11 percent. He is deputy chairman of the regional agro-industrial committee and previously served as chairman of a collective farm. Among the other candidates were Anatoly Berezovoi, a pilot and cosmonaut who took a 211-day space flight in 1982, and Gen. Vladimir Sein, political chief of the Transcaucasian Military District. Their vote totals were unavailable. The KGB and its supporters attempted to discredit Kalugin before the election, and one resident said in a letter to the newspaper Arguments and Facts that it was rumored people who voted for Kalugin would be imprisoned. Pravda, the Communist Party newspaper, said Tuesday the election campaign was ``unusually sharp and tense, sometimes going beyond the bounds of decency.'' Kalugin served as a KGB operative in the United States from 1958 to 1970, first under the cover of a Radio Moscow correspondent and later as a first secretary in the Soviet Embassy in Washington.

DOC.HEAD: Events In German Unification
With AM-Germany-Unification, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Here are some key dates in the German unification process. Nov. 9, 1989 _ East Germany's Communist government opens the Berlin Wall and border points in a bid to halt growing discontent. Nov. 20 _ Protesters in Leipzig who had been demonstrating for democracy begin chanting in favor German unity. Nov. 28 _ West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl proposes ``confederative structures'' to bring the two nations closer together. Dec. 22 _ Berlin's Brandenburg Gate, long a symbol of division, is opened. Feb. 1, 1990 _ East Germany's caretaker prime minister, Hans Modrow, puts forward his own unity plan. Feb. 13 _ The four World War II Allies _ France, Britain, the United States and the Soviet Union _ give the go-ahead to German unification. March 18 _ A conservative coalition comes out as the strongest force in East Germany's first ever free elections. April 24 _ Kohl and Lothar de Maiziere, the democratically elected East German prime minister, agree on July 1 as the date for merging the two countries' economies. July 1 _ The West German mark becomes the East German currency, linking the two countries' economies inextricably. Aug. 9 _ West German lawmakers approve Dec. 2 as the date for joint German elections, but East German lawmakers refuse. Aug 21 _ After weeks of wrangling, East German lawmakers agree to Oct. 14 as the day for German unification.

DOC.HEAD: Government, Black Leaders Appeal for End to Factional Fighting
DOC.TEXT: Government and black leaders Tuesday made a joint plea for peace as the death toll from 10 days of tribal fighting topped 400. President F.W. de Klerk conferred separately with Zulu leader Mangosuthu Buthelezi and Gen. Bantu Holomisa, head of the Xhosa homeland of Transkei, to discuss fighting in black townships around Johannesburg between Zulus and Xhosas. ``Not only must the bloodshed cease, the war of words must cease,'' the government and the black leaders said in a joint statement after the talks in Pretoria. ``This has often been interpreted at grass-roots level as license for violence.'' Whether the talks will calm the townships remained in doubt. Holomisa leads a nominally independent homeland in the southeast part of the country far away from the fighting. He is an ally of the African National Congress, the largest black opposition movement, but he has no real influence outside his region. Buthelezi's supporters have been fighting rivals in the eastern province of Natal for five years. The ANC, led by Nelson Mandela, was not represented at Tuesday's meetings. The fighting since Aug. 12 has pitted Zulus loyal to Buthelezi's conservative Inkatha movement against Xhosas, most of them followers of the ANC. Buthelezi said he had met privately with top ANC leaders in recent weeks to discuss the violence, but he would not identify them. He reiterated his call for an immediate meeting with Mandela. Buthelezi said Mandela had ``almost been throttled by members of his own leadership'' for suggesting such a meeting. Holomisa, meanwhile, charged in a statement that South African police have been aiding Inkatha fighters in the recent unrest. Police have repeatedly denied such accusations. The Zulus and Xhosas have battled with guns, machetes, spears, clubs and axes in the some of the worst township violence since nationwide unrest during the mid-1980s. Police said the death toll had reached 405 by Tuesday night. There were several scattered clashes, but no major fighting reported Tuesday. The Johannesburg-area fighting has marked the spread of political violence from Natal Province, where Inkatha-ANC fighting has killed some 5,000 blacks since 1986. The ANC has rejected a face-to-face meeting with Buthelezi since fighting began in Johannesburg. Mandela canceled a meeting with Buthelezi earlier this year, reportedly because of pressure from ANC leaders in Natal. The ANC contends Buthelezi is trying to broaden Inkatha's constituency beyond Natal by instigating violence against ANC supporters around Johannesburg. Buthelezi and other Inkatha leaders contend the ANC is not willing to tolerate any rivals and seeks to monopolize political power. Both the ANC and Inkatha oppose apartheid, the system of racial segregation that allows 5 million whites to maintain political and economic control over 30 million blacks. But the two groups differ over tactics and plans for a future South Africa.

DOC.HEAD: Pakistan Removes Spy Chief; He's Latest Bhutto Ally to Go
DOC.TEXT: The military-backed government removed the nation's spy chief Tuesday, marking the latest in a string of dismissals of ousted Prime Minister Benazir Bhutto's associates. Shumsur Rehman Kallue, a retired army general and head of the Inter Services Intelligence, was replaced by Maj. Gen. Mahmood Durrani, a former aide to Gen. Mohammad Zia ul-Haq. Zia, who overthrew Ms. Bhutto's father in 1977 and ruled Pakistan for 11 years, died in a mysterious plane crash in August 1988. In announcing Kallue's dismissal, a Defense Ministry spokesman said: ``He was an officer with a very good reputation. There was no friction between him and the army.'' The ISI, comparable to the U.S. Central Intelligence Agency, served as Washington's conduit for arms shipments to the Moslem guerrillas fighting to overthrow the Soviet-backed government in neighboring Afghanistan. Ms. Bhutto's 20-month-old government was dismissed Aug. 6 on charges of corruption, ineptitude and abuse of power. It was replaced by a caretaker government seen by many as a thinly disguised form of military rule. The new government, composed of some of Ms. Bhutto's former allies and fiercest opponents, has removed several of her political appointees, including a number of ambassadors. Kallue's appointment as head of the ISI last year created an uproar within the military, and it was seen as a victory over Pakistan's army chief of staff, Gen. Mirza Aslam Beg, who had submitted his own candidate. The ISI is closely linked to the military, and Ms. Bhutto's appointment of Kallue was seen as an attempt to distance the intelligence bureau from the military.

DOC.HEAD: Text of Saddam's Message to Bush
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Following is the text of Iraqi President Saddam Hussein's message to President Bush carried by the official Iraqi News Agency in Arabic and translated by The Associated Press: ``Once again, U.S. President George Bush stood before the American people to twist words, hide facts or part of the facts, and confuse causes with results. ``In his speech yesterday, 20th of August, 1990, before American war veterans, he referred to the Americans in Iraq and stressed on calling them hostages, despite Iraqi declarations that clarified beyond any doubt that the Americans are here as result of a real aggression launched against the Arab nation and Iraq by President Bush himself and his ally (British Prime Minister Margaret) Thatcher. ``Had this aggression not occurred, had President Bush considered realistically the interests of the American people then none of what happened to the Americans and others would have happened. Nevertheless, what happened to them remains the lightest all the formulas that such circumstances require, even by the stands of America itself. ``President Bush know, or should know, that America itself and during World War II had interned tens of thousands of its citizens simply because they were of Japanese origin and based this action on the theory of deterring larger harm by lesser, or smaller harm. ``So if this precedent already exists and is recorded in the files of the United States of America along with other actions recorded in the files on humanity, isn't it a form of racial discrimination when what is allowed for other nations, including the Americans, is not allowed for the Arabs, including the Iraqis? ``Despite all this, the Iraqis have stated clearly that what has happened was a force majeure dictated by the circumstances among many other options.'' ``And we regret what happened. ``Preventing some foreigners from traveling is not an act of vengeance, but a force majeure to deter a crime of aggression President Bush intends to commit against the people of Iraq after the crime he committed in occupying the Shrine of Kaaba (Mecca) and the tomb of the Prophet (Medina), and should he proceed to commit this crime, then a major catastrophe will befall not only this region but the entire world. ``Bush continues in his speech to talk about the outlaws, comparing clearly between Iraq and its representatives and Hitler, forgetting that all these descriptions apply to him because Iraq did not send its fleets and aircraft to attack Europe or America. It is Bush and those whom he dragged with him to the cliff who were the ones who embarked the aircraft and ships and invaded our region. After desecrating our sanctities, they want to kill the people and rob them of their human rights. ``Is there any doubt that these descriptions apply to Presient Bush when he is seeking to fuel a war that might burn the entire world? Is there a better proof of his intentions after he stonewalled all the initiatives and solutions which we had offered for settling the main problem or the issue of the foreigners which is a result of the main problem? ``It is undoubtedly misbehavior, a reflection of poor insight and wisdom, for the White House to reject our initiative of the 12th of August 1990, a few hours after it was aired before President Bush took it upon himself to request official text to guard against inaccuracy in translation or deficiency in phrases for technical reasons. ``Is this possible, President of the United States of America? ``He who does not want history to link him to the basic characteristics of Hitler, must search thoroughly for peaceful means and not rush into preparations for war. ``What we presented in our initiative of the 12th of August 1990, and in our letter to the families of the foreigners whom the National Council decided to host, is a clear way for anyone to distance himself from the basic descriptions of Hitler. ``Characteristics of love and peace that are desired by the peoples of the world. ``At the same time, we defend, without fear from any arrogant and sinful tyrant or aggressor, the principles of our religion and holy shrines and the honor of the homeland and nation, even all the values of humanity combined. ``The claim that the American forces have come here to defend Saudi Arabia does not stand in the face of the conflicting fact because the reality is that we have no intention of attacking Saudi Arabia or any other country. ``However, to say that your forces came here to defend American interests: you know that the Arabs, including Iraq, are not opposed to legitimate interests, whether they be the West's in general, or the United States.' ``You also know that prosperity, scientific and technical development and the promotion and flourishing of growth, cannot be achieved in the way the Arabs want it to without the West's cooperation. ``To achieve this, the Arabs have to sell oil. The major oil market is Europe and the United States, in addition to Japan. ``I assume that President Bush knows that Iraq, for example, sold a third of its oil to the United States until the 2nd of August 1990, and that Iraq was against the feverish price increases that took place in 1973. We have documents to prove that. ``At any rate, the Arabs, including Iraq, wish to sell their oil for all the purposes we have already mentioned, not to drink it or freeze it. ``The fact that Iraq owns about 20 percent of the world's oil reserves does not annul the principles we have already referred to. ``If whoever owns oil is boycotted by the world, it would be all the more reason for the world to boycott America and the Saudi Arabian government. ``After all, is not food more vital to the human being than oil? ``We answer by saying `yes.' By all human standards, it is more vital than oil. The human being cannot survive without food. ``If President Bush's criteria for boycotts, hostility, war and siege are applicable to Iraq merely because it will, or that it already does, own 20 percent of the world's oil reserves, then it is all the more reason that these standards, in every sense, be applied to those who own the same percentage or more of food, primarily grain. ``Then what is required is that the world stand against America and Australia. ``But if U.S. interests have become so small and narrow in Bush's view that they are restricted to the relations between Bush and (Saudi King) Fahd before Bush's assumption of the presidency and followed his election; and if their interests have become so narrow that they do not consider them as they should in terms of good and positive relations with a large and great nation, but consider them only with Jaber al-Ahmed, the Croesus of Kuwait, and his band, who is unable to construct a useful sentence and who, along with people like him, has been a source of shame to the Arabs and proof to the West of their backwardness, then, you will be cursed by what you are doing. ``Before concluding my letter, I would like to say that the source of potential and power, Mr. Bush, does not lie in the size of armies and technological superiority, nor in your alliance with those who betrayed their nation and people. It lies in the inclination toward what is right. ``However, god is greater and more powerful than everyone and, as we have previously said, America would not have been a superpower if it had not been influential in the world. ``In order to remain influential, it must respect the freedom of peoples and the right of nations to make their own choices. It also must respect other people's sanctities and feeling. ``If you continue to ignore this, then I warn of the consequences, and I hereby record for history that pursuing this policy will cause America to fall from its present status and it will lose many opportunities. ``In all circumstances, if your pursue war and blockade, you will be defeated. And, with the help of God, we will triumph. ``God is great. Shame be on the shameless, ``Saddam Hussein, on the 30th of Moharram 1411, corresponding to 21st of Auugust, 1990.''

DOC.HEAD: Air Traffic Controller on Anti-AIDS Drug Accepts New FAA Job
With AM-AIDS Problems, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: A government air traffic controller who lost his Dulles Airport job after he began taking an anti-AIDS drug has accepted a lower-level FAA position in Miami, the controller said Tuesday. Ron Wilkinson said he would continue to pursue an anti-discrimination complaint against the Federal Aviation Administration and planned to file a federal court suit alleging discrimination based on a handicap. FAA spokesman Roger Meyers in Miami confirmed that Wilkinson, 29, had been offered a job in the FAA's Miami control center but said he didn't know whether the job had been accepted. The FAA suspended Wilkinson's medical certificate in July 1989 when he told his superiors at Dulles, which serves the Washington metropolitan area, that he was taking the drug AZT, or zidovudine, after testing positive for the presence of HIV virus. The FAA says that controllers, who have the critical duty of monitoring and directing aircraft, are to be given less critical jobs if they take AZT. Wilkinson said he was only offered another job at Dulles months later, after being put on forced leave. He had argued that the FAA should offer him a job in Miami where he was being treated by a doctor and had a group of people helping him deal with his exposure to AIDS. Wilkinson said he has none of the symptoms of AIDS itself and has been healthy since his medical certificate was lifted. A person who tests positive for antibodies to the AIDS virus has a 20 percent to 30 percent chance of developing AIDS over a five-year period, according to the federal Centers for Disease Control. Acquired immune deficiency syndrome attacks the body's immune system, rendering it incapable of resisting other diseases and infections. The FAA has said AZT may impair a controller's ability to keep track of aircraft. Wilkinson, his lawyers and the controllers' union have disputed that, saying medical evidence shows no serious side effects from use of the drug. Wilkinson said he has accepted a job as an air traffic assistant, with a salary $4,000 lower than his earnings as a full controller. In accepting, he said, he retained his right to pursue the anti-discrimination case. The new job also will deny him an additional $4,000 in overtime and differential pay, he said. The FAA has yet to confirm his employment or set a starting date for the new job, he said. The agency gave him until Aug. 22 to accept or reject the offer, he said. Wilkinson said he has nearly 11 years of federal service, including eight years as an Air Force controller. He said he would have qualified as a top-level controller in about a year if his certificate had not been voided.

DOC.HEAD: With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Army 1st Lt. Dominique Allen doesn't want to wait around her post much longer. She wants to join her husband of less than two weeks in the Saudi Arabian desert. Her husband, Spec. Joseph A. Hudert III, already is stationed with the 82nd Airborne Corps in the Middle East. ``I'll feel better being over there,'' the 24-year-old nurse said Monday. ``I'll be busy. I'm doing my part for the Army. I might be able to see him. The chances are slight, but I might.'' She and her husband, who met in ROTC at Virginia Commonwealth University, had dated for six years and had planned to marry next year. But when word came down that both likely would be sent to the Mideast, they decided to move things up. In a speech Monday, President Bush cited the newlyweds as fine examples of the soldiers participating in Operation Desert Shield. He said they ``show the true caliber of America and the vital essence of our mission.''

Peter Burrell can't say exactly what motivated him to take his chances and set out from Baghdad across the Iraqi desert nearly a week after the Kuwait invasion, but his timing was good. ``The borders weren't open one day before, and they weren't open one day after,'' Burrell said. ``It was the one day that looked the best.'' Burrell celebrated his safe return Monday with his wife, Jeanette, and about 50 friends and schoolchildren. Burrell, an engineer for Brisbane-based Johnson Controls International, had been in the Iraqi capital only about three weeks when Iraq invaded Kuwait. He said he and 35 others from the United States, Great Britain, Yugoslavia and Germany left Baghdad Aug. 8, heading for the Jordanian border in cars and buses. They found that travel across the Iraqi desert was not restricted. But Burrell and the others weren't sure until near the end of the 18-hour desert journey that the border to Jordan would be open.

The man who commanded ground forces in the aborted 1980 attempt to free hostages from Iran says it's time for the United States to declare war on Iraq and kick it out of Kuwait. ``I've seen enough war to last me more than my lifetime, but at this particular juncture, we got a maniac over there and we need take necessary steps to get rid of him,'' retired Army. Col. Charles Beckwith said in a telephone interview Tuesday from his home in Austin, Texas. He said he didn't think there was any need yet to go in and rescue any Americans from Kuwait or Iraq. But he was much more forceful on what should be done if Iraq uses poison gas, saying that if ``one American soldier is killed as a result of that I would pray that George Bush would employ nuclear tactical weapons on the battlefield.''

State Rep. Paul McHale, a major in the Marine Corps Reserve, volunteered last week for active duty and is now in Saudi Arabia, according to his wife and a Marine official. McHale was serving his two-week, annual reserve stint with the 7th Marine Expeditionary Brigade in Twentynine Palms, Calif., when the infantry brigade received orders to ship out. McHale, 40, an infantry officer with training in desert warfare, applied to go overseas with the unit. McHale is expected to be in the Middle East for six months, said his wife, Katherine. ``No one who knows Paul is surprised,'' she said. ``He was in a situation where he had something to offer and felt strongly that it was his responsibility to do it.'' McHale, a state House member since 1982, is up for re-election this November, but is running uncontested.

DOC.HEAD: Death Sentence Commuted to Life After Pleas by Religious Figures
DOC.TEXT: The state Board of Pardon and Paroles on Tuesday commuted the death sentence of a repentant convict after receiving pleas for mercy from Mother Teresa, Jesse Jackson and relatives of the murder victim. William Neal Moore's defenders call him a born-again Christian who has been a positive influence on other prisoners. Moore, 39, had been scheduled to die Wednesday in Georgia's electric chair, but won a stay of execution earlier Tuesday from the U.S. Supreme Court. Moore was a depressed 23-year-old soldier from Fort Gordon when a friend told him about an old man who kept $20,000 cash in his home, according to evidence in the case. Moore got drunk and entered the home of 77-year-old Fredger Stapleton. When Stapleton fired a gun at him, Moore said he panicked and shot back, killing the man. It was the third time the Pardons and Paroles Board had granted clemency to a Georgia death-row inmate since capital punishment was reinstated in 1976. In both other cases, a conspirator had been sentenced to die while the defendant who actually committed the killing received a life sentence. Chairman Wayne Snow Jr. said he believed the board's unanimous decision was based largely on the fact that Moore, who pleaded guilty, did not have a jury trial. The board members felt considerable information about Moore ``might have come out in a trial of the case,'' Snow said. He also noted that members of the victim's family had asked the board to spare Moore's life. ``That's not something we often see,'' Snow said. The parole board heard Monday from Mother Teresa, the Nobel Peace Prize winner, who called from Calcutta, India, and urged the panel to ``do what Jesus would do,'' said staff member Marsha Bailey, who took the call. Jackson, the former Democratic presidential candidate, wired the board on Saturday to urge clemency. Snow said Moore, under Georgia law, will not be eligible for parole consideration until he has served 25 years in prison, meaning Moore will have to wait nine more years. Moore has written Stapleton's family members ``a lot of times from prison, that he's sorry, and that he hopes the family can forgive him,'' said Loretta Jordan Farmer, Stapleton's great-niece. ``And I can.'' The petition seeking clemency said the Columbus, Ohio, native was a good person who joined the Army as a teen-ager, compiled a spotless record and was weighing a military career when his wife, his childhood sweetheart, soured on the traveling of Army life and left him, taking their 2-year-old son.

DOC.HEAD: Sununu Says Bush Image Not Hurt by Vacation During Crisis
With AM-US-Gulf Bjt
DOC.TEXT: White House Chief of Staff John Sununu on Tuesday shrugged off the idea that President Bush was hurting his image by vacationing during the Mideast standoff with Iraq. Sununu joined the president on a golf outing here to raise funds for Maine Gov. John McKernan's re-election campaign. Bush has gone boating daily and made several trips to the golf course since coming to Maine Aug. 10 for a 25-day vacation. He has flown back to the White House twice, met at his oceanfront home with Jordan's King Hussein and spent hours on the telephone dealing with the crisis. ``I think everybody knows he keeps in touch with what's happening,'' Sununu said. ``I'd rather have a president that kept the whole thing in perspective than one who locked himself behind closed doors and brooded about the whole problem.'' White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater, speaking separately with reporters, said ``the president's in command wherever he is. That's all that matters.'' One reporter asked Sununu if he thought Bush ``wouldn't have this problem if Saddam Hussein played golf?'' ``He's got one large sandtrap, doesn't he?'' Sununu said with a laugh.

DOC.HEAD: White House Rebuffs Iraq Negotiation Offer
DOC.NOTE: Eds: CORRECTS Maine to Maryland in last graf
DOC.TEXT: The White House on Tuesday rebuffed an offer from Iraq to negotiate, saying ``the world is united'' in demanding the unconditional withdrawal of Saddan Hussein's army from Kuwait. White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater said Western nations are willing to talk to Iraqi officials about the welfare of their citizens held in Iraq and Kuwait. ``But that's not the same as negotiations over a U.N. demand to get out,'' said the press secretary. He declined to respond to what he called the latest ``litany'' of criticism of Bush from Saddam. Iraq's foreign minister, Tariq Aziz, said in Amman, Jordan, Tuesday that ``we are ready to talk'' and ``put all the cards on the table'' at a U.N. Security Council meeting. Aziz and Saddam, in separate statements, warned that the United States would be defeated and ``humiliated'' if it went to war against Iraq. Fitzwater said Iraqi officials have refused to give a U.S. diplomat in Baghdad access to Americans, and he added, ``At this point we see very little to talk about when all we get are negative responses.'' The White House also announced that Defense Secretary Dick Cheney, returning from a trip through the tense Middle East, and Gen. Colin Powell, the chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, will fly to Maine Wednesday to confer with Bush at his oceanfront vacation home. Among the matters they will discuss are a planned call-up of military reserves. Fitzwater said Bush will not sign before Wednesday the order calling up reserves to fill in the ranks of doctors, cargo handlers and other specialists depleted by the massive deployment of U.S. troops to defend Saudi Arabia. The number of reservists to be called was still unspecified. One administration official said privately the order may be open-ended. Chief of Staff John Sununu said it will be a ``very surgical, specialized call-up.'' Fitzwater said 18 Americans got out of Kuwait Tuesday but ``there are still 54 Americans missing'' _ 13 in Kuwait and 41 in Iraq. ``It does appear that citizens of all nations are being moved about in Iraq to unknown destinations,'' he said. In Washington, State Department spokesman Richard Boucher said there were ``credible reports'' that Iraq had forced some Westerners to industrial installations and said an American in Kuwait was seized in his home and interned in a hotel. Boucher said the reports had not been confirmed, nor was it known whether Americans were among those taken to plants. Saddam has threatened to use Westerners as a human shield to dissuade the United States from attack. More than 3,000 Americans are among more than 10,000 foreigners trapped in Iraq and Kuwait. The buildup of U.S. forces continued in Saudi Arabia. At the Pentagon, Gen. Hansford T. Johnson, the top official responsible for getting troops and supplies to Saudi Arabia, said security rules prevented him from disclosing the exact number of ground troops there or on the way but that ``we've moved in essence'' the equivalent of a town the size of Jefferson City, Mo. Preliminary 1990 census figures put Jefferson City's population at 35,408. An additional 20,000 or so sailors are deployed on warships in the area. Fitzwater spoke with reporters at the Woodlands Country Club in Falmouth, Maine, while Bush was out golfing at a tournament raising $200,000 for Maine Gov. John McKernan's re-election drive. Fitzwater stressed that it was not the United States alone but ``all nations'' that were demanding Iraq to end its occupation of Kuwait. ``We demand complete and unconditional withdrawal from Kuwait. That is the position of the United Nations and that's the position of all nations,'' the spokesman said. ``I'm sure all nations are interested in the welfare of their citizens, interested in talking to Iraq at any point. That's not the same as negotiations over a U.N. demand to get out,'' he said. Fitzwater said Joseph Wilson, the U.S. charge d'affaires in Baghdad, met with Iraqi officials Monday demanding access to Americans. His plea was spurned. Asked if there could be no talks with Iraq until its tanks are out of Kuwait, Fitzwater replied, ``The important point here is that the world is united in demanding that Iraq withdraw from Kuwait. That has not changed one iota by these comments this morning.'' Bush, back from a day of speeches in which he termed the foreigners in Iraq and Kuwait hostages and attacked Saddam as ``a man of evil standing against human life itself,'' ignored reporters Tuesday, saying nothing to them during on an early morning jog and on the golf course. Bush spoke by telephone Tuesday to Thomas Pickering, the U.S. ambassador to the United Nations, and to National Security Adviser Brent Scowcroft who was back at the White House. Fitzwater said U.S. warships were still shadowing several ships in the Persian Gulf region to make sure none violated the trade embargo with Iraq. However, he said, one Iraqi tanker was being allowed to dock in a Yemen port based on assurances from the Yemeni government that that country would not unload or use Iraqi oil. Sununu, also out golfing in McKernan's tournament, defended Bush's decision to stay in Maine in spite of the crisis. ``Everybody knows he keeps in touch with what's happening,'' said Sununu. ``I'd rather have a president who kept the whole thing in perspective than one who locked himself behind closed doors and brooded about the problem.'' The president later attended a memorial service for his uncle, Dr. John Walker, 81, a retired surgeon and investment banker from Easton, Md., who died Thursday.

DOC.HEAD: Saudi and Iraqi Pilots Play Games Along Border
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Saudi and Iraqi pilots are playing cat-and-mouse games along the border virtually every day, the commander of a Saudi air base said Tuesday. Prince Turki Bin Nasser also confirmed that the Iraqis have moved mobile missile launchers capable of delivering chemical weapons into Kuwait. In the aerial games, neither side is very close, Turki said. Normally the Iraqis fly about 40 miles from the border while the Saudis are about 20 to 30 miles from their border. Turki briefed reporters on condition they not identify the location of the base or the names of Saudi pilots who are working with American fliers. ``There is always this cat-and-mouse thing on the border,'' Turki said. ``They have done it more than once . . . almost every day.'' The Saudis are flying 24 hours day in shifts and are often in American-made F-15 jets. The Iraqi Air Force is equipped with MiGs and Mirage jets. A Saudi pilot said a pilot will ``lock on'' to an Iraqi with his radar or vice-versa. Pilots know they have a pilot in their sights when they see a blip on the screen. Once an Iraqi pilot knows he's in the sights of a Saudi, ``they turn and go home,'' said the pilot, speaking on condition he not be identified. The Saudi pilot said his role is defensive, but he would not hesitate to fire a missile if an Iraqi crossed the border or appeared to be a threat. Asked about London reports in the Jane's Soviet Intelligence Review that Iraq has moved 36 Scud missile launchers into into Kuwait, he said President Saddam Hussein of Iraq put missiles in the seized territory the first week after he invaded Aug. 2. ``Any movement into Kuwait is a threat,'' he said. The Scud, which Iraq used in its war with Iran in the 1980s, is a ground-to-ground missile. To counter Iraqi missiles, the United States has shipped the advanced Patriot air defense system to Saudi Arabia. The state-of-the-art Patriots are capable of defending against aircraft and missiles. They have only been deployed in the United States and West Germany before.

DOC.HEAD: Two Drown After Cruise Ship's Lifeboat Dumps Crew Members into Harbor
DOC.TEXT: Coast Guard investigators inspected a cruise ship Tuesday after two crewmen drowned and five were injured during a dockside safety drill. A cable holding a lifeboat broke during the drill Monday, dumping 13 crew members of the Regent Sun into the frigid waters of Skagway Harbor, police said. Most were quickly pulled from the water, but divers had to retrieve the bodies of the drowning victims. Rescuers tried for more than an hour to revive them on the Skagway dock. The two were a 24-year-old Honduran and a 59-year-old Greek. Police and the ship's owner declined to release their names Tuesday because relatives had not been notified. One crewman, Juan Matute, 23, remained hospitalized, in stable condition with a head injury. The men who died apparently were trapped under the lifeboat when it fell on top of them, said Jeff Brady, editor and publisher of the Skagway News. All the crew members were wearing life jackets, Brady said. Ann Burguieres, communications manager for the ship's owner, Regency Cruises Inc. in New York, said it appeared to be a freak accident. It was the first fatal accident on the ship, she said. The Regent Sun continued to its next port, Juneau, where Coast Guard officials were conducting their investigation. Juneau is 92 miles south of Skagway in southeastern Alaska's scenic Inside Passage. Burguieres said the Regent Sun already had been scheduled Tuesday for its quarterly Coast Guard safety inspection. Its safety equipment is inspected by the crew weekly, she said. The Regent Sun is the cruise line's flagship. Built in 1964, it is 627 feet long and registered in the Bahamas. The crew is mostly European, Burguieres said. The ship operates in the Inside Passage during the summer, offering seven-day cruises between Vancouver, British Columbia, and Whittier, southeast of Anchorage. The current cruise originated in Whittier on Friday, Burguieres said.

DOC.HEAD: A United Germany: Mighty Nation with Problems to Solve
With AM-Germany-Unification, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: When the two Germanys finally unite, they will be a mighty nation of 78 million people stretching from France to Poland. The two Germanys were founded in 1949. Their division resulted from Adolf Hitler's defeat in 1945. East Germany was run by Stalinist leaders for four decades, while West Germany immediately adopted a parliamentary democracy system of government. West Germans built a prosperous nation from the ashes of World War II. West Germany has one of the world's most powerful economies and is known for its excellence in high-technology. Its currency, the deutsche mark, is king in Europe. Over the past two years West Germany has also established itself as an important player in world politics. East Germany was long considered one of the most prosperous nations in Eastern Europe. But last fall's revolution revealed a nation that had been weakened by years of Communist mismanagement and corruption. East Germany has major industries, including chemical production. But many of its industries are on the verge of collapse, overburdened by antiquated production practices, crumbling factories, and skyrocketing debts. Financial experts say the Germans will expand their economic might after unification. But many problems will have to be overcome, such as soaring unemployment in what is now East Germany. Some experts predict that within 10 years, East Germans will enjoy the same kind of prosperity as their Western neighbors. When the two nations unite, their total area will be roughly the size of Montana.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Expects Improved Cooperation With Mexico In Narcotics War
DOC.TEXT: Drug control cooperation between the United States and Mexico is expected to improve in the coming year but the next few months will be critical in dealing with new governments of Colombia and Peru, the State Department said Tuesday. In a midyear update of its annual international narcotics control strategy report, the department's Bureau of International Narcotics Matters said it is encouraged by developments in the fight against cocaine, but the heroin situation gives less reason for optimism. ``With new governments of two of the Andean nations _ Colombia and Peru _ the coming months will be critical if the hemispheric commitment to narcotics is to be sustained and tangible progress made in dismantling trafficking networks and reducing the cocaine supply,'' the department said. It said the outgoing government of Peru declined to sign an agreement for $35 million in U.S. military aid to assist in counter-narcotics efforts, but new President Alberto Fujimori ``has indicated a commitment to continuing the counter-narcotics effort, as well as a willingness to conclude agreements on military assistance.'' It said the Colombian government ``has continued to extradite major drug traffickers and money launderers to the United States, an action which Colombian traffickers fear most.'' ``Given recent decreases in reported cocaine usage in the United States and reported reductions in emergency room incidents involving cocaine, these developments in the Andes provide reasons for encouragement,'' the report said. ``The U.S. and Mexico continued to cooperate closely on cocaine interdiction ... and we expect that cooperation between the U.S. and Mexico will continue to improve during the coming year,'' the department said. However, the department said, ``The international heroin situation is not as encouraging as that of cocaine. Overproduction of opium has kept prices down in the U.S. and Europe and the supply of heroin is abundant worldwide.''

DOC.HEAD: UNDATED: running uncontested
DOC.TEXT: Army Pfc. Holly Kittle didn't exactly leave Hal Weese standing at the altar, but their wedding did have to be called off. Less than 36 hours before their August marriage, Kittle was ordered back to Fort Campbell, Ky., to prepare to ship out for the Middle East. ``My aunt said it was almost as if the minister had said, `If there's anyone present who objects to this couple getting married, speak now or forever hold your peace,' and Uncle Sam stood up and waved his hand,'' said Weese, an Army specialist fourth class on leave from Weisbaden, Germany. Weese said his fiance, a personnel clerk who celebrated her first anniversary in the Army last week, hadn't received her orders by Monday. Meanwhile, he was left to cancel the tuxedo rentals, dispose of the already-baked wedding cake and explain the situation to family and guests. Kittle and Weese, both 19, were sweethearts at Elkins High School and graduated in 1989. Before returning for the wedding, they had not seen each other in nine months and had run up phone bills of more than $700 planning the ceremony. The couple was preparing for their wedding rehearsal when the call came for Kittle to return to her base. She could have received a two-day extension if she had presented a marriage certificate, but neither she nor Weese wanted to do that. ``We decided to wait until the event could be a happy one. We've set numerous dates and something has come up each time to cause postponement,'' said Weese, who is on leave until next Wednesday. Beyond then, it could be six months to a year before he returns to the United States from Germany. ``Until then, we'll just have to grin and bear it,'' he said.

A Marine who filed for conscientious objector status last week has been told to prepare for deployment as part of a U.S. policy he says is unnecessarily ``interventionist.'' Marine Cpl. Jeff Paterson, stationed at Kaneohe Marine Corps Air Station, has been told he won't be transferred to a non-deployable unit, attorney Eric Seitz said Monday. But the attorney planned to file a lawsuit Tuesday in U.S. District Court to ensure his client would not be sent to Saudi Arabia. Paterson, 22, of Hollister, Calif., said he belongs to La Casa, a group that objects to U.S. ``interventionist'' policies. He said he does not want to be a pawn in America's fight for Middle East oil and profits. Paterson, who has seven months remaining in his military commitment, has been working as a supply clerk. He formerly worked in the field artillery. Military policy prohibits officials from confirming that a soldier or his or her unit are being deployed. Capt. Leonard Ryan, a spokesman for the Marine base, said filing for conscientious object status did not necessarily exempt him from deployment. Ryan said, however, that if military officials confirm Paterson is a conscientious objector, every effort will be made to transfer him to a non-deployable unit. The determination will be made after a series of interviews, Ryan said. He did not know how long it would take to make a decision. Ryan said Paterson was being charged with unauthorized leave because he was not on leave when he gave an off-base news conference last week to announce his plans to resist deployment.

DOC.HEAD: Elvis' Driving License Sold in London
DOC.TEXT: Elvis Presley's driving license, issued in 1952 when he was a 17-year-old high school student in Tennessee, sold for $7,400 on Tuesday, Sotheby's said. The late King of rock 'n' roll's faded signature was on the tattered license, which gave the color of his eyes as blue, his hair brown and his height 5 feet, 11 inches. An unidentified Canadian collector bought it at a sale of rock and film memorabilia. The highest priced item was a surrealistic collage by John Lennon, bought anonymously for $44,300. It comprised clippings from magazines of girls on motorcycles with superimposed head shots of pop artist Andy Warhol. A 1975 letter from the late member of the Beatles fetched $7,400 and a 10-foot fiberglass statue of him went for $5,300. A bright purple cape worn by pop singer Prince in his film ``Purple Rain'' sold for $13,700 to the Hard Rock Cafe in Los Angeles. The Hard Rock Cafe in London paid $6,300 for a lot, which included the Rolling Stones' first paycheck in 1963 for 30 pounds, worth $84 then.

DOC.HEAD: Baltic Republics Move Toward Talks on Independence
DOC.TEXT: Estonia announced Tuesday it would open the first formal talks on independence with the Kremlin on Thursday, the 51st anniversary of the Hitler-Stalin pact that led to the annexation of the Baltics. Latvian officials said its negotiations on independence would begin with Soviet authorities within 10 days. There was no confirmation from the Kremlin that it would begin talks with either republic. In the Lithuanian capital of Vilnius, lawmakers named an eight-member panel for its talks with the Soviet Union on independence. All three republics have been in the forefront of efforts to win their independence from the Soviet Union, which forcibly absorbed them after the 1939 non-aggression pact signed by Nazi Germany and the Soviet Union. The pact, along with secret protocols, placed the three into Moscow's sphere of influence. It also cleared the way for Germany to invade Poland about a week later to begin World War II. After decades of denials, Soviet officials finally admitted in August 1989 that a secret deal with Adolf Hilter had deeded control of the Baltics to the Kremlin. Baltic activists have long maintained that the secret agreement and the republics' annexation by the Soviet Union were illegal. Activists plan bonfire demonstrations in all three republics Thursday to mark the anniversary. Church bells also are to be rung at the same time throughout the region along the Soviet Union's western border. Endel Lippmaa, the Estonian government minister in charge of negotiations with the Kremlin, told The Associated Press in a telephone interview that the republic's five-member delegation would begin talks with Soviet officials in Moscow on Thursday. He said the talks were aimed at full independence for Estonia. He stressed that Estonia was not interested in remaining in the Soviet Union in a new confederation or in a new federal government structure. In Moscow, Latvian officials met for more than two hours with Soviet authorities to discuss independence-related issues. Andrejs Krastins, deputy chairman of the republic's parliament, said the first formal talks between the Kremlin and any of the three Baltic republics would open Thursday in Moscow. ``The talks will be between two equal partners,'' he told a news conference. The Soviet TV program Vremya made no mention of any upcoming talks or an agreement by Soviet officials to deal with the Latvians as equals. The official news agency Tass reported the claims by the Latvian officials, but also did not confirm any commitment by the Soviet side. Latvia also promised to protect non-Latvians on its territory _ mainly Russians _ but also said claimed threats against them had been exaggerated. Lithuania named an eight-member team to negotiate independence from the Soviet Union. Lithuania declared its independence on March 11, but has agreed to suspend the measure for 100 days once talks begin. Lithuanian President Vytautas Landsbergis made a radio appeal Tuesday to fight the black market activity that blossomed during a Kremlin economic blockade imposed in the dispute over independence. The blockade has since been lifted, but black-market dealing continues. The Baltics weren't the only republics moving toward independence Tuesday. Armenia's parliament debated a declaration of independence, but decided to delay a vote until at least Wednesday.

DOC.HEAD: Norfolk Again Says Goodbye to Its Troops
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 5th graf to CORRECT to James River sted St. James.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto upcoming
DOC.TEXT: The Persian Gulf crisis is more than headlines to those with ties to the world's largest naval base. It means once again, saying goodbye to husbands and wives, sons and daughters, neighbors and friends. ``These are not just news stories, these are our neighbors,'' said Jack Hornbeck, president of the local Chamber of Commerce. ``I live in Virginia Beach. Next door and across the street are naval aviators. A surface warfare officer lives just down the block. ``When they deploy, the neighborhood kind of pulls together to help out the families. We want these people to know we support them.'' Deployments are nothing new to the Norfolk area, home to a variety of military posts, inluding the largest naval base, Norfolk Naval Station. In the past two weeks, 34,000 have left in ships and planes as part of the deployment of U.S. troops to Saudi Arabia and the Persian Gulf. Thirty-five ships carrying 28,000 sailors left from the Norfolk Naval Station and nearby Little Creek Amphibious Base since the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait. Forty-eight F-15s have flown from Langley Air Force Base, across the James River from Norfolk. But more than 100,000 sailors and nearly 100 ships remain at the Norfolk Naval Station. The deployments came on short notice after Iraqi tanks rolled into Kuwait on Aug. 2. The aircraft carrier John F. Kennedy had five days notice. That left little time for anything other than preparations. ``The major challenge for these families was getting ready to leave,'' Capt. Tom Johnson, Atlantic Fleet chaplain, said Tuesday. ``Now they are seeing the empty piers and the reality of the separation is setting in.'' Cmdr. George Keller, director of the Norfolk Navy Family Services Center said the number of calls for assistance has increased. ``The unknown is the most significant thing. This was on such short notice and that has raised the level of stress. Deployments are something the Navy lives with,'' he said. Area leaders say the influence of the military on the area goes beyond the mere numbers. The military brings more than $5.4 billion to the local economy every year. More than a quarter of the area's 1.3 million people have a direct link to the military. ``It's hard to find anybody in any walk of life in this area that didn't start in the Navy,'' said Donald Smith, a sociologist at Old Dominion University. ``The Navy is very much a part of us ... part of our community. There is no us or them,'' Norfolk Mayor Joe Leafe said. Cathy Stokoe, executive director of the Navy Family Services Center and a Navy wife for 26 years, said the community's feelings toward the troops and their families makes life a little easier when the threat of war is near. ``If there is something going on, you couldn't ask for a better place to be,'' she said.

DOC.HEAD: Lawsuit Challenges NRC Decision on Low-level Waste
DOC.TEXT: More than two dozen groups filed a lawsuit Tuesday challenging a Nuclear Regulatory Commission decision to ease controls on the disposal of low-level nuclear wastes. The lawsuit, filed in the U.S. Court of Appeals here, said the new policy means unhealthy levels of radiation could be left in the soil and buildings at closed nuclear power plants and that radioactive contamination could drift into the ground water at garbage dumps. The lawsuit also alleges that NRC didn't provide for adequate public participation before issuing the new policy in June. ``The NRC's rule trades off people's lives in favor of the financial interests of the nuclear industry,'' said Joan Claybrook, president of Public Citizen, one of the environmental groups that filed the lawsuit. The NRC said it would, on a case-by-case basis, deregulate the disposal of certain low-level atomic wastes from nuclear power plants, hospitals, laboratories and other facilities if the radioactive emissions are considered ``below regulatory concern.'' Under the new policy, such wastes could be disposed of in conventional landfills. All radioactive wastes under previous NRC policy automatically must be given special precautions and taken to designated disposal sites. The NRC has argued that many of the low-level wastes now requiring special treatment emit such a low dosage of radiation that they don't pose a health concern.
