In addition to Public Citizen, other groups joining the lawsuit were the U.S. Public Interest Research Group, the Natural Resources Defense Council, the Nuclear Information and Resource Service and Physicians for Social Responsibility.

DOC.HEAD: Trotsky Eulogized 50 Years After His Assassination
LaserPhoto MO2
DOC.TEXT: Fifty years after Soviet revolutionary Leon Trotsky was assassinated with an ice ax in Mexico City, city fathers hailed him as a symbol of Mexico's policy of granting asylum to exiles regardless of political stripe. Trotsky is being honored and called a visionary, and the restored Trotsky house was inaugurated as a city-run museum. Mayor Manuel Camacho Solis said at Monday's ceremonies, ``In current times, the most profound significance of this house is in communicating that what happened here should never again happen again: harassing and taking the life of someone who thinks differently.'' ``What Trotsky predicted _ the end of the system that persecuted him _ is today being achieved,'' said another speaker, political historian Adolfo Sanchez Vazquez. Trotsky died on Aug. 22, 1940, 26 hours after Soviet dictator Josef Stalin had his political rival murderously assaulted at Trotsky's home-in-exile in the fashionable Mexico City neighborhood of Coyoacan. The assassin, who struck Trotsky in the skull with a mountaineer's ice ax after Trotsky returned from a seafood restaurant, spent 20 years in prison. His identity was a mystery but he was thought to be a Spaniard, Ramon del Rio Mercader, also known as Jacques Mornard and Frank Jackson. The house, formerly maintained on meager funds donated by Trotsky's grandson, Esteban Volkow, and members of the Trotskyist Revolutionary Workers Party, was given a meticulous facelift. The city spent more than $230,000 to refurbish it and build the adjacent Asylum Rights and Public Freedom Institute. The institute affirms Mexico's policy of providing political asylum to exiles, regardless of ideology, officials said at the ceremony. ``It is a transformation of history into an instrument of rights,'' institute board member Javier Wimer told about 200 people. Trotsky and his wife, Natalia Sedova, arrived in Mexico in January 1937, after Stalin ordered Trotsky's exile and execution. The two leaders of the 1917 Bolshevik revolution were locked in a power struggle as the health of Vladimir Lenin, founder of the Soviet state, waned. Camacho said Trotsky's exile in Mexico was an example of this country's overall international and internal policy _ ``Everyone was against Trotsky and the president of the republic received him in Mexico.'' Mexico has given asylum to the late Shah of Iran, refugees from the Spanish Civil War and Chilean exiles. Edgar Sanchez, spokesman of the Revolutionary Workers Party, attended the ceremony with more than a dozen party members waving red and white party flags. ``It's very positive what is happening here now,'' he said in an interview. He lauded the government's policy on political asylum but added that Camacho's presence ``doesn't change the fact that there are other rights that are not respected by the government of the Institutional Revolutionary Party.'' He was referring to the governing party that has dominated Mexican politics since 1929, often through fraud and intimidation. Members of two other Trotskyist groups gave the Soviet Union's Mexican ambassador a petition with 500 signatures demanding changes in the way Trotsky's role is taught in the Soviet Union. Trotsky traditionally has been vilified in Soviet textbooks as a traitor to the Communist Party. The institute's book collection includes 5,000 volumes by and about Trotsky and other exiles, museum coordinator Jose Enrique Ortiz said. Harvard University donated a catalog of the complete works of Trotsky contained in its library. The institute's exposition hall opened with works by exiled Chileans and Spaniards in Mexico. Two wall-sized paintings depicting Trotsky's assassination dominate the exhibit. Volkow, who found Trotsky bleeding to death in his study, attended the ceremony. Museum specialists restored the house and gardens where Trotsky's ashes are buried, using documents and photos to return it to its condition at the time of Trotsky's death, Ortiz said. The garden reflects Trotsky's passion for collecting the hardy desert plants that his wife spent much of her time tending, he added. Trotsky's eyeglasses, broken in the attack, are perched on his writing desk along with documents about World War I and Stalin, subjects Trotsky was writing about when he was killed. Bloodstains from the fatal attack are still in the house. So are bullet holes in bedroom walls from an earlier assassination attempt.

DOC.HEAD: Leftist Guerrillas Attack Barracks, Five Civilians Hurt
DOC.NOTE: EDs: Subs 3rd graf, Military sources, to update that one killed
DOC.TEXT: An attack by leftist guerrillas in El Salvador on an army barracks across the street from the presidential residence raises doubts about the rebels' willingness to negotiate, the State Department said Tuesday. ``The guerrillas should immediately cease these attacks and negotiate seriously to end the war,'' said the department's deputy spokesman, Richard Boucher. Military sources in San Salvador, the Salvadoran capital, said one person was killed and five were wounded in Monday night's battle. Army troops backed by helicopter gunships exchanged automatic rifle fire with the rebels for about 30 minutes. The attackers withdrew shortly after nightfall. The guerrilla attack came as peace talks in neighboring Costa Rica stalled Monday over rebel demands that the army be abolished and officers be punished for politically motivated murders. ``These actions raise serious questions about FMLN (guerrilla) willingness to reach a negotiated end to the war,'' Boucher said. ``Rather, the guerrillas appear to be trying to cause a break in the talks and renewed violence. The guerrillas continue to threaten a second offensive.'' More than 73,000 people, the majority of them civilians, have been killed since the war began in October 1979.

DOC.HEAD: Palestinian Stabs Tourist in Jerusalem; Anti-U.S. Sentiments High
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: A Palestinian shouting ``American! American!'' on Tuesday stabbed a tourist outside the Old City of Jerusalem as anti-U.S. feelings continued running high among Palestinians in Israeli-occupied territories. Police identified the tourist as Paul Ollsen, 28, from South Africa, and said he was hospitalized in fair condition. The attacker managed to flee, police said. Iraq's President Saddam Hussein _ who the Palestinians view as a hero _ has offered to withdraw from Kuwait in exchange for an Israeli withdrawal from the occupied areas and the Golan Heights, all captured from Arab countries in the 1967 Middle East war. Near the occupied West Bank town of Ramallah, two Palestinian youths armed with wooden clubs injured a Jewish driver in an apparent political attack, police said. The wounded man, Yair Sfarani, 48, was taken to a hospital in Israel. The attackers, who fled in Sfarani's car, were later spotted in the West Bank town of Hebron but escaped, police said. They said the attackers' identities were known and their arrest was expected soon. The attacks came as Palestinians shuttered shops and offices in a general strike throughout the West Bank, the Gaza Strip and the annexed Arab east Jerusalem. The strike was called to commemorate the 1969 arson attack on the Al-Aqsa Mosque, one of Islam's holiest shrines. The mosque in the walled Old City was severely damaged in the fire, set by an Australian Christian tourist who apparently believed it would hurry the return of the Messiah. In Gaza, Israeli soldiers shot and wounded at least 11 Arabs during stone-throwing clashes in four refugee camps, Arab hospital officials reported. The military command said it was checking the reports. Also Tuesday, the Interior Ministry said it has banned three Palestinian activists, including leading PLO supporter Faisal Husseini, from travel abroad on grounds it would harm Israeli security. Army radio said the Interior Ministry had been given information by Israeli security agents alleging the activists planned to meet with groups ``hostile to the state.'' The radio did not elaborate, but the phrase usually refers to the Palestine Liberation Organization. The travel bans will prevent the Palestinians from attending a conference in Geneva next week on non-governmental organizations.

DOC.HEAD: UN Charter Provides Joint Military Action to Enforce Embargoes
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Following are Articles 41, 42, 43 and 51 under Chapter 7 of the U.N. charter covering Security Council action in cases of threats to peace and acts of agggression:
DOC.HEAD: Article 41
DOC.TEXT: The Security Council may decide what measures not involving the use of armed force are to be employed to give effect to its decisions, and it may call upon the members of the United Nations to apply such measures. These may include complete or partial interruption of economic relations and of rail, sea, air, postal, telegraphic, radio and other means of communication, and the severance of diplomatic relations.
DOC.HEAD: Article 42
DOC.TEXT: Should the Security Council consider that measures provided for in Article 41 would be inadequate or have proved to be inadequate, it may take such action by air, sea or land forces as may be necessary to maintain or restore international peace and security. Such action may include demonstrations, blockade, and other operations by air, sea, or land forces of members of the United Nations.
DOC.HEAD: Article 43
DOC.TEXT: 1. All members of the United Nations, in order to contribute to the maintenance of international peace and security, undertake to make available to the Security Council, on its call and in accordance with special agreement or agreements, armed forces, assistance, and facilities, including rights of passage, necessary for the purpose of maintaining international peace and security. 2. Such agreement or agreements shall govern the numbers and types of forces, their degree of readiness and general location, and the nature of the facilities and assistance to be provided. 3. The agreement or agreements shall be negotiated as soon as possible on the initiative of the Security Council. they shall be concluded between the Security Council and members or between the Security Council and groups of members and shall be subject to ratification by the signatory states in accordance with their respective constitutional processes.
DOC.HEAD: Article 51
DOC.TEXT: Nothing in the present Charter shall impair the inherent right of individual or collective self-defense if an armed attack occurs against a member of the United Nations, until the Security Council has taken measures necessary to maintain international peace and security. Measures taken by members in the exercise of this right of self-defense shall be immediately reported to the Security Council and shall not in any way affect the authority and responsibility of the Security Council under the present Charter to take at any time such actgion as it deems necessary in order to maintain or restore international peace and security.''

DOC.HEAD: United Nations Says 75 Staff, Dependents Leaving Baghdad
DOC.TEXT: Seventy-five U.N. staff and dependents have left the Iraqi capital of Baghdad and the world body intends to remove the remaining 235 staff and families from Iraq and Kuwait, U.N. officials said Tuesday. A U.N. spokeswoman who briefed reporters declined to call the move an evacuation, but U.N. diplomats said the staff was being evacuated for their own safety during the gulf crisis. Iraq invaded Kuwait on Aug. 2, then declared its annexation. During the weekend, Iraq ordered all foreign missions in Kuwait to move their operations to Baghdad by Friday, or the remaining diplomats would be treated as foreign nationals _ many of whom have been taken to possible military targets. The spokeswoman, speaking on condition of anonymity, said communications links with Kuwait City were cut and she declined comment on the Iraqi demand that all foreign missions in Kuwait be closed. The 75 staff members and families worked for the Economic and Social Commission for West Asia.

DOC.HEAD: Despite Successful Prosecution, People Call For Tougher Law
DOC.TEXT: Even though the first test of a new federal law against drunken flying brought conviction of three airline pilots, the prosecutor and others are renewing calls to beef up the law or test pilots for alcohol. ``What we need is to provide the traveling public with aggressive steps to ensure that transportation professionals are sober and unimpaired,'' Steve Hilton, spokesman for Sen. John Danforth, R-Mo., said Tuesday. Danforth is co-sponsoring a bill to require random alcohol testing in safety-related transportation jobs. Barry Sweedler, director of the office of safety recommendations for the National Transportation Safety Board, said he favors a ``zero tolerance'' level for alcohol in pilots. ``There's no place for any alcohol in the cockpit of an airplane or the bridge of a ship or the cab of a truck or the engine of a train,'' Sweedler said. Former Northwest Airlines pilots Norman Lyle Prouse, Robert Kirchner and Joseph Balzer admitted drinking the night before their March 8 flight from Fargo, N.D., to Minneapolis-St. Paul. They argued that they weren't impaired during the flight, despite blood-alcohol readings of 0.13 percent, 0.06 percent and 0.08 percent, respectively, two hours after landing. A jury deliberated three days before finding the three guilty of flying under the influence Monday in the first test of a 1986 federal law aimed at cracking down on alcohol and drug use on commercial transportation. To reach a guilty verdict, jurors had to decide the pilots' performance actually was impaired by drinking. That's because the law doesn't define drunkenness as a certain percentage of alcohol in the blood, as do many state drunken-driving laws. Assistant U.S. Attorney Elizabeth de la Vega said Congress should consider making the law tougher by specifying that it is a felony to fly with blood-alcohol concentrations of 0.04 percent or more. For some pilots, their former colleagues' arrests was all it took for them to rethink their habits. ``I stopped drinking, period,'' Northwest Airlines Capt. Jerry Wortman said Tuesday. ``I think it made me realize that in this job or in any job there's no point to it any more.'' Wortman, a Northwest pilot for the past 23 years, said he was averaging only one drink a week when the arrests prompted him to quit. The case has prompted a handful of commercial pilots to submit to an industry-wide alcohol rehabilitation program, said John Mazor, a spokesman for the Air Line Pilots Association in Washington. Since the program began in the mid-1970s, about 1,200 pilots have signed up, Mazor said. Hilton said it's important to focus on random alcohol testing legislation to improve detection. Rep. James Oberstar, D-Minn., who heads the Aviation Subcommittee of the House Public Works and Transportation Committee, said there is opposition to random alcohol testing on civil liberties grounds. Besides, Oberstar said, aviation experts consider the heavy drinking by the three former Northwest Airlines pilots an aberration. ``We're not talking about an epidemic, that's for sure,'' Oberstar said. According to the NTSB, there have been only 16 airline accidents since 1983 in which drug or alcohol use by pilots was found to be a factor. None of involved a crash of a major airline. The FAA office in Oklahoma City said it has recorded 126 pilot revocations and 111 suspensions for drug and alcohol violations in the past five years. Only 36 of the pilots worked for commercial, passenger-carrying airlines and 12 of those had their licenses revoked, including Prouse, Kirchner and Balzer, the FAA said. Joann Sloane, an FAA spokeswoman in Washington, said the trial has heightened awareness of the problem but hasn't prompted changes in FAA policy. Major U.S. airlines aren't planning changes in their alcohol policies, said Kathleen Henriques, spokeswoman for the Air Transport Association. ``They are continually talking about drinking and flying,'' she said. ``There hasn't been anything spurred by this incident.''

DOC.HEAD: Dog Days Dog the South; Floods Ravage the Northern Tier
DOC.TEXT: Rain was scattered over broad areas of the nation Tuesday, with flooding in parts of Washington and Indiana, and hot, sticky weather gripped parts of the South and southern Plains. Showers and thunderstorms extended from southern Wisconsin across south-central New York state into central New England, south across the eastern half of the Gulf Coast, over parts of Louisiana, eastern Texas, along the Texas Gulf Coast, southeastern Kansas, north-central Wyoming, across the northern Pacific Coast into the Idaho Panhandle. Severe thunderstorms were possible over sections of Indiana, Ohio, Kentucky, Tennessee, North Carolina, South Carolina, Georgia, Mississippi, and Alabama. Heavy rain caused extensive flooding during the morning at Yakima, Wapato, and minor flooding at Selah, Wash., the National Weather Service reported. Heavier rainfall totals included 1.43 inches at Stampede Pass, Wash., and 1.14 inches at Yakima, Wash. Floods were possible over eastern Oregon as well as the Washington Cascades and eastern Washington state, and there was a risk of flooding north of the Salmon River in Idaho. Record flood levels continued along the Tippecanoe River in Indiana. The river at Ora was slightly higher than the previous record flood and there had been little change since late Monday. The Tippecanoe crested at Monterey on Monday. Flood watches were posted for Tuesday into Wednesday over southeastern Virginia as well as the mountains and western portion of West Virginia. A storm, possibly a tornado touchdown, destroyed a trailer north of Gulfport, Miss., early Tuesday, the weather service said. Montgomery, Ala., only reached 98 Tuesday, ending a seven-day streak of 100-plus temperatures. But unseasonably high temperatures and high humidity continued over portions of the southern Plains and the Tennessee Valley. Advisories for heat indices from 105 to 110 degrees Tuesday and Wednesday were posted for northeastern Texas, Arkansas and southwestern Tennessee. Tuesday's low for the Lower 48 states was 32 at Truckee, Calif. Temperatures around the nation at 3 p.m. EDT ranged from 52 at McCall, Idaho, to 102 at Waco, Texas.

DOC.HEAD: Nat'l Strike Hits Peru after Rebels Black Out Much of Country
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 13 grafs to UPDATE with strike effectiveness reports vary, new violence. Picks up 11th graf, `A smaller...'
DOC.TEXT: Rebels blacked out much of Peru and set off bombs in Lima in support of a one-day national strike on Tuesday called to protest austerity measures announced by the new government of President Alberto Fujimori. Most bus drivers stayed home and many stores and factories were shuttered in fear of violence during the strike. Labor leaders said 80 percent of unionized workers stayed off the job in Lima and at least 65 percent did so nationwide. Mining union leaders said 80 percent of Peru's 70,000 miners did not work Tuesday. But business leaders said at least 90 percent of union members showed up for work. Communist and leftist labor organizations called the walkout. They decided on Monday to shorten the strike to 24 hours instead of the original two days. Guerrillas of the Maoist Shining Path organization called an ``armed strike'' to coincide with the national strike, threatening to use violence against anyone who goes to work or engages in business during the stoppage. The rebels blew up at least three electrical towers late Monday, blacking out 80 percent of Lima and most of Peru's southern coast, an electricity company spokesman said, speaking on condition of anonymity. Officials said power was disrupted as north as Chiclayo, 410 miles from the capital. Early Tuesday. rebels firing machine guns from a passing car killed one policeman and wounded another. The officers were trying to arrest a guerrilla for spraying graffitti on a factory wall. Rebels on Tuesday also exploded bombs in front of the Bayer and Bata plants outside Lima, destroying factory doorways but causing no injuries. Immediately after causing the blackout Monday night, the rebels simultaneously exploded two car bombs in the capital, neither of which caused casualties, police said. One blew up in front of an army school in a poor Lima neighborhood. The other exploded near state mining company offices in Callao, Lima's port city, knocking down the wall of a nearby building. Rebels also set fires in the shape of the hammer and sickle on three hills around Lima, police said. A smaller rebel group, the pro-Cuban Tupac Amaru Revolutionary Movement, joined the call for an armed strike Tuesday. Streets in Lima's poor neighborhoods and shantytowns were nearly deserted Tuesday. In previous armed strikes rebels burned dozens of vehicles in these areas. Bus traffic was more normal in downtown Lima and in upper-class neighborhoods, where police presence is greater. Juan Hurtado Miller, the prime minister who is also minister of the economy, said Monday the government would stick by its program despite the workers' complaints. ``I will not take even one step back,'' he said. ``It's not possible to fix in just 15 days what it took five years to destroy,'' he added, referring to the administration of former President Alan Garcia. The government announced a severe austerity plan on Aug. 8 to arrest Peru's 3,000 percent annual inflation and rebuild the country's devastated economy, in which four of five people lack steady work. The price of a gallon of gasoline jumped from 7 cents to more than $2 and the cost of many food products tripled and quadrupled. The government set a new minimum wage of about $50 a month to help workers cope with the new prices. Workers' groups want the minimum raised to $400. On Monday, four Shining Path gunmen killed the owner of a Lima clothing factory and his wife. He apparently refused to pay protection money, police said. Two Shining Path rebels were killed in a gunfight with police in Callao. The rebels were handing out leaflets calling on people to heed the armed strike call, police said. Almost 20,000 Peruvians have died in political violence in the 10 years since the Shining Path took up arms. Officials said the blackout affected large portions of metropolitan Lima and disrupted power along the coast. Shortly after the blackout started, police said they stopped a group of people from lighting a series of torches placed on a hillside to form a hammer and sickle, symbols used by the Shining Path's wing of the Peruvian Communist Party.

DOC.HEAD: Administration Considers Scaling Down Embassy in Kuwait
EDSs: Combines pvs files; inserts 2 grafs after 6th graf, Iraqi President, with background on closure order; trims at end to shorten
DOC.TEXT: The Bush administration is making contingency plans to cut back the U.S. Embassy staff in Kuwait but will not shut its doors despite Iraqi demands, U.S. officials said Tuesday. ``Obviously, we need to maintain an essential presence to take care of American citizens,'' one official told The Associated Press. There are about 120 U.S. diplomats in the Iraqi-occupied Persian Gulf country. Their main concern has been keeping track of the 2,500 or so Americans trapped in the country since the invasion three weeks ago. One of the problems facing administration decision-makers is whether the American diplomats will be able to leave easily or safely. ``There is no final decision on whether or how many U.S. diplomats may be withdrawn,'' said the official, who spoke on condition of anonymity. Iraqi President Saddam Hussein has demanded the closing of embassies in Kuwait City in retaliation for the worldwide economic boycott approved by the U.N. Security Council. Saddam on Monday warned diplomats in Kuwait to shut their embassies by Friday and to transfer their missions to Baghdad. Otherwise, a foreign ministry spokesman said, they ``will be treated ... as ordinary foreign nationals.'' The nine West European nations, meeting Tuesday in Paris, rejected the ultimatum and asserted their intention to remain open. The decision was announced by Gianni de Michelis, the Italian foreign minister. The U.S. Embassy, headed by Ambassador Nathaniel Howell, maintains contact with as many Americans in Kuwait as it can reach by telephone or in person. They are advised of developments and keep the embassy informed of their own situations. More than 500 Americans have left Kuwait during the crisis despite the embassy's advice that they not risk defying Iraqi travel restrictions. Last week, when Iraq demanded Americans and Britons in Kuwait gather at hotels, the embassy conveyed the order but gave no specific advice. A handful of Americans showed up at the hotel, found no Iraqi authorities there and left the next day. Britain and the Soviet Union already have decided to scale down their diplomatic presence in Kuwait without ceasing operations. This might provide a pattern for the United States to follow as it weighs its own decision. Earlier Tuesday, the State Department said there were ``credible reports'' that Iraq has forced some Westerners to go to oil refineries and other industrial installations and that an American was seized from his home in Kuwait and detained in a hotel. Spokesman Richard Boucher said the reports had not been confirmed, nor was it known whether Americans were among those taken to the plants. The reports came from a variety of sources, including diplomats in Iraq, another U.S. official said. ``The Westerners were seen around oil refineries, but no one got close enough to pinpoint whether they included Americans,'' said the official, who spoke on condition of anonymity. Saddam has threatened to use Westerners as a human shield in the event of a U.S. military attack. More than 3,000 Americans are among more than 10,000 foreigners trapped in Iraq and Kuwait. President Bush has described the Americans as hostages and said he would hold Iraq responsible for their safety. Iraq has allowed only U.S. diplomats to depart, although eight private U.S. citizens managed Monday to reach Saudi Arabia, Boucher said. The 18 U.S. diplomats who left Iraq drove across the border to Jordan, leaving about 10 members of the U.S. Embassy staff behind, sufficient to operate, the spokesman said. The American seized at his home in Kuwait Monday night was not identified. Boucher said Iraqi soldiers had forced a man, probably a Kuwaiti, at gun-point to identify the homes of Westerners. The American was taken to the Meridien Hotel, where he was reported to be in good condition. Officials are uncertain about the whereabouts of two other groups of Americans. Thirty-five have not been seen by U.S. officials since they were taken from the Rashid hotel in Baghdad last Friday. The State Department presumes they are in another hotel, the Melia Mansour, where British citizens have been interned, but American diplomats have been prevented from checking, despite daily requests to the Iraqi foreign ministry. Twelve Americans were seized Sunday night from two hotels in Kuwait City. In all, 54 Americans are in Iraqi custody. Included are six Americans who are being held in the Melia Mansour hotel in Baghdad. ``The holding of innocent people against their will for political gain is wrong and it cannot be condoned,'' Boucher said. ``Iraq is violating the most basic norms of international behavior by its stated policy of using innocent civilians as a form of insurance against against international efforts to impose U.N.-mandated sanctions. ``The United States will continue to press Iraq by all means available to fulfill its obligations for the safety and welfare of foreign citizens in Kuwait and Iraq by allowing them to leave. The United States will not negotiate concessions in return for what is an international obligation on the part of Iraq.''

DOC.HEAD: Iraqi Authorities: Citizens of 7 European Lands Can Leave Kuwait
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Iraqi authorities told Western ambassadors that citizens of seven European Community nations will be allowed to leave Kuwait, an official of the Foreign Ministry's Persian Gulf crisis unit said early Wednesday. The offical listed the countries as Italy, Belgium, Spain, Denmark, the Netherlands, Ireland and Greece. He said the citizens would be allowed to leave Kuwait by way of Jordan and Turkey. About 120 Italians are in Kuwait. Nothing was said about foreigners in Iraq, and figures for other nationalities were not given. The official spoke to The Associated Press on the condition of anonymity after RAI, Italian state television, reported that word was conveyed to the Italian ambassador in Kuwait. He said the ambassador also was told about Dutch citizens, because Italy represents Dutch interests in Kuwait. State TV reported that Premier Giulio Andreotti, who is vacationing in northern Italy, received the news in an urgent telephone call from President Francesco Cossiga late Tuesday. ``There is wonderful news,'' Andreotti said, according to an RAI reporter who saw the premier take the call at an art exhibit. ``The Italians in Kuwait will be able to leave.'' Andreotti told a reporter he hoped the news is the first sign of an ease-up by Iraq. It was not immediately clear when any of these foreigners would actually leave the country. They were trapped when Iraq invaded Kuwait on Aug. 2. President Saddam Hussein of Iraq has said he would prevent more than 11,000 Westerners from leaving Iraq and Kuwait until the United States withdraws from the Persian Gulf and lifts the maritime quarantine of his country. Many of the foreigners already have been reported deployed at strategic military and industrial points in Iraq to deter assault.

DOC.HEAD: British, American GIs Swapping Gear in Desert _ Even Briefs
With AM-Gulf-British Pool
EDITOR'S NOTE _ The following dispatch is from pool reporters for The Associated Press, Reuters and Press Association, Britain's domestic news agency.
DOC.TEXT: British and American GIs have been swapping gear in the Saudi Arabian desert and a pair of Uncle Sam's finest briefs now adorn the wall of a Royal Air Force office at Dhahran Air Base. The new GI-issue underwear are known to the Brits here as ``shreddies.'' ``They want our gear and we want theirs,'' said RAF junior technician John Christie, 23. ``A lot of swapping goes on and we've even got some underpants from them.'' Nobody would tell British pool reporters flown to the Persian Gulf by the Ministry of Defense just how a pair of U.S. briefs found their way to the wall of RAF Squadron 29's administrative shack. But in the spirit of international cooperation, Cpl. Paul Worts, 26, commented: ``I just love the Yanks. They're all that stands between me and boredom. Watching their antics gives us all hours of endless fun.'' Weapons Technician John Christian, 31, noted ``things have picked up since the Yanks started shuttling in their troops on chartered civvy air lines. ``We reckon Delta has a better class of stewardess than United. We've become connoisseurs of the only women we get to see here. But it's strictly on a look-but-don't-touch basis.''

DOC.HEAD: British Intelligence Says Chemical Warfare Threat Not That Great

EDITOR'S NOTE _ The following dispatch is from pool reporters for The Associated Press, Reuters and Press Association, Britain's domestic news agency. The writers were Charles Miller of Press Association, Ian Bruce of the Glasgow Herald and Simon O'Dwyer Russell of The Sunday Telegraph.
DOC.TEXT: Iraqi forces in Kuwait must steal water, food and fuel to survive, British intelligence sources said Tuesday. They also said the Iraqi threat of chemical warfare is not as great as first feared. The sources, speaking on condition of anonymity, said the 120,000 Iraqi soldiers now occupying Kuwait are in far worse shape than the West first believed _ even President Saddam Hussein's elite Republican Guard. Their logistics system is a ``shambles,'' soldiers are reduced to stealing water and siphoning gasoline from civilian cars, and many troops are ``young and shaky,'' the sources said. American intelligence now paints a picture of an Iraqi army whose discipline is breaking down and whose equipment is becoming increasingly unserviceable in the rigorous desert climate, the sources said. ``There is a danger of giving too much credit to Saddam's capabilities,'' said Air Vice Marshal Sandy Wilson, commander of British forces in Saudi Arabia. He said he is confident the allied forces now in Saudi Arabia can repel an Iraqi air attack. ``The window of vulnerability which existed in the days immediately following the invasion of Kuwait has passed. We now have a very good air defense system in place, and I am sure we can fulfill our commitments,'' Wilson said. The intelligence sources said Iraq would probably have ``a fairly small chance'' of mounting either a successful chemical or conventional attack on allied forces. Asked if the Iraqis would seize the chance of attack before the arrival of U.S. tanks by sea in two weeks time, the sources said it was highly unlikely. ``If they did, we would chew them up from the air and could relatively easily shut off their already stretched supply lines,'' one source said. The intelligence sources said the threat of chemical bombardment by long-range, Soviet-made Scud missiles had been largely nullified by deployment of Saudi Patriot anti-missile missiles. Iraq possessed a very limited amount of deadly nerve gases such as Sarin and Tabun, the sources said. They said Iraq has large quantities of mustard and phosgene gas, but the effects of these would be ``severely degraded'' in the 115-to 130-degree heat in the potential battle area. At Dhahran, the main Saudi air base, parking space has become a critical problem with more than 240 fighter aircraft from three nations and scores of transport and helicopter gunships on the tarmac. A steady stream of U.S. military and chartered civilian aircraft drone in around the clock as the steady build-up continues. On average, an aircraft lands every 10 minutes. On Tuesday, U.S. C-141 Starlifter transport planes were landing at Dhahran roughly every quarter of an hour. Some were forced to sit idling on the taxiway for up to half an hour, awaiting a takeoff which would vacate a parking bay. One U.S. pilot, stepping off a Starlifter after a seven-hour flight from Madrid, said this was his fourth visit to Dhahran in four days. The Saudi pilots at Dhahran flying British-made Tornado fighters only received the aircraft weeks ago. According to Lt. Col. Yahya Zahrani, 39, commander of the Royal Saudi Air Force's 29th Squadron: ``We are now operationally fully ready, and I believe, in the longterm, Saddam will be shown that his invasion was a mistake.'' He said his unit and the British Air Force Tornadoes were now coordinating their efforts and were ``in all but name a joint force.'' Morale is high and the 1,000-strong British force gleefully point out that while they are sleeping in air-conditioned huts, most of the 60,000 American troops here are bedding down in tents. On the main airfield, U.S. air personnel have taken to sleeping at night beneath their fighter aircraft and helicopter gunships in an attempt to escape the heat. The resolve among the British pilots was best summed up by Flight Lt. Steve Pittaway, a Tornado navigator with 5 Squadron. ``I believe what Churchill said. Britain is indeed a sleeping lion, and, given a cause and a sense of purpose, such as that which we have over the invasion of Kuwait, our resolve is absolute,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Al-Azhar Condemns Saddam, Justifies Western Intervention
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The Moslem world's venerated center of theology, Al-Azhar, and Egypt's highest cleric on Tuesday condemned Iraq's invasion of Kuwait. The two also indirectly urged the execution of Iraqi President Saddam Hussein. Al-Azhar's Sheik Gad el-Haq Aly Gad-el-Haq and Egypt's Mufti Mohammed Sayed Tantawi justified the presence of ``foreign'' forces to defend Saudi Arabia, which many Moslem groups oppose. The statements by Egypt's Mufti Mohammed Sayed Tantawi, and Al-Azhar, the ancient university-mosque and seat of Islamic learning, were published in early editions of Wednesday's state dailies. Hours earlier, President Hosni Mubarak appealed to Saddam in a nationally broadcast message to withdraw his forces from Kuwait and avoid ``a destructive war ... `in the name of Islam, the religion of peace (and) ... in the name of Arab nationalism.'' The Moslem cleric's statement was run on Al-Akhbar daily's frontpage under the headline: ``The Leader of Iraq is Treacherous and Moslems Have a Duty to Kill Him.'' However, the text of the comments referred to a tyrant in general, not specifically Saddam. Accusing the Iraqi troops of committing crimes in Kuwait, al-Azhar's Gad el-Haq quoted a verse from the Koran that said: ``If the Iraqi leaders continue to the end of the destructive road, the Arab and Islamic world must react and save themselves from this tyranny and its armies must encircle the tyrant.'' Tantawi, too, referred to verses from the Koran, which Moslems believe are the direct words of God to the Prophet Mohammed, calling for the execution of a tyrant if he does not redeem. ``The Moslems and their leaders should first try and solve a dispute. If one party is tyrannical to the other and does not accept reconciliation, the Moslems and their leaders must decide to kill the tyrant, without any hesitation,'' said Tantawi in explaining the verses. ``However,'' he added, ``if the tyrannical party changes and resorts to peace, the Moslem leaders must reconcile the two parties.'' Islamic leaders have shown varied reactions to Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait. At an Arab League summit earlier this month, 12 of the states agreed to impose sanctions on Baghdad and to help defend Saudi Arabia against a possible Iraqi threat. Islam's holiest shrines, Mecca and Medina, lie in Saudi Arabia. Islamic activists in Algeria and Jordan, among others, have supported Iraq's acts and condemned the deployment of American and Western vessels and troops in the Gulf region. But both clerics justified the presence of non-Arab, non-Moslem forces.

DOC.HEAD: Army Halts Deactivation of 2nd Armored Division
DOC.TEXT: The face-off in the Middle East has brought a reprieve for the 2nd Armored Division, the tank unit that Gen. George S. Patton led to fame in World War II. The Army began deactivating the division at Fort Hood two months ago because peace seemed assured in Europe and because of looming cuts in the defense budget. But the Pentagon has called the deactivation to a halt and ordered the division's remaining soldiers, with their M1 Abrams tanks and Bradley fighting vehicles, to prepare to join Operation Desert Shield in Saudi Arabia, Fort Hood spokeswoman Liz Crossan said Monday. About 2,300 of the division's 12,000 members have pulled out since the Army began the deactivation in June, she said. ``As the situation in the Middle East develops, the Department of the Army is going to review the 2nd Armored Division and make a decision regarding any further deactivation,'' Crossan said. The division lost about 500 soldiers in June, 800 in July and 900 last week, she said. The rest were to be deactivated by September 1991. The Army hasn't decided whether the restore the unit to full force, said Army spokesman Capt. David Roth in Washington. The Pentagon says elements of the 2nd Armored Division and the 1st Cavalry Division from Fort Hood will soon join the United States' massive military response to Iraq's invasion of Kuwait. The armored division was formed in July 1940 to fight in World War II. Led by Patton, the 2nd Armored was the first allied unit to enter Belgium, helped win the Battle of the Bulge in the winter of 1944 and was the first American unit to enter Berlin on July 4. 1945. Parts of the division also fought in the Korean War and in Vietnam. Later, Elvis Presley served in the 2nd Armored. It moved to central Texas in 1946, when Fort Hood was called Camp Hood. Monday's announcement offered temporary relief to community leaders worried that the loss of 12,000 soldiers and 30,000 civilians would devastate the region's economy. Retired Gen. Robert Shoemaker, a Bell County commissioner and a board member of the community group Keep Hood Alive and Kicking Inc., said he was relieved. The group failed last week to get a court order halting the deactivation. ``All that KHAKI really wanted was for the Army to look long-range,'' Shoemaker said.

DOC.HEAD: 2 Ex-Congressmen Among Foreigners Arriving in Jordan
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.NOTE: EDs: LEADS with 16 grafs to UPDATE with figures on foreigners entering Jordan, CORRECTS that ex-congressmen stayed overnight in Amman rather than flying back to New York, ADDS quotes and background, minor editing. Pickup 11th graf pvs `Meanwhile, as...'
DOC.TEXT: Thousands of foreigners continued to pour across the border by land and air from Iraq on Tuesday, including two ex-congressmen who arrived on a flight from Baghdad. George Hansen of Idaho and Thomas Kindness of Ohio spent five days in Iraq with an interpreter on a fact-finding mission under the auspices of Hansen's Free America Foundation. Both were Republican representatives in their states. Twenty Arab-Americans with dual nationality were among the 8,419 foreigners who arrived by land and air from Iraq on Tuesday, said a Jordanian immigration official, who could not be named under standing regulations. Hansen and Kindness, who arrived with a planeload of foreigners on an Iraqi Airways flight, said they would spend the night in Amman before catching a flight Wednesday for New York. Also on the flight were CBS anchorman Dan Rather and a network crew of eight that was ordered out of Baghdad, Hansen said. Five Australian diplomatic staffers also were on the arriving flight, said airport sources who spoke on condition of anonymity. In a telephone interview, Kindness said he and Hansen were carrying back appeals to President Bush from Iraq's Moslem and Christian leaders ``to give consideration to the sanctity of the Arab peninsula, where so many holy treasures are located.'' Hansen said he and Kindness were examining U.S. policy in the Middle East but provided few details beyond that. He said they ``went out and tested the water everywhere we could, and we did it substantially alone, and I guess I can't say that it was uncomfortable being there.'' The two tried to find out about Americans who had been stranded in Baghdad after Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait but had only mixed success, Hansen told The Associated Press. ``Some of them apparently had made their way home,'' Hansen said. ``Others were still in Iraq but had joined, apparently, some of the others that were also detained there and had been farmed out as quote, guests, end quote, in the smaller villages around some of the defense installations and that type of thing.'' Hansen was a GOP congressman for seven terms. He lost election in 1984 after being convicted of filing false financial disclosure statements to Congress. In December 1979, Hansen was criticized by the State Department for visiting Iran twice on an unauthorized one-man mission to discuss American hostages held in the U.S. Embassy in Tehran. Kindness represented western Ohio for 12 years until 1986, when he made an unsuccessful bid to oust Sen. John Glenn. He became a lobbyist in Washington but ran for re-election to Congress, losing in the Republican primary in May. Kindness said their trip, arranged by the Iraqi Embassy in Washington, stemmed from conversations with ``some Arab-American friends'' who were concerned about the ``growing tension'' in the Persian Gulf. He said he left Baghdad with a better understanding of the Iraqi point of view. ``Iraq does not want to fight the United States,'' Hansen said. ``I think they understand the problem of doing such a thing. ... They don't want to make a first-strike effort.'' Meanwhile, as other foreigners, mainly Arab and Asian nationals, continued to flood into Jordan overland from Iraq, 346 Soviets and five Frenchmen caught flights for home shortly after their arrival. While the crisis sparked by Iraq's Aug. 2 seizure of Kuwait deepened, the U.S. Embassy in Amman called on the estimated 3,000 American citizens in Jordan to register with it. The State Department Monday called for the departure of all U.S. citizens without essential business. Soviet and French nationals reached the Ruweishid border post, 204 miles northeast of Amman, late Monday, according to their respective embassies. Officials said all had departed by air for home Tuesday. The Soviets had been working in Kuwaiti oilfields, and were the third Soviet group to leave since the invasion, according to a Soviet Embassy spokesman. A French Embassy spokeswoman said the five French citizens included the wife of a French diplomat in Baghdad, two other adults and two children. Iraqi President Saddam Hussein has allowed Soviets to leave freely. The Soviet Union was Saddam's chief arms supplier before Moscow agreed to cut off weapons shipments after the Kuwait invasion. France was also a major weapons supplier, but the Iraqis have interned French citizens along with other Westerners. A total of 560 French were in Iraq and Kuwait at the time of the invasion. Officials in Baghdad said Tuesday they would not be allowed to leave if France joins the U.S. in enforcing a U.N. embargo against Iraq. Jordanian border officials said Egyptians made up most of the hundreds of foreigners continuing to arrive from Iraq. About 20,000 Egyptians who had crossed into Jordan earlier were gathered at Jordan's Red Sea port of Aqaba waiting for ferries to take them home.

DOC.HEAD: Trial Opens for Record Promoter Accused of Cash and Cocaine Payoffs
DOC.TEXT: Trial began Tuesday for one of the most successful independent record promoters of the 1980s, who is accused of supplying cocaine and cash to get records played on radio stations in Texas and California. Joseph Isgro is charged under a 1960 federal law that makes such ``payola'' bribes punishable by one year in prison and a $10,000 fine. But authorities hope also to convict him of far more serious crimes. A 57-count indictment handed up in November accuses Isgro, 43, of Glendale, of racketeering, obstructing justice, tax fraud, mail fraud, conspiring to distribute cocaine and other charges. The maximum sentence is 200 years in prison and $1.47 million in fines. Also on trial are Raymond Anderson, a former Columbia Records executive accused of accepting kickbacks from Isgro, and Jeffrey Monka, accused of setting up a sham company to launder Isgro's payola payments. Anderson faces up to 20 years in prison and $13,000 in fines, Monka 23 years and $1.35 million. Isgro's company grossed as much as $10 million a year during the 1980s, employing up to 30 people in lavish offices on Sunset Boulevard as it promoted records for Columbia, Warner Brothers, RCA, Polygram and other labels. As jury selection began Tuesday, Isgro's lawyer, Donald Re, maintained his client was a legitimate businessman. ``The government's case really depends upon the testimony of about four or five witnesses,'' Re told reporters outside court. ``All of them are informants, all of them are bought and paid for by the government,'' he said. ``I don't think it's the kind of case a jury will buy.'' One of those witnesses is Isgro's bodyguard, David Michael Smith. Court documents say Smith has told investigators he saw Isgro give cash to Joseph Armone, a convicted heroin dealer identified by federal authorities as a high-ranking member of New York's Gambino crime family. Two Isgro associates, Ralph Tashjian and William Craig, already have been convicted of giving payola to radio station directors for favorable play of their clients' songs.

DOC.HEAD: Cat Recuperating After 37 Days in Vending Machine
DOC.TEXT: A cat locked for more than a month in an otherwise empty vending machine appears healthy and is up to her ``old loving tricks,'' the owner said. Shadow, a $300 blue-point Himalayan, was found in the machine last week, after 37 days without food or water. She lost about three pounds during the ordeal but is regaining it rapidly, her owner, Daresa Hooper, said Monday. Shadow spent the night in an animal hospital before returning to her home here, said Mrs. Hooper. ``She's getting better and better every day,'' Mrs. Hooper said. ``She's got her muscle control back, and she didn't have any brain damage, thank God. She remembers all of us, and she's back to her old loving tricks.'' Shadow's ordeal began July 9, when Mrs. Hooper sold six vending machines to J.R. Hilton, who owns a vending business in Chesapeake, on the Virginia coast about 30 miles south of here. The cat apparently got inside the machine while it was being worked on, Mrs. Hooper said. Mrs. Hooper, her husband, James, and their two children searched in vain for the pet, but eventually lost hope and got two other cats. On Aug. 14, Hilton opened one of the machines. ``When I opened it up, there were two big, blue eyes looking at me,'' he said. ``After it realized what was going on, it let out three big yowls like a cat in distress.'' ``The first day home, she had this worried look on her face like she couldn't understand why we didn't come get her,'' Mrs. Hooper said. ``I sat down and cried with her and told her I was sorry. I think she understood.''

DOC.HEAD: Senator Terry Sanford Calls for Reduction in Gulf Forces
DOC.TEXT: Sen. Terry Sanford, D-N.C., called Tuesday for a gradual reduction in U.S. forces in the Middle East, saying the show of force has accomplished its goal of stifling Iraqi aggression. ``We have accomplished our mission of stopping Iraq's drive to take over Saudi Arabia and the rest of the Middle East,'' Sanford said in a news release. ``We should begin to reduce our forces in Saudi Arabia, ever so slowly, and look to a more multinational force to keep the peace.'' The call by Sanford, who has a liberal voting record, was the most outspoken criticism of the U.S. buildup so far from Capitol Hill. Sanford said the United States must put the lives of its soldiers and the interests of Americans stranded in the Middle East ahead of worries about Iraq's invasion of Kuwait and its oil reserves. ``Iraq did not violate U.S. rights particularly, and it is not up to us to rectify their wrongdoing,'' he said. ``Except that we are part of the United Nations, we have no interest in Kuwait worth the life of a single serviceman. Certainly I would not risk a single life to restore the Kuwaiti royal family to the throne.'' Sanford said President Bush and his advisers may have exposed Americans in the Middle East to greater danger ``when they exhibited all that bluster about forcing Iraq to retreat from Kuwait.'' ``Seizing foreign nationals is about the only defense Saddam (Hussein, Iraq's leader) has to discourage invasion, which the U.S. buildup gives him reason to fear,'' Sanford said. The matter is best left to the United Nations and continued multinational efforts to embargo Iraqi trade, he said. Even the embargo should be tempered to avoid hampering food shipments, Sanford said. ``This is not in keeping with the humane practices of civilized societies,'' he said. ``Cutting off the income Iraq would receive from the sale of oil will be quite adequate to resolve the matter.''

DOC.HEAD: Report Shows Sharp Rise in Food Stamp Recipients
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 4th graf to include overall figure for number of food stamp recipients.
DOC.TEXT: A government report showing a sharp rise in the number of food stamp recipients reveals a lot more poor people in the United States than many wish to admit, the chairman of a congressional committee on hunger said Tuesday. ``It shows you to a certain extent the sleeping giant that is out there,'' said Rep. Tony Hall, D-Ohio, in a statement released by his office following published reports about an Agriculture Department study on food stamps. He said the findings in the report demonstrate how even a slight downturn in the economy can be too much for some people, throwing them onto public assistance rolls. The report, a summary of which was furnished by the Agriculture Department on Tuesday, said the number of people using food stamps rose by more than 1 million between the second quarter of fiscal 1989 and the second quarter of this fiscal year, pushing the overall figure to just over 20 million. The rise extended to 44 states and the District of Columbia, varying in size and timing from state to state. Nearly half the total increase was attributable to a rise in recipients in Texas, California and Florida, the report said. Agriculture Department investigators found no consensus about the causes of the increases. They said the increases are so recent that much of the data traditionally used to analyze food stamp trends are not available. However, the study offers several possible reasons for the increases, including greater unemployment, more working poor, higher food prices, changes in the distribution of income, more female heads of household, changes in the immigration laws giving thousands of aliens legal status and making them eligible for food stamps and improved accessibility and outreach. ``Food stamps are an entitlement,'' said Hall's statement. ``It doesn't make any sense to create an entitlement program and then keep it a secret. At some time everyone is going to have to come to grips with the fact that we have this many poor people.'' Further studies will be done to improve the food stamp program, said a committee staff member. Also, hearings on poverty in America will be held soon by the House Select Committee on Hunger, which Hall chairs. The House earlier this month approved a farm bill that would expand access to the food assistance program. The House approved $18.1 billion for fiscal 1991. The Senate has yet to act. The Agriculture Department study was undertaken at the request of the Senate Appropriations Committee, which was concerned about the recent rise in recipients. The Bush administration, anticipating 18.1 million food stamp recipients this year, requested $13.3 billion for fiscal 1990. Congress approved $14.8 billion and later provided another $1.2 billion when the initial amount proved to be too low.

DOC.HEAD: West African Troops to Sail for Liberia to Try for Cease-Fire
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with six grafs to UPDATE that task force ships still in Freetown harbor and departure for Liberia delayed. Pickup 4th graf pvs, `Guinean soldiers...'
DOC.TEXT: West African soldiers loaded their equipment on board six ships Tuesday as they prepared to set sail for Liberia to halt the bloody civil war there. Their orders were to stand by in the port of beleaguered Monrovia and avoid fighting during truce negotiations. Hours after the troops were scheduled to leave, their ships remained in the harbor of Freetown. Some soldiers were seen sleeping on the pavement while others were attending a disco in the port authority area. Hundreds of soldiers from Gambia, Ghana, Nigeria and Sierra Leone were expected to leave for Liberia on Wednesday. Late Tuesday, they were still loading armored cars, tanks and other military equipment on board their vessels. The ships began loading after Liberian rebel leader Charles Taylor refused to go to a meeting on Tuesday to discuss a cease-fire with Gambian President Sir Dawda Jawara. Taylor had agreed on Monday to attend the meeting. Instead, he sent three envoys to meet with Jawara, chairman of the Economic Community of West African States; task force commander Lt. Gen. Arnold Quainoo of Ghana; and West African foreign ministers. Guinean soldiers were traveling overland across their border with Liberia to join the task force, according to a West African Community statement issued in the Gambian capital, Banjul. This would take the Guineans through hostile territory held by rebels led by Taylor. He has threatened to attack any foreign troops that intervene in the 8-month-old conflict in the West African nation of about 2.5 million people. African leaders previously told their soldiers they must fight, if necessary, to force a cease-fire in the three-sided conflict. The rebels are out to oust the government of President Samuel Doe, which they branded as corrupt. But a rebel faction led by Prince Johnson broke with Taylor. Rebels now are fighting each other as well as Doe's forces. The Banjul statement said the task force has orders to remain on standby in the Liberian capital's port and avoid all operations while mediation efforts to bring about a truce go on. West African leaders decided Aug. 6 to intervene in the war. They said it was no longer an internal conflict because thousands of their nationals were trapped in Monrovia and because of the burden on neighboring states of about 400,000 Liberian refugees from the fighting. Guinea already has hundreds of troops stationed on its border after Taylor's rebels invaded to kill Liberian refugees of the Mandingo tribe. Mandingos are accused of supporting government soldiers. On Monday, Doe's soldiers and the rival rebel faction under Johnson, which controls most of Monrovia, announced a truce. Johnson has pledged to hold Monrovia's port for the arrival of the African force, which Doe also has welcomed. Fighters from both Doe and Johnson forces told a diplomat in Monrovia on Monday they were ready to join forces to resist any attack by Taylor's men. Taylor's forces number about 10,000, the largest army in Liberia, but are mainly ill-trained peasant recruits and boys. Doe's forces for weeks have held them off four miles east of Doe's clifftop presidential mansion. The rebels invaded Liberia on Dec. 24 invasion from Ivory Coast, In February, the rebels split into rival factions under Taylor and Johnson. The capital has been under siege since the end of June. Many of the 400,000 residents have fled or were evacuated. Water supplies, electricity and telephone communications were cut about eight weeks ago. Monrovia has been without fresh food supplies for weeks. Decomposing bodies lie in the streets. No hospitals are operating.

DOC.HEAD: Britain's Thatcher Vows Never to Negotiate on Hostages
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher pledged on Tuesday never to negotiate for the release of hostages held by Iraq, as government sources confirmed that some Britons have been moved to military sites. She denounced President Saddam Hussein of Iraq for using innocent Britons and other Westerners as ``human shields,'' saying this practice ``totally flouted'' fundamental human rights. She emphasized British rejection of the Iraqi order that all embassies in Kuwait be closed by Friday and said the British Embassy will remain open. ``Solidarity is important here. We are fully entitled to keep our embassy there . . . our people are there and they have a right to expect the full amount of protection that we can possibly give them,'' she said. Mrs. Thatcher promised that the hostage-taking would not deter Britain from helping to liberate Kuwait and defend Persian Gulf states from further Iraqi aggression action. She announced the government was considering sending additional forces and aircraft to the region. Hours later, senior government sources disclosed for the first time that some of the 137 Britons rounded up in Kuwait by the Iraqis had been taken to military sites. ``There are some who are in civilian installations but we have found out today (Tuesday) that there are others at military installations,'' said one government source, speaking on condition he was not identified. The Foreign Office said Tuesday night the Iraqi military took 10 Britons and one American from homes in Kuwait City to a civilian establishment in the city where they were ``safe and well.'' It was the first report of Britons being rounded up from homes. The Foreign Office said it couldn't confirm a U.S. State Department report that they were taken at gunpoint. It said the whereabouts were known of 97 of the 137 Britons rounded up in Kuwait. The high-level government sources said 76 were at civilian installations but refused to say if the other 21 were held at military sites. They did not disclose the location of the military sites. For the first time, Mrs. Thatcher referred to the Britons being held by Iraq as hostages. ``As President Bush pointed out . . . Saddam Hussein is trying in his tactics to hide behind Western women and children and use them as human shields and use them as part of his negotiations,'' she told a news conference. ``We will never bargain.'' She accused the International Committee of the Red Cross of failing to take action to protect foreign nationals in Kuwait and Iraq. She said it was contacted Aug. 8 and 10, but she was ``deeply disappointed'' it did nothing. Foreign Office Minister William Waldegrave met Cornelio Sommaruga, Swiss president of the ICRC, in Geneva Tuesday and asked the organization to try to help Britons and other foreigners in Kuwait and Iraq, the Foreign Office said. It said Waldegrave stressed it was clear Iraq breached the 4th Geneva Convention which protects civilians. Waldegrave said Sommaruga shared British government ``anger and frustration'' and that the ICRC was doing its best to gain access to the hostages. An ICRC spokesman said the meeting was one of a series of contacts the ICRC had held with several countries since Iraq invaded Kuwait on Aug. 2. Mrs. Thatcher asked other nations to contribute military forces or funds to show solidarity with the international effort to deter Iraq and enforce the U.N. embargo against it. She said she and President Bush had said from the beginning ``we do not rule out military force'' but the key was making the economic sanctions effective to bring pressure on Iraq. She said she supported a further U.N. resolution following the sanctions on Iraq voted by the United Nations Security Council, adding: ``That resolution must have teeth, if it's to be effective.''

DOC.HEAD: Jurors Begin Deliberations in Contra Supply Case
INSERTS 1 graf after 5th graf pvs, `Attorneys for...,' to UPDATE with jury ending deliberations for the day.
DOC.TEXT: Jurors in a trial detailing covert Contra supply operations began deliberating Tuesday whether to compensate a crewmember of a plane shot down in Nicaragua and the co-pilot's survivors. After five weeks of testimony, U.S. District Judge C. Clyde Atkins instructed the jury, cautioning them against a verdict based on sympathy or public opinion. Brian Strange, attorney for plaintiff Eugene Hasenfus, told the jury that the cargo handler and his wife, Sally, should at least be reimbursed for expenses connected to his legal battle in Nicaragua, where Hasenfus was captured and held for three months. ``They were told their families would be taken care of and then the defense comes before you and says, ``Not us,' '' said Strange. Attorneys for a Miami-based cargo carrier, Southern Air Transport, and several other defendants in the lawsuit say Hasenfus and co-pilot Wallace ``Buzz'' Sawyer Jr., who died in the crash, had no formal contract and knew the risks of the secret flight. The jury recessed for the day after 6{ hours, and was to resume deliberations Wednesday. Atkins threw out a major portion of the claims last week. All that's left for the jury to decide is whether Hasenfus is due back pay and if Sawyer's family can collect death benefits from retired Air Force Gen. Richard Secord and Southern Air. On Friday, Atkins ruled that jurors cannot consider damages for mental stress suffered by Hasenfus after the plane was shot down by Nicaraguan troops in October 1986. The Marinette, Wis., man was the sole survivor of the crash. The judge also removed claims seeking punitive damages and allegations the aircraft was unsafe. Thomas Spencer, an attorney for Secord, said his client did not have the authority to make a contract with Hasenfus or Sawyer, of Magnolia, Ark. ``My client didn't contribute to the death of Buzz Sawyer or the harm to Gene Hasenfus,'' said Spencer. ``The White House called him and asked to help with the re-supply operation.'' Secord helped former National Security Council aide Oliver North organize the Contra supply network. He was placed on two years' probation after pleading guilty to lying to Congress about his role in the Iran-Contra affair.

DOC.HEAD: Farmers Demonstrate Against Imported Agricultural Products
DOC.TEXT: Farmers opposed to imports of agricultural products shouted insults and hurled bottles at a Cabinet member, news reports said Tuesday. Kang Bo-seong, minister of agriculture, forestry and fisheries, was attending a rally Monday when he was heckled by thousands of slogan-chanting farmers, the newspaper Dong-A Ilbo said. About 15,000 farmers took part in the rally in Chonan in central South Korea, where Kang was to have explained the government's position about multinational trade negotiations called the Uruguay Round, it said. Farmers threw bottles and tried to storm the podium when Kang arrived, forcing him to leave after making a short speech, the newspaper said. Kang escaped unhurt. The farmers demanded that the government stop imports of agricultural products and reject the Uruguay Round negotiations, which are sponsored by the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade to remove trade restrictions. Farmers have staged a series of anti-government protests, contending that their livelihood has been damaged by imported products. About 50 farmers have killed themselves in protests over the government's agricultural policy.

DOC.HEAD: Producer: No `Miss Saigon' Unless Attitudes Change
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 4th graf, `Mackintosh, however...,' to ADD explanation for $600,000 loss producer is willing to incur.
DOC.TEXT: The producer of the hit London musical ``Miss Saigon'' said Tuesday he would take a $600,000 loss rather than bring the show to Broadway amid controversy over his casting of a white man to play a Eurasian pimp. But Cameron Mackintosh left the door open for a rapprochement that could bring the show _ and its $25 million in advance ticket sales _ to Broadway in April 1991. The show initially was supposed to begin previews a month earlier. ``I cannot in good conscience reschedule the production in the absence of a positive working environment and an understanding ... that artistic freedom of choice cannot be compromised,'' Mackintosh said in a three-page statement released in New York. Mackintosh, however, said he was willing to work out differences with Actors' Equity and that he had sent the union a letter outlining the problems he felt must be overcome for a U.S. production. The $600,000 loss is expenses the producer already incurred preparing to bring the show here. Equity's approval of Jonathan Pryce to play the role of the Eurasian was insufficient evidence that the union had a change of heart, he said. ``Their decision was made solely on the technical basis of Mr. Pryce's acknowledged star status. As I have repeatedly stated, it is also essential that the profoundly unpleasant atmosphere currently surrounding the production be dispelled,'' Mackintosh said. Helene Feldman, a spokeswoman for Equity, said the union would have no comment until Wednesday. Equity executive secretary Alan Eisenberg was in a meeting Tuesday afternoon and unavailable to comment. Mackintosh had canceled the $10 million production on Aug. 8 after Actors Equity, which has veto power over a foreign actor's appearance in the United States, voted against letting Pryce bring his award-winning role to Broadway. Pryce won the Olivier Award, the London equivalent of the Tony, for his portrayal of the brothel owner in the play. The New York production had been planned as the most expensive show in Broadway history; its $25 million in advance ticket sales is a record. Equity, after the vote against Pryce, said it could not ``appear to condone the casting of a Caucasian in the role of a Eurasian.'' But in a special meeting of its 70-member executive council Thursday, Equity reversed field and approved Pryce. The council, which represents its 37,500 members, was swayed by Mackintosh's demonstration of good intent and his promise to seek Asian actors for Broadway roles, said Eisenberg. Pryce, who won a 1977 Tony for his work in ``Comedians,'' also was determined to be a ``star'' during the second Equity meeting, Eisenberg said. Stars from other countries usually receive automatic Equity approval. Asian-American groups had urged Equity to stand firm against Pryce, citing the dearth of good roles for minority actors. ``Miss Saigon'' has a cast of 50, including 34 roles for minority actors. The Pryce role is the only one in the cast that has been announced. The musical is a love story about an American soldier in Vietnam during the final days of the war in 1975.

DOC.HEAD: Europe Coordinates Military Response to Iraq
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Western European nations agreed Tuesday to increase pressure on Iraq with a coordinated military response and urged the Security Council to give Persian Gulf forces more power to help enforce U.N. sanctions on Iraq. The decision by foreign and defense ministers of the nine-member Western European Union, or WEU, signaled a unified, tougher European posture toward Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait. It was followed by a European Community decision to refuse Iraqi orders to close embassies in Kuwait and a veiled threat that Iraqi embassies in Europe could also be shut. The WEU plan was a green light for Belgium, the Netherlands and Italy to send ships already heading through the Mediterranean to the crisis area. Along with several other nations, they were awaiting a decision by the ministers before committing naval forces to the region. French Defense Minister Jean-Pierre Chevenement said Spain and Greece also announced they would send ships. All warships will remain under their national commands. Coordination will extend to zones of operation, task sharing, logistical support and exchanges of information, according to a final communique. ``Our exceptional meeting responds itself to a situation which is exceptional in its gravity and its implications,'' Foreign Minister Roland Dumas of France said. ``A small country surely, but a sovereign independent country, would find itself wiped off the map if international reaction had not been so vigorous and unanimous.'' Europe has until now reacted with varied responses, timid in comparison with the United States. Britain and France, both with special interests in the Arab world, are currently the only WEU members with forces now in the gulf region. The European fleets are composed mainly of minesweepers, corvettes, frigates and destroyers. France sent an aircraft carrier and guided missile cruiser in an eight-ship fleet totaling 3,800 sailors. West Germany said it would move to change its constitution to allow the use of military forces outside the European theater, British Foreign Secretary Douglas Hurd announced. But officials added this was likely a long process, and not possible before joint German elections this year. Only Portugal expressed reserves about joining in the multinational military effort, Dumas said. WEU Secretary-General Willem van Eekelen said members agreed in principle to the use of force to respect the U.N. embargo on Iraq. The ministers asked the U.N. Security Council to take ``needed supplementary measures for the embargo to be effectively in place.'' A U.S. draft resolution now before the Council calls for international military action to back up the embargo. The WEU warned of ``serious consequences'' should harm come to foreign nationals trapped in Iraq and Kuwait. The WEU was created in 1954 and is the only wholly European forum for security and defense. Its members _ France, Britain, West Germany, Italy, Belgium, the Netherlands, Spain, Portugal and Luxembourg _ all belong to the 12-nation European Community. The WEU meeting was the first major European gathering to address the Iraqi invasion. It was followed by a working lunch of EC foreign ministers to discuss the plight of trapped Westerners and other issues. Italian Foreign Minister Gianni de Michelis said the EC decided to defy an order by Iraqi President Saddam Hussein to close embassies by Friday ``in order to ensure the protection of our nationals.'' He said diplomats were instructed not to forcefully resist closing of the missions. De Michelis said after the EC meeting that any attempt to harm Westerners would be considered ``the most serious kind of offensive act against the Community.'' Italy is current EC president. President Francois Mitterrand of France, which called for the two meetings, said trapped Westerners were ``being held hostage,'' a term the EC declined to use. It was the first time France referred to its 560 nationals in Iraq and Kuwait as hostages.

DOC.HEAD: Hardees Pulls Cafeteria Ad for Roy Rogers
DOC.TEXT: Roy Rogers restaurants has again killed the most popular television ad it's ever run, after the spot drew criticism last week from the same group that protested it the first time around. The advertisement features women serving plates of food in a school cafeteria. The spot, with ``See You in September'' in the background, encouraged schoolchildren to come eat at Roy Rogers before they're faced with nine months of cafeteria food. The ad first appeared in the summer of 1988 and became ``one of the highest awareness-level commercials'' in the fast food industry, said John Merritt, vice president for public relations at Hardee's Food Systems, the new owner of Roy Rogers. But Marriott Business and Food Services Management, which owned Roy Rogers at the time, also provides food to school systems, airlines, universities and other customers. ``The Institutional Food Workers of America came unglued and jumped on Marriott with both feet,'' Merritt said. The cafeteria ad was revived last week by Roy Rogers' marketing department in Rockville, Md. But the spot has been axed yet again. ``The same people predictably came unglued,'' Merritt said. He said Hardee's is not in the cafeteria business, but decided that the ``See You in September'' ad reflected poorly on the entire food service business. ``(It's) just not becoming to us to be poking fun at them,'' he said. ``You need to put the shoe on the other foot.'' Hardees, which bought Roy Rogers from Marriott in January for $365 million, plans to transform the 648 Roy Rogers restaurants into Hardee's on a market-by-market basis, with all of them converted by summer of 1991.

A Southwest Airlines passenger jetliner made an unscheduled landing at Albuquerque International Airport after one of its two engines was shut down in flight, officials said. The 737 with 124 passengers aboard landed without incident at about 8:30 p.m. Monday, said Ann Genett-Schrader, Southwest Airlines' manager of public relations in Dallas. ``There was a compressor problem with the (right) engine and it was really very minor,'' she said Tuesday. The company's flight 362 originated in Lubbock, Texas, and stopped in Albuquerque about 7:20 p.m., officials said. The airplane took off from Albuquerque at 7:40 p.m. bound for Los Angeles. But when the compressor problem occurred, the pilot shut down the engine and returned the craft to Albuquerque, Ms. Genett-Schrader said. The passengers continued to their destination on another flight.

DOC.HEAD: Resort Claims Comic Has Problem with Drugs, Alcohol
DOC.TEXT: Caesars Palace attorneys say they will present evidence that comedian Rodney Dangerfield has ``severe problems with cocaine, marijuana and alcohol abuse'' when his lawsuit against the resort goes to trial. An attorney for Dangerfield called the allegations ``a joke.'' The civil trial is scheduled to begin Monday in U.S. District Court here. Dangerfield and his Paperclip Productions Inc. of New York are seeking $225,000 in damages from Caesars. The resort has filed a breach of contract countersuit against its former headliner for $100,000 plus punitive damages. Dangerfield sued the resort because of a March 16, 1988 incident in which he said he suffered eye damage after being scalded by a burst of steam when entering a steam room behind the hotel's showroom. In documents filed with the court Monday, the resort's attorney, Jill R. Cohen, wrote that the steam didn't cause Dangerfield's eye problems. The brief blames Dangerfield's lifestyle, and his use of a certain type of eyedrops despite warnings to the contrary. The document said one witness will testify that at a party after the alleged incident, Dangerfield, 64, was ``so intoxicated from drugs and alcohol that he literally passed out face first in a plate of food.'' ``There will be substantial evidence that Mr. Dangerfield has severe problems with cocaine, marijuana and alcohol abuse, that he swills vodka by the tumblerful, smokes marijuana from morning to night and is a regular user of cocaine,'' the trial document stated. ``Medical opinion testimony will demonstrate that such abuses significantly contribute to Mr. Dangerfield's eye conditions,'' the document said. Dangerfield's attorney, Barry Langberg, disputed the allegations. ``Rodney has denied them and I have never seen him use drugs,'' Landberg said Tuesday. ``We've heard the allegations of drug use and malingering before and they are totally contrary to Rodney's performance record. ``Mr. Dangerfield has an excellent history of keeping his engagements. The only recent performances he has missed have been the ones at Caesars because their negligence caused his eye injuries and at Bally's (in Las Vegas) because he wouldn't cross the picket lines during the musicians strike.'' Dangerfield filed the lawsuit in 1988, claiming his eyes were injured so severely that he had to cancel five performances at Caesars. Dangerfield, who is paid $45,000 per show, according to court documents, was paid $135,000 for performing three times during the week-long run. The trial brief contends Dangerfield isn't entitled to be paid for performances he says he missed because of the injury. The Ceasars' brief alleged he gambled at a competing hotel one night when he missed a performance. On another night, the document says, he attended a boxing match at Caesars, sitting in a front row seat in public view while the resort had to announce he could not perform because of an injury.

DOC.HEAD: Dolphin Dies at Disney `Seas' Pavilion
DOC.TEXT: A 12-year-old female dolphin died after developing breathing problems in an exhibition tank at the Living Seas pavilion at Walt Disney World, a Disney spokesman said Tuesday. A necropsy found the dolphin had ``a pre-existing lung condition that could have been exacerbated by normal play in the underwater tank,'' said Disney's John Dreyer. The dolphin, one of three in the glassed-in tank with other marine mammals, began having problems late Monday and a veterinarian was called, Dreyer said. The 8-foot-long, 330-pound dolphin died early Tuesday. The dolphins have been at the pavilion at Epcot Center since it opened in 1986. They aren't trained to perform, but live in a tank simulating their natural habitat. The necropsy was conducted by veterinarian Bob Stevens, who will file a report on his findings to the National Marine Fisheries Service, Dreyer said.
