DOC.HEAD: Financial Markets Hit Again Over Seething Gulf Situation
DOC.TEXT: Stocks plunged and oil prices surged to new highs this morning in markets preoccupied with the rapid military escalation in the Persian Gulf crisis. On Wall Street, the Dow Jones industrial average tumbled from the opening bell and was down about 77 points to the 2,580 level by late morning. Broader indicators of stock prices also dropped. Petroleum traders said the energy market was especially susceptible to war rumors from the Middle East, where the United States and Iraq seemed to be moving toward a hostile confrontation over Iraq's seizure of Kuwait Aug. 2. On the New York Mercantile Exchange, the price of unleaded gasoline shot up to $1.06 per gallon for September delivery, 4{ cents higher than a record set on Monday. The September contract price of benchmark light sweet crude oil rose 14 cents per 42-gallon barrel to $28.70 by midmorning today after dipping 7 cents on Monday. Contracts for later months all rose, suggesting that traders believe a long siege in the Persian Gulf will cause major supply problems.

DOC.HEAD: Stock Plunge Weighs on Grain and Soybean Futures
DOC.TEXT: Grain and soybean futures prices opened lower this morning on the Chicago Board of Trade. ``The stock market opened with a huge plunge, signaling possibly the onset of a recession, which the grains view negatively,'' said Joel Karlin, an analyst with Research Department Inc. in Chicago. But even before the stocks started to plunge, the Board of Trade markets were under pressure. Follow-through selling from Monday's weak close undercut the opening of soybean trading. And despite some concern about an early frost and too much rain in the Midwest, the weekly USDA report late Monday showed the corn and soybean crops both doing fairly well, said Karlin. Analysts say the lack of export demand also is weighing on the markets, particularly wheat. In early trading, wheat futures prices were 1} cents lower to { cent higher with the September contract at $2.79{ a bushel; corn was \ cent to } cent lower with September at $2.52 a bushel; oats were unchanged to { cent lower with September at $1.16 a bushel; and soybeans were unchanged to 2\ cents lower with August at $6.08{ a bushel. Livestock and meat futures were mostly lower on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange. Live cattle futures were .37 cent to .60 cent lower with the October contract at 76.82 cents a pound; feeder cattle were .45 cent lower to .05 cent higher with August at 89.30 cents a pound; live hogs were .32 cent to .82 cent lower with October at 49.25 cents a pound; and frozen pork bellies were 1.45 cent to the limit 2 cents lower with August at 47.72 cents a pound. Cattle futures on Monday were mostly lower while the pork complex was mostly higher.

DOC.HEAD: Tender Offer for Kansas Gas Extended
DOC.TEXT: Kansas City Power & Light Co. said Tuesday it had extended its $857 million tender offer for Kansas Gas and Electric Co. stock until Sept. 14, saying that about 43 percent of KG&E shares had been tendered. Kansas City Power said that about 13.7 million of KG&E's 31.7 million outstanding shares had been tendered as of the previous deadline of midnight Monday. KG&E, based in Wichita, opposes the tender offer, calling it illegal and inadequate. The company has declined to call a special shareholders' meeting requested by Kansas City Power. The bid is the first hostile takeover attempt in the electric utility industry, and some industry analysts believe it could have implications for other utilities. Kansas City Power is seeking 90 percent of the KG&E stock for $27 a share. The offer began July 23 and represented a 37 percent premium over the market price of KG&E stock on the last trading day before the offer. ``This confirms the strength of our offer. ... There are just a lot of people saying this makes sense. It's just a stronger offer, and people are saying it's a strong offer,'' Kansas City Power spokesman Turner White said. Lyle Koerper, a KG&E spokesman, said his company was not surprised by the extension of the tender offer or the number of shares tendered. ``Last week we said we would review all options to KCPL's unprecedented action, including remaining independent,'' he said. KG&E said last week it had asked its financial adviser to search out alternatives to the takeover bid. Industry experts have speculated that other utilities in the region might want to acquire the Wichita company under terms more favorable to KG&E management and stockholders. Whatever the outcome of the tender offer, some business experts say, KCPL still has an uphill struggle to win regulatory approval for a takeover of KG&E.

DOC.HEAD: Trump Bailout Plan Approved By New Jersey Casino Commission
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 8 grafs to UPDATE with quote from commission chairwoman, recast. Picks up 6th graf, `The loan...'. A version moved on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: The state casino board today approved a financial bailout plan for developer Donald Trump, staving off what his lawyers said last week could have been the collapse of his empire. In a uninimous vote, the Casino Control Commission granted Trump permission to use his three Atlantic City gaming halls as collateral for a $65 million bank loan that is the center of the bailout. Trump attended the half-hour meeting, staring straight ahead, unsmiling and with his lips pursed, even as the plan was approved. ``This is a big hurdle and I'm happy,'' Trump told a throng of reporters and camera crews. ``Maybe you can focus on someone else now.'' During hearings last week, Trump's attorneys told the commission that rejection of the plan, or even a delay of more than a week or so, could topple the first domino in the celebrity developer's casino, airline and real estate empire. Although the vote to approve was 5-0, commissioner W. David Waters said he was concerned because the commission had not looked into greater detail at Trump's casino debt. Acting Commission Chairwoman Valerie Armstrong said Trump would have to return sometime in October for a hearing on the overall financial stability of his casinos and other holdings. ``I do not view this restructuring as the total solution to the problem,'' Armstrong said. ``We must hold a full financial stability hearing as soon as possible.'' The loan allowed Trump to make an overdue $43 million bond payment in June on the Trump Castle casino. Earlier, the state Division of Gaming Enforcement had reluctantly endorsed the plan but criticized the debt-heavy state of Trump's casinos. The division added provisos to the plan requiring that Trump return three weeks from now with details of how he plans to make a $47 million bond payment due Nov. 15 on his new Taj Mahal Casino Resort. Trump is expected to return with a proposal to swap some of his $3.2 billion in debt for equity, sell assets _ perhaps the poorly performing Trump Shuttle airline _ or negotiate reduced or deferred interest rates. Ed Tracy, president of Trump's three casinos and one non-casino hotel here, said the commission's decision to postpone ruling on the matter until today did not cause problems with the banks. Claridge Casino Hotel president Roger Wagner said Monday that Trump's stated desire to keep all three casinos would prove difficult. ``I think he would like to do that,'' Wagner said. ``But maybe that is a positioning he has to do to keep the value up.'' Wagner, who stayed at the Claridge after an April offer to become president at Trump Castle, said there might not be much of a market for the casinos because of a stagnant gaming market overall. He said the April 2 opening of the Trump Taj Mahal Casino Resort hamstrung Trump by further taxing his already strained resources.

DOC.HEAD: Circle K Closing 201 Stores
DOC.TEXT: Circle K Corp. has begun closing 201 stores targeted as unprofitable and will complete the job by the end of the month, company spokesman Ray Cox said. More closings are possible after the effects of the step are analyzed, he said Monday. About 1,600 employees in 21 states will be affected, but 95 percent of them will be moved to other stores, Cox said. Most of the stores are concentrated in Texas, California, Georgia and Florida. He would not say how much the closings were expected to save, or how much it would cost to terminate the leases. Analysts said they doubted that 200 closings would suffice to pull the company from the protection of U.S. Bankruptcy Court, where it filed for Chapter 11 protection from creditors May 15. The company determined which stores to close mainly by gross sales and profitability figures, Cox said. But other factors, including traffic counts and neighborhood deterioration, also were taken into account. ``They're probably closing all the leases they can get out of easily,'' said Dennis Telzrow, an analyst with Eppler, Guerin & Turner in Dallas. Circle K's latest move follows the recent termination of 400 leases on stores that had been shut down. Those leases were estimated to cost the company $1 million to $1.5 million a month. The company also had deals to sell 375 stores in Hawaii and the Pacific Northwest before its Chapter 11 filing. The deals have been delayed pending court approval. Circle K operates about 4,500 convenience stores in 32 states and has an additional 1,300 licensed or joint-venture stores in 14 foreign countries. Other states where stores will be closed include Arizona, Louisiana, Oklahoma, Colorado, Mississippi, Alabama, New Mexico, North Carolina, Oregon, Washington, Utah, Idaho, Tennessee, Kentucky, Missouri, Montana and South Carolina.

For Release Sunday, Aug. 26, and thereafter
DOC.HEAD: Exports Booming Despite Sanctions, Hard Times
LaserGraphic planned
DOC.TEXT: China's economy is sluggish, verging on recession, but exports are booming. Foreign investment has lagged since the brutal crackdown on dissent more than a year ago. Businessmen still worry about political instability and are put off by numerous roadblocks to profitable joint ventures. ``Trade is the bright spot in the Chinese economy,'' a Western diplomat said, on condition of anonymity. ``If the current trend keeps up, this year's may be the biggest trade surplus in China's history.'' Total trade rose 8.6 percent in 1989 to $111.5 billion. From January through June this year, the $25.65 billion in exports exceeded imports by $2.56 billion. Economists predict a $10 billion surplus for 1990, nearly double the record 1982 surplus of $5.63 billion. More industries produce goods for export because economic problems have shrunk domestic markets. Economists say China also is pushing exports in order to repay foreign loans, many of which are due in 1992. Led by its freewheeling southern coastal provinces, China is exporting more to the United States than ever before, despite international censure of the harsh action against pro-democracy demonstrators in June 1989. Exports to the United States rose 43 percent last year to $11.99 billion, according to U.S. Commerce Department figures. President Bush's decision in May of this year to continue most-favored-nation status eliminated a major threat to the growing trade. Japan has not cashed in on the boom, even though it has moved faster than other industrialized nations to ease sanctions imposed on Beijing after the army assault on Tiananmen Square. China's exports to Japan fell 3.5 percent to $3.43 billion in the first half of 1990 and imports from Japan plunged 39.9 percent to $3.22 billion. Total trade between the two fell 5 percent in 1989 from the previous year. ``Japanese businessmen were discouraged by Tiananmen,'' said Nobuo Maruyama, senior economist at the Institute of Developing Economies in Tokyo. After more than a decade of investing in China and waiting, he said, the Japanese are turning to other Asian nations with cheap labor, such as India, Indonesia and the Philippines. According to the Western diplomat, Japanese businessmen ``aren't terribly enthusiastic about China as a place to invest, or to trade, since exports have fallen due to import restrictions. They've become hard-nosed about doing business here.'' Japanese investors express the same concerns about China as about the Soviet Union: Joint ventures can find little hard currency to buy imports and factories face shortages of electricity and raw materials, despite recent orders that special help be given to foreign-financed companies. Economic austerity measures China imposed in late 1988 to curb inflation caused the domestic market to shrink. The pall cast by the military crackdown and fears of future instability further dampened foreign enthusiasm, and investment in China fell 14.7 percent in 1989 to $1.85 billion, according to Chinese estimates. Late last year, Political and Economic Risk Consultancy Ltd. of Hong Kong issued an evaluation for 1990 that pronounced China by far the riskiest for foreign investment of 10 Asian nations, including the coup-prone Philippines. After pointing to corruption, red tape and the potential for unrest, it said: ``Only investors with a long-term view of profit-making that takes into account huge potential short- and medium-term pitfalls should consider a large commitment of capital at this time.'' Investors willing to take the risk favor China's southern and coastal provinces, which have thousands of factories financed from nearby Hong Kong. ``These areas have been incorporated into the world economy, and technological and managerial innovation are seeping in,'' the diplomat said. ``Five or six years ago, Guangdong had a bad problem with quality. Now it's the preferred source for quality and on-time delivery, even when wages are higher than in Thailand.'' Japanese companies, with a labor shortage at home, increasingly use assembly plants along the Chinese coast that require minimal investment and training, said Maruyama, the Tokyo economist. ``Smaller Japanese firms making labor-intensive, low-cost items like tableware, compact cameras, pajamas and baby clothes are staying in business by producing in China,'' he said. ``Long-term joint ventures are too risky. They only want to use the labor power.'' One investment bright spot comes from Taiwan, whose businessmen seek factory sites abroad because of rapidly rising costs and pollution concerns at home. Taiwanese invested an estimated $550 million in China last year, replacing Japan as the third-ranked foreign investor after Hong Kong and the United States. Beijing has established special investment zones with concessionary terms for Taiwanese in Fujian province, across a narrow strait from the island, and in Guangdong.

DOC.HEAD: Wang Receives Largest Contract in Company History
DOC.TEXT: Wang Laboratories Inc., plagued by losses for more than a year, announced Tuesday it has received a government contract worth up to $841 million _ the largest in the computer maker's history. Under the contract, Wang will provide a wide range of computers, software and other services for the U.S. State Department during the next five years. The $841 million estimate is based on the State Department's projected needs during the five-year period. ``It certainly is a very significant hunk of business,'' said Frank Ryan, a spokesman for the Lowell, Mass.-based company. More important, he said, the contract reflects confidence in the company, which has been working feverishly to try to turn around its fortunes. The company lost $715 million in its last fiscal year and has eliminated more than 8,000 jobs. Wang announced last month it would cut another 1,000 jobs. The government contract will not change the company's plans to cut its payroll, Ryan said. Wang, like other Massachusetts companies, has been hurt by a decline in the market for mid-size computers. Richard Miller, who took over as company president last August and was named chairman this year when founder An Wang died, has tried to revamp the company's products and cut costs. Wang officials said the company's efforts to build a relationship with the State Department helped provide an edge. ``Wang has worked closely with the U.S. foreign affairs community for more than a decade,'' said Eugene Shugoll, vice president of Wang's federal systems division. While the contract will add to the company's revenue, Wang could use another major deal to show nervous customers that the State Department contract was not a fluke, said Marc Schulman, an analyst with UBS Phillips & Drew. Aside from the State Department, other foreign affairs agencies will be eligible to buy computers from Wang under the contract announced Tuesday. They include the U.S. Agency for International Development, the U.S. Information Agency and the Foreign Agricultural Service of the U.S. Department of Agriculture. The contract is the second positive development for Massachusetts' slumping computer industry. Prime Computer Inc., based in Natick, recently landed $180 million worth of business as part of an Army contract. That was the largest contract in Prime's history.

DOC.HEAD: Bullitt Family Puts King Broadcasting Up For Sale
DOC.TEXT: The majority shareholders in King Broadcasting Co. said Tuesday they plan to sell the privately held radio and television company. King owns six television stations in the Northwest and Hawaii, six radio stations in Seattle, Portland, Ore., and San Francisco, and 13 cable television systems in Washington, Idaho, California and Minnesota. Priscilla Bullitt Collins, chairman of King's board, and her sister Harriet Stimson Bullitt, chairman of the executive committee, said they intended to concentrate on preserving the environment in the Northwest. ``In part because of our age (we have both passed our 65th birthdays) we prefer to sell at a time of our own choosing rather than wait until a sale would be required by our deaths,'' the sisters said in a news release. They said they have retained Dillon, Read & Co. and Sterling Payot Co. to advise them on the sale. The sisters said their stock along with that of their late mother, Dorothy Bullitt, make up about 70 percent of the privately held company's shares. The Puget Sound Business Journal has estimated King's 1988 annual revenues at about $150 million and said King has approximately 1,200 employees. The Seattle Times quoted the media reserach firm Paul Kagan Associates as saying that NBC affiliate KING-TV has a market value of about $150 million. The entire company is valued at more than $400 million, the Times said. The sisters said they intend to work through the Bullitt Foundation to enhance environmental quality in the Northwest. King's properties include television stations KING, Seattle; KGW, Portland; KREM, Spokane; KTVB, Boise, Idaho; K38AS, Twin Falls, Idaho; and KHNL, Honolulu. Its radio stations are KING-AM and KING-FM in Seattle, KINK-FM and KGW-AM in Portland and KSFO-AM and KYA-FM in San Francisco. The company owns cable systems in Brooklyn Park and St. Croix, Minn.; Los Angeles, Santa Clarita, Riverside County, Lodi, Placerville, San Andreas, Mammoth Lakes and Mount Shasta, Calif.; Twin Falls and American Falls, Idaho; and Ellensburg, Wash. In all, the systems have more than 200,000 subscribers. King also owns Northwest Mobile Television, the nation's largest mobile production company. Dorothy Bullitt, who died last year at age 97, founded King when she bought a struggling Seattle radio station in 1946 and renamed it KING. In 1948, she bought 8-month-old KRSC-TV and subsequently renamed it KING-TV.

DOC.HEAD: MCI May Take $500 Million Charge For Modernization
DOC.TEXT: MCI Communications Corp. said Tuesday it was considering a writedown of $500 million to $550 million this quarter to cover the cost of replacing old analog equipment with digital gear. The move came as the No. 2 long-distance phone company announced plans to install a fully digital network by the end of next year at a cost of $1.1 billion. The plan includes the integration of 3,000 miles of optical fiber lines acquired when MCI purchased Telecom USA Inc. earlier this year. It also includes an agreement with Williams Cos. Inc. of Tulsa, Okla., for an interchange in each other's phone systems. Terms of the Williams deal were not disclosed. Both companies said the interchange agreement would allow them to save substantial amounts of capital investment over the next few years. MCI and Telecom USA have been the second and fourth largest customers for Williams' fiber-optic phone system, WilTel, which sells access to its lines to long-distance companies. The agreement will allow WilTel to serve a large number of cities, using the MCI network, than it does now, Williams officials said. Digital phone systems transmit calls in computer language, providing clearer reception and greater capacity than traditional analog systems. MCI earned $177 million in the second quarter on revenue of $1.86 billion. A write-down of assets could hurt earnings, but MCI did not speculate what that impact could be.

DOC.HEAD: London Shares Fall on Gulf Crisis
DOC.TEXT: Anxiety over the Gulf crisis drove share prices down again Tuesday on the London Stock Exchange. Sharp early falls on Wall Street hit the London market late in the day after jittery trading, which was hurt by unfounded rumors that a U.S. jet had been shot down over Iraq. As stock markets across Europe were also unsettled, investors were not in a buying mood, dealers said. At the close, the broad-based Financial Times-Stock Exchange 100 index stood at 2,108.1, a loss of 48.5 points, or 2.3 percent. The closing figure was slightly higher than the day's low of 2,098.5. The narrower 30-share index closed at 1,615.7, a fall of 43.8 points, while the broader 500-share index finished at 1,135.94, down 27.52. Volume amounted to 412.4 million shares, up from the 350.6 million traded Monday.

DOC.HEAD: AMR Eagle to Order 100 Large Commuter Planes
DOC.TEXT: AMR Corp.'s regional subsidiary, AMR Eagle, is expected to announce Wednesday that it will order 100 large commuter airplanes in a deal worth $800 million. Company spokesman Ed Martelle declined to discuss details of the transaction. But several industry sources said AMR Eagle will order or take options on at least 100 aircraft made by a joint venture between France and Italy's primary aerospace manufacturing companies. Officials of AMR Eagle, which operates the nation's largest commuter airline network, the American Eagle system, were expected to announce the deal at a news conference Wednesday at AMR's headquarters in Fort Worth. Called ATR, the joint venture between France's Aerospatiale and Italy's Aeritalia produces two turboprop-powered commuter airliners, the ATR-42 and the ATR-72. Aerospatiale and Aeritalia recently acquired Boeing's Canadian commuter airplane manufacturing subsidiary, de Havilland of Canada. Sources said they expect most or all of the planes being ordered by AMR Eagle to be ATR-42s, a 42-seat twin-engine turboprop. Paul Turk, an analyst with Avmark Inc., a Washington consulting firm, said the ATR-42 has a sticker price of about $9.5 million. AMR Eagle owns five of the six operating companies that fly under the American Eagle name. Together, the six American Eagle operations form the largest commuter airline in the nation, with 1,500 daily flights to 150 cities. American is the nation's largest airline, with 525 planes and orders or options for more than 500 additional big jets.

DOC.HEAD: Venezuela Announces 20 Percent Cut in Foreign Debt
DOC.TEXT: Venezuela's public foreign debt will cut by more than 20 percent under a reduction agreement reached between the country and creditor banks, Venezuelan officials announced Tuesday. The deal covers $20.5 billion of this oil-producing nation's $26 billion public-sector debt. The country owes about $35 billion in public- and private- sector debt. Cutting the debt has been a major goal of the 19-month-old government of President Carlos Andres Perez. He has said consistently that this once-wealthy nation is now too poor to pay on loans contracted over two decades of boom times. Debt-cutting negotiations began early last year under the umbrella of U.S. Treasury Secretary Nicholas Brady's plan to ease the burden of Third World nations. Officials said more than 90 percent of a total 400 creditor banks have chosen from a list of five debt-cutting options offered by Venezuela. The most popular options were the exchange of Venezuelan debt for low-interest, 30-year U.S.-guaranteed bonds, and the loaning of fresh funds to Venezuela. Least popular was the option that Venezuela had pushed the hardest: allowing Venezuela to buy back debt on the secondary market at about 41 percent of its value. Although one option allows banks to recapture more funds if the price of oil rises, officials said the income earned from high oil prices would far outweigh possible givebacks to the banks.

DOC.HEAD: Turner Enters New Arena _ Books _ But Not in Traditional Style
DOC.NOTE: With LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: Ted Turner is about to take his first step into the world of book publishing, but not with the role of giant slayer this time. Turner Publishing Inc. is getting started as a modest venture with little of the brashness that has accompanied other Turner projects, such as the launch 10 years ago of Cable News Network. ``We don't have any intention of becoming a Random House or Simon & Schuster. Publishing is not the main business of TBS, and it never will be,'' said Michael Reagan, vice president and publisher of Turner Publishing. But Reagan is hoping the publishing unit will cut itself a comfortable niche by utilizing Turner's cable television empire to generate interest in the book titles. Turner Publishing, a wholly owned subsidiary of Turner Broadcasting System Inc., puts its first book, a coffee-table volume of Reagan's photographs, on the market next month. The book, ``Portrait of Great Britain and Northern Ireland,'' is tied to a TBS mini-series. Most of what follows also will be tied to TBS television programming, especially the company's vast movie library. Set for a Valentine's Day release is ``Kisses,'' a photo collection of silver screen smooches ranging from Clark Gable and Vivien Leigh in ``Gone Withpside is that there's not a lot of expectations,'' he said. ``I don't think anyone expects us to make a profit right away.'' But, Reagan added, ``We have to prove ourselves financially. ... As time goes by, the burden will be on us to make a profit.'' Low expectations are probably a good thing, considering the recent slump in some segments of the publishing industry. Several industry giants, including Simon & Schuster and Harcourt Brace Jovanovich, took writedowns in the past year. Competition for best-sellers has driven up the advances commanded by some well-known writers. Some companies have taken on debt to buy other companies and have been forced to watch other costs more closely to meet repayment obligations. Analysts say Turner's relatively small investment in the book unit minimizes its risk. ``It's such a small part of the company,'' said Mary L. Kukowski, who follows TBS for Bear, Stearns & Co. Inc. in New York. ``A lot of what Turner does is interesting, but this is not important in terms of what moves the stock.'' Turner Publishing evolved from the TBS chairman's creation of the Turner Tomorrow Award, in which a $500,000 prize is offered for a novel that addresses positive solutions to global problems. The award carries a promise to publish the winning manuscript and, Reagan said, ``it became apparent we'd need a publishing company.'' Reagan said the publishing venture was a natural, given the TV material in the TBS archives with potential for transfer into book form, as well as the company's existing marketing and promotion machinery. ``If you spend $2 million doing mini-series or a documentary, all that research is already being done. It's not much more money to add a book to that mix,'' said Reagan, who is not related to the former president. Also ripe for mining are the 3,700 movies Turner owns, mainly as a result of its $1.3 billion purchase of the MGM film library four years ago. In addition to ``Kisses,'' a retrospective of ``Outlaws, Rebels and Rogues'' is planned as well as projects based on the film classics ``Citizen Kane'' and ``Casablanca.'' Reagan said he expects the movie-oriented books to have more mass appeal than those tied to the documentaries. For example, ``Kisses,'' a joint venture with Citadel Press, will have a first printing of 50,000 copies, while ``Portrait of Great Britain and Northern Ireland'' will ship 20,000. Reagan, who joined TBS in 1985 and worked on the ``Portrait of America'' and ``Portrait of the World'' series, also has taken photographs for a book on Cuba. But once that volume is completed, he said, he will concentrate on his executive duties. ``What we're trying to do is break some ground on the idea of what a tie-in is,'' Reagan said. ``In the past, (publishers would) take a screenplay and novelize it, or slap a star's face on the cover. This has nothing to do with a script. It's a tie-in in the broadest possible sense.''

Stock prices fell sharply in heavy trading today as investors continued to worry about the prospect of war in the Mideast. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrial stocks was down 49.51 points to 2,606.93 as of 3 p.m. EDT on Wall Street. In the broader market, declining stocks outnumbered advancing ones by about 7 to 1 on the New York Stock Exchange, with 202 up, 1,450 down and 326 unchanged. Volume on the Big Board came to a brisk 172.06 million shares with an hour of trading remaining. Traders said the main influence on the market was continuing concern about the Iraqi situation. ``Everyone's just very, very nervous here,'' said Tony Woodruff, a managing director at Kidder, Peabody & Co. In a speech this morning, Iraq's president, Saddam Hussein, said his nation's detention of foreigners was justified given the aggressive response by foreign nations to Iraq's invasion of Kuwait. Saddam also said that if the United States continues its aggression, ``a disaster will take place concerning the whole world.'' Woodruff said the continuing rise in oil prices due to the Mideast tension is of particular concern to the market. Analysts said the market also was hurt by losses on overseas exchanges. Stock prices fell sharply in Frankfurt, primarily due to a rumor _ later dismissed _ that a U.S. plane was shot down over Iraq. Share prices also closed sharply lower in London trading. Earlier, prices slipped for the fourth consecutive session in Tokyo. The Dow twice plunged more than 50 points, each time triggering one of the NYSE's ``circuit breakers'' designed to prevent a price freefall. The mechanism bars stock sales connected to index-futures arbitrage until the prices of the stocks involved rise. Among most-active blue-chip issues today, General Electric fell 2[ to 61~, Philip Morris lost 1\ to 43|, Boeing slipped 2\ to 46\, IBM dropped 2 to 100\ and AT&T fell 1 to 32}. The NYSE's composite index of all its listed common stocks dropped 3.35 to 177.07. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index was down 4.07 at 327.22.

DOC.HEAD: Data General Could Cut More Workers
DOC.TEXT: Data General Corp., which has already cut its work force by about one-third, may slash its payroll further to help end a string of losses, analysts said Tuesday. Employment at Data General has shrunk to 11,700, down from 17,700 in 1985, the last year the company reported a profit. One of the biggest thorns for the company has been its line of mid-size computers, whose market has declined as smaller computers grow more powerful. Data General has been pushing a line of workstations, which are powerful desktop machines, to help reverse the company's slide. It's also been making products that conform to industry standards. Nonetheless, Data General is still struggling with weak revenues. For the first nine months of the current fiscal year, the company had revenues of $907 million, compared with $957 million a year ago. ``We are committed to taking whatever steps are necessary to become profitable,'' said James Dunlap, a spokesman for Westboro, Mass.-based computer maker. ``We are looking at all options that would allow us to cut costs. We cannot rule out any possibility.'' Some Wall Street analysts said a round of layoffs could be announced soon, and more than 1,000 jobs might be eliminated. ``There have been signals in the air that something major was coming,'' said Marc Schulman, an analyst at UBS Phillips & Drew. He defined a major cut as at least 1,000 jobs. ``Most companies don't like to cut more than they have to,'' said P. Martin Ressinger, an analyst with Duff & Phelps. ``I think Data General might cut more than they have to in order to get the profits, and not just break even.'' Analysts say Data General has introduced potentially strong products, particularly with its workstations, but the company faces a tough task in carving out more of the market. The company should concentrate first on becoming profitable, and then turn its attention to attracting customers, Schulman said. ``First they become profitable, then people will start to evaluate their products,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Grain, Soybeans Mixed
DOC.TEXT: Grain and soybean futures prices were weak Tuesday on the Chicago Board of Trade, with wheat losing more than 3 cents a bushel. ``We'll need an influx of bullish news just to keep this market steady,'' said Joel Karlin, an analyst with Research Department Inc. in Chicago. The agricultural commodities withstood the buffeting of news from the Middle East, which sharply affected gold and oil prices. However, Karlin said, the sharp drop in stock prices at the market's opening was interpreted by grain traders as continuing evidence that a recession may be in the offing, a negative influence on farm futures. Commodities also were under some pressure from a weekly government report issued late Monday indicating the corn and soybean crops continue to be growing well in the Midwest. There was no help for prices on the demand side, either, said Karlin. ``There's no export demand for wheat and the situation may be the same for corn and soybeans in a few months,'' he said. At the close, wheat futures prices were { cent higher to 3{ cents lower with the contract for delivery in September at $2.77} a bushel; corn was \ cent higher to 1{ cents lower with September at $2.51 a bushel; oats were \ cent to { cent lower with September at $1.61\ a bushel; soybeans were 1{ cents lower to 4} cents higher with August at $6.11 a bushel.

DOC.HEAD: National Semiconductor to Close Facilities, Lay Off 2,000
DOC.TEXT: National Semiconductor on Tuesday announced restructuring that will close facilities in Washington and Arizona and reduce its worldwide work force by about 2,000. The electronics company also said it expects to incur a one-time charge of about $140 million in its first fiscal quarter ending Aug. 26, and said its operating results for the quarter will be below expectations. ``We are taking these actions both to refocus our strategic investments on high-growth, high-potential businesses and to reduce our costs in line with current revenue projections,'' said Charles E. Sporck, president and chief executive officer. National Semiconductor designs, manufacturers and markets advanced semiconductor products. The company said it will close the fabrication line in its plant in Puyallup, Wash., idling 300 people. It also plans to close its Tucson, Ariz., military-product assembly and testing facility, which will affect 450 workers. ``We haven't determined yet where the other layoffs will take place,'' said company spokeswoman Mary Coady. Sporck cited several factors for the decisions, including ``reduced levels of military demand and severe pricing pressure in certain market sectors.'' Iraq's invasion of Kuwait has forced Saudi Arabia to make a fundamental and perhaps permanent change in its public approach to the outside world. The invasion forced Saudi Arabia, long equivocal about its links with the West, to publicly ally itself with the United States, despised by many Arabs for its support of Israel. The United Arab Emirates and otherarate statements, warned that the United States would be defeated and ``humiliated'' if it went to war against Iraq. Fitzwater said Iraqi officials have refused to give a U.S. diplomat in Baghdad access to Americans, and he added, ``At this point we see very little to talk about when all we get are negative responses.'' The White House also announced that Defense Secretary Dick Cheney, returning from a trip through the tense Middle East, and Gen. Colin Powell, the chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, will fly to Maine Wednesday to confer with Bush at his oceanfront vacation home. Among the mattersFitzwater said Bush will not sign before Wednesday the order calling up reserves to fill in the ranks of doctors, cargo handlers and other specialists depleted by the massive deployment of U.S. troops to defend Saudi Arabia. The number of reservists to be called was still unspecified. One administration official said privately the order may be open-ended. Chief of Staff John Sununu said it will be a ``very surgical, specialized call-up.'' Fitzwater said 18 Americans got out of Kuwait Tuesday but ``there are still 54 Americans missing'' _ 13 in Kuwait and 41 in Iraq. ``It does appear that citizens of all nations are being moved about in Iraq to unknown destinations,'' he said. In Washington, State Department spokesman Richard Boucher said there were ``credible reports'' that Iraq had forced some Westerners to industrial installations and said an American in Kuwait was seized in his home and interned in a hotel. Boucher said the reports had not been confirmed, nor was it known whether Americans were among those taken to plants. Saddam has threatened to use Westerners as a human shield to dissuade the United States from attack. More than 3,000 Americans are among more than 10,000 foreigners trapped in Iraq and Kuwait. The buildup of U.S. forces continued in Saudi Arabia. At the Pentagon, Gen. Hansford T. Johnson, the top official responsible for getting troops and supplies to Saudi Arabia, said security rules prevented him from disclosing the exact number of ground troops there or on the way but that ``we've moved in essence'' the equivalent of a town the size of Jefferson City, Mo. Preliminary 1990 census figures put Jefferson City's population at 35,408. An additional 20,000 or so sailors are deployed on warships in the area. Fitzwater spoke with reporters at the Woodlands Country Club in Falmouth, Maine, while Bush was out golfing at a tournament raising $200,000 for Maine Gov. John McKernan's re-election drive. Fitzwater stressed that it was not the United States alone but ``all nations'' that were demanding Iraq to end its occupation of Kuwait. ``We demand complete and unconditional withdrawal from Kuwait. That is the position of the United Nations and that's the position of all nations,'' the spokesman said. ``I'm sure all nations are interested in the welfare of their citizens, interested in talking to Iraq at any point. That's not the same as negotiations over a U.N. demand to get out,'' he said. Fitzwater said Joseph Wilson, the U.S. charge d'affaires in Baghdad, met with Iraqi officials Monday demanding access to Americans. His plea was spurned. Asked if there could be no talks with Iraq until its tanks are out of Kuwait, Fitzwater replied, ``The important point here is that the world is united in demanding that Iraq withdraw from Kuwait. That has not changed one iota by these comments this morning.'' Bush, back from a day of speeches in which he termed the foreigners in Iraq and Kuwait hostages and attacked Saddam as ``a man of evil standing against human life itself,'' ignored reporters Tuesday, saying nothing to them during on an early morning jog and on the golf course. Bush spoke by telephone Tuesday to Thomas Pickering, the U.S. ambassador to the United Nations, and to National Security Adviser Brent Scowcroft who was back at the White House. Fitzwater said U.S. warships were still shadowing several ships in the Persian Gulf region to make sure none violated the trade embargo with Iraq. However, he said, one Iraqi tanker was being allowed to dock in a Yemen port based on assurances from the Yemeni government that that country would not unload or use Iraqi oil. Sununu, also out golfing in McKernan's tournament, defended Bush's decision to stay in Maine in spite of the crisis. ``Everybody knows he keeps in touch with what's happening,'' said Sununu. ``I'd rather have a president who kept the whole thing in perspective than one who locked himself behind closed doors and brooded about the problem.'' The president later was attending the funeral of his uncle, Dr. John Walker, 81, a retired surgeon and investment banker from Easton, Maine, who died Thursday.

DOC.HEAD: Call for Top Finance Officials to Discuss Gulf Crisis
DOC.TEXT: A leading official of the European Community on Tuesday urged finance officials of the United States and other key industrialized nations to meet soon to discuss the Persian Gulf crisis. Jacques Delors, president of the European Commission, said the officials should meet ``to give positive signs'' to the jittery financial markets. There have been increasing fears that skyrocketing oil prices, caused by the international embargo against Iraqi and Kuwaiti crude, will tip the United States and maybe other Western nations into a recession. Delors, a former French finance chief, said the Mideast crisis required more coordination of the economic policies of the Group of Seven countries _ the United States, Britain, France, Canada, Japan, Italy and West Germany. Those nations' top finance officials meet periodically to assess the world economic outlook and monitor their own economic and monetary performance. Delors acknowledged he had no say in scheduling the high-level talks, comparing his suggestion to ``a bottle sent out to sea.''

DOC.HEAD: Endorses Plan to Create U.S.-Style Central Bank
DOC.TEXT: The European Community's executive body on Tuesday endorsed a blueprint for forming tighter economic and monetary links that would include a U.S.-style central bank in 1993. It also would lead to creation of a single currency to be used throughout the dozen nations of the trading bloc. The plan was offered to guide the nations at a special conference opening in December to make any needed changes in their founding Treaty of Rome to forge an economic and monetary union. Henning Christophersen, the community's top economics official, told a news conference that there should be a short period of time between establishing the European-wide system of central banks, dubbed EuroFed, and moving to a single currency. The commission's blueprint will be discussed by economics and finance ministers of the dozen nations at a meeting in early September in Rome. The first stage of a three-part plan to put an economic and monetary union in place began on July 1, with greater coordination of policies among the community governments. Under the proposed blueprint, the second stage would open on Jan. 1, 1993, when work would get under way on the independent central banking system. No date has been proposed for the final stage and introduction of the single currency.

DOC.HEAD: Wall Street Firm Buys Back 2.36 Million Shares
DOC.TEXT: Bear, Stearns & Co. on Tuesday repurchased 2.36 million shares of its own stock when the share price of the Wall Street firm hit a 52-week low. The buyback, part of a program dating to November 1987, amounted to about 2.4 percent of the firm's common shares outstanding. The stock was bought from a single, unidentified institutional investor, a spokesman said. The purchase was made early in the trading day, when Bear Stearns' shares fell to $10, setting a new 52-week low. The stock has traded as high as $15.25 in the last year. ``The stock was for sale. We've been buying stock on an ongoing basis,'' company spokesman Jonathan Barnett said. Like many Wall Street firms, Bear Stearns shares have been hurt by a recession in the securities industry. The stock closed Tuesday at $10.50 a share in New York Stock Exchange trading, down 25 cents from Monday. ``Their stock price is down. They've got excess capital,'' said Lawrence Eckenfelder, an industry analyst with Prudential Bache-Securities Inc. in San Francisco. The purchase was made under a company program that allows it to use profits from November 1987 on to repurchase stock. Bear Stearns' board in July 1988 expanded the program to include purchases in privately negotiated transactions.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar, Gold Mixed
DOC.TEXT: The dollar finished mixed after falling overseas Tuesday in a volatile session that saw the currency buffeted by conflicting reports about the prospects for stability in the Middle East. Gold prices slipped after rising sharply in Europe. On the New York Commodity Exchange, one troy ounce of gold closed at $407.40, off $2.70 an ounce from Monday. Later, Republic National Bank quoted an after-hours bid of $406.90, down $2.35 as of 4 p.m. EDT. Traders sold the dollar following a report that Iraqi President Saddam Hussein was willing to negotiate a peace settlement. But later reports that the Iraqis were mining Kuwaiti ports and refineries pushed the dollar higher. ``The dollar and gold got whipsawed by these conflicting reports,'' said Marc Chandler, an analyst with MMS International in Chicago. ``The dollar put in its lows on the idea that there would be peace, then when that seemed to fade,'' it was pushed back up. In times of international turmoil, the dollar is in demand because it is perceived as a ``safe-haven'' currency. But another round of bearish economic data further pressured an already weak U.S. currency. The government reported that the federal budget deficit jumped $25.9 billion in July, pushing the fiscal year's imbalance so far to $189.1 billion, compared with $123.7 billion at the end of July 1989. The report induced traders to sell dollars because it appears the U.S. economy may be headed into a recession. Lower interest rates, which typically follow in an economic slowdown, would make dollar-denominated securities less appealing to foreign investors. Still, investors are ``a little afraid to get a little too short of dollars,'' said Gilbert Cisneros, a trader at the Bank of Boston's New York office. ``If something does spark (in the Middle East), it's expensive to get the dollars back.'' In Tokyo, the dollar fell to a closing 146.55 Japanese yen from 147.47 yen late Monday. Later in London, the dollar fell to 146.35 yen. In New York the dollar closed at 146.80 yen, up from 146.51 yen. In London, the British pound rose to $1.9215 from $1.9185 late Monday. In New York, it cost $1.9113 to buy one pound, less expensive than Monday's $1.9135. Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Monday included: 1.5645 German marks, up from 1.5642; 1.2900 Swiss francs, down from 1.2955; 5.2635 French francs, up from 5.2565; 1,161.75 Italian lire, up from 1,157.25, and 1.1399 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1427. Other late dollar rates in Europe, compared with late rates Monday included: 1.5545 German marks, down from 1.5625; 1.2855 Swiss francs, down from 1.2940; 5.2325 French francs, down from 5.2375; 1.7530 Dutch guilders, down from 1.7585; 1,155.75 Italian lire, down from 1,156.50; and 1.1437 Canadian dollars, unchanged. Gold rose in London to a late bid of $413.25 a troy ounce from $409.75 late Monday. In Zurich, gold rose to $414.75 an ounce from $409.75 late Monday. Earlier in Hong Kong, gold fell $2.32 an ounce to $407.45. Silver prices were mixed. On New York's Comex, silver bullion fetched $5.091 a troy ounce, down from $5.129 on Monday. But in London, silver rose to a late bid of $5.20 an ounce from $5.14.

DOC.HEAD: IBM Announces New Mid-Range Computers, Enhancements
DOC.TEXT: IBM on Tuesday announced two new lower-priced models of its popular midrange Application System-400 computer line, as well as software enhancements designed to improve the computers' performance. The cheapest of the new models is priced at $18,250, 27 percent below the previous lowest-cost AS-400, International Business Machines Corp. said. IBM says this means small companies, or departments of large corporations, can now afford an AS-400 computer. IBM also announced a new model of its Application System-Entry line, a lower-priced computer line. This new model, which will be priced at $11,000, could later be upgraded to an AS-400 machine, IBM said. In addition, IBM announced more than 200 hardware and software enhancements for the entire AS-400 line. They include a new version of the AS-400's operating system, the base layer of software that controls internal computer functions, as well as new data storage devices. IBM said it intends to announce new high-end extensions of the 2-year-old AS-400 line by mid-1991 that will increase performance and capacity. Bob Djurdjevic, an industry analyst and president of Annex Research in Phoenix, said the new low-end AS-400 models should help increase the market share for the line. But he said more significant news was buried in IBM's announcement, the fact that it will license independent software houses to use the internal code of the operating system of the AS-400 computers to develop new applications programs. Previously, IBM regarded this operating system code as proprietary, Djurdjevic said. He said the move shows IBM is responding to the move by the computer industry toward ``open,'' or non-proprietary, operating systems. ``The fact that the AS-400 is now becoming a more open system will undoubtedly aid it in its competition for software developers' hearts and minds,'' he said in a report on IBM's announcement. There already are about 8,000 applications programs for the AS-400 line, he said.

DOC.HEAD: SEC Settles with One Businessman; Wins Court Order Against Another
DOC.TEXT: A California businessman settled a civil complaint with federal securities regulators Tuesday, the same day they accused him of failing to disclose the size of his stake in a company over a three-year period. The Securities and Exchange Commission said it had accepted Joel M. Barry's settlement of charges that he failed to report on time, among other things, transactions totaling $3.3 million. Barry neither admitted nor denied any wrongdoing. In an unrelated case, the SEC's regional office in Fort Worth, Texas, said a San Antonio, Texas, man accused of helping loot a mutual fund, the Prospector Fund, of millions of dollars, has settled civil charges. In the case against Barry, 40, of Thousand Oaks, Calif., the SEC charged that he violated securities laws by failing to file reports in a timely manner over three years concerning transactions involving Electronic Clearing House Inc., Agoura hills, Calif., of which he was chairman, and Basics Financial Planning and Investments Inc., an Anaheim real estate concern of which he was president. Basics also was accused of failing to disclose in a timely fashion $2.4 million in transactions between June 1987 through June 1990. Federal securities laws require stockholders holding 5 percent or more of a publicly traded company to report when it acquires the 5 percent, as well as any significant developments. The disclosure requirement is aimed at giving the public adequate information to make investing decisions. The SEC charged that Barry and Basics did not file for more than three years the required disclosure documents, when they held between 16 and 42 percent of ECHI's common stock. In the Texas case, Carl L. Lazzell of San Antonio settled civil charges without admitting or denying wrongdoing and agreed to pay restitution in an amount to be determined by a federal judge. According to the SEC, Lazzell, who was Prospector's former portfolio manager, caused the gold stocks' mutual fund to buy about $20 million in over-valued securities and allededly took $1 million in kickbacks from two Canadians, David H. Ward of Vancouver and Edward Carter of Toronto, who controlled the securities. James Sims, an SEC attorney in Texas, said Prospector suffered $15 million in trading losses but has recovered much of it through separate civil lawsuits.

DOC.HEAD: Seiko and Franklin Agree on Distribution in Japan
DOC.TEXT: Franklin Electronic Publishers Inc. announced Tuesday that it will sell electronic reference products in Japan under a distribution agreement with Seiko Instruments Inc. The publishing company, based in Mount Holly, will export electronic speaking dictionaries designed for students of English as a foreign language. The products use speech synthesis to pronounce American English words. ``We are delighted to have reached an accord with a world-class company such as Seiko to sell Franklin's state-of-the-art American electronic products in the Japanese market,'' said Franklin chairman Morton E. David. Franklin publishes a library of 20 hand-held electronic reference products, including the Spelling Ace spelling corrector and Wordmaster electronic thesaurus.

DOC.HEAD: Gasoline Sets New Record Price
DOC.TEXT: Unleaded gasoline prices soared to a fifth straight record high on Tuesday, but the price of crude oil fell as traders reacted to what appeared to be more conciliatory rhetoric from Iraq. ``It calmed the market,'' said William Byers, an oil analyst with Bear Stearns & Co. ``It calmed traders, because it indicated there was another possible solution to the situation, other than military.'' Crude prices slipped as Iraqi officials were quoted as saying they were willing to negotiate a solution to the Middle East crisis. But prices inched back up after the White House said it had no plans to seek a deal while Iraqi forces remained in Kuwait. The September contract for light sweet crude oil closed at $28.41 per barrel, 15 cents lower than Monday, but other futures prices for months going through June 1991 were all higher on the New York Mercantile Exchange. Later months were lower. ``Everybody's trading on headlines,'' Byers said. Oil markets have been chaotic since Iraq invaded its neighbor on Aug. 2, pushing up prices of crude oil and gasoline over fear of supply disruptions. The rise has been particularly dramatic in the wholesale price of unleaded gasoline, which closed at a record high Tuesday for the fifth-straight day to $1.013, up 1.01 cents from Monday. Concerns about shortages have some consumers keeping their tanks full and some service stations keeping their supplies at higher levels, said Ann-Louise Hittle, a senior oil analyst with Shearson Lehman Brothers Inc. ``They're anticipating shortages down the line,'' Hittle said. Traders have been concerned of a lack of refinery capacity, with U.S. plants running at nearly full capacity and three modern Kuwaiti refineries taken out of the world market by the international boycott of oil from Iraq and Kuwait. Other petroleum futures were up Tuesday, as natural gas moved from $1.417 to $1.420 per 1,000 cubic feet on September contracts and wholesale home heating oil rose .75 cent to 83.71 cents per gallon. Tuesday was the last trading day for September petroleum contracts on the Merc. After the markets closed, the American Petroleum Institute reported that crude oil and gasoline imports were up last week. Gasoline stocks were also higher, although crude stocks were slightly down. The API's weekly report said crude imports rose to 6.5 million barrels per day for the week ending Aug. 10, up from 6.2 million barrels per day a week earlier but down from 6.9 million barrels per day a year earlier. The nation's stockpile of crude oil dipped from 375.9 million barrels to 375.7 million barrels, although it was well above the 335.2 million barrels reported a year earlier. Gasoline stockpiles rose to 214 million barrels, up from 212.4 million barrels a week earlier but down from 223.9 million barrels a year earlier. Gasoline imports rose to 545,000 barrels per day, up from 376,000 barrels a day a week earlier and 280,000 barrels a day a year earlier. U.S. refineries were running at 92.3 percent of capacity, down from 94.3 percent a week earlier but up from 90 percent a year earlier.

DOC.HEAD: Gold Prices Bounce on Reports from Middle East
DOC.TEXT: War-wary traders sent gold futures prices into a strong rally then a sharp reversal as Middle East developments sent conflicting signals Tuesday to the trading pits at the Commodity Exchange in New York. Prices were up more than $6 an ounce early, then turned around and sunk nearly $9 below Monday's close before trimming the losses. On other markets, petroleum futures were mostly higher; orange juice was sharply lower; grain and soybeans were mostly lower; and cattle was mostly higher while pork declined. ``The gold market was a pretty volatile session,'' said Craig Sloane, an analyst with Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Co. in New York. ``Traders are nervous. If you happen to be long in gold you've got a lot to lose if things calm down in the Middle East.'' Even before trading began for the day, the market was looking for higher prices on a rumor that a U.S. plane had been shot down in the Mideast. The prices held firm even after the rumor was denied. But when Saddam Husseim made an address to President Bush and Iraq's defense minister, Tariq Aziz, called for a negotiated settlement, the gains in gold futures gave way, dropping $15 below the day's high. ``Perhaps the market was expecting or fearing a declaration of war or whatever,'' Sloane said. The losses were trimmed before the close as the market came to realize that Iraq's statements broke no new ground. ``It doesn't take much to get the market moving in any direction,'' said Sloane. Gold futures settled $2.70 to $2.90 lower with the August contract at $407.40 a troy ounce; silver was 3.4 cents to 4.1 cents lower with September at $5.105 a troy ounce. Petroleum futures had a wild day at the New York Mercantile Exchange, opening sharply higher, then plunging on news of Iraq's willingness to negotiate a Middle East settlement, then rallying to close mostly higher. West Texas intermediate crude oil settled 15 cents lower to 18 cents higher with the September contract at $28.41 a barrel; heating oil was .75 cent to 1.78 cents higher with September at 83.71 cents a gallon; and unleaded gasoline was .25 cent to 5.55 cents higher with September at $1.0126 a gallon. Orange juice futures dropped sharply on fears that Brazil, which cut prices last Friday, might bring them even lower. Futures lost 14.5 cents a pound since Friday's announcement. ``They fear getting into a price-cut cycle,'' said Sandra Kaul, an analyst in New York with Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc. On the New York Cotton Exchange, orange juice futures retreated 1.95 cents to 4.15 cents with September settling at $1.6675 a pound. Cattle futures were mostly higher while the pork complex declined on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange. Live cattle regained losses suffered Monday when many traders interpreted a USDA cattle-on-feed report as bearish, said Tom Morgan, president of Sterling Research Corp. of Arlington Heights, Ill. That interpretation was shown to be mistaken, he said, when Tuesday's cash markets were strong. ``In pork, there's an overall bearish situation,'' he said. ``We're going to see the slaughter increase more than seasonally as we move into the late summer and fall.'' Live cattle settled .30 cent lower to .53 cent higher with the October contract at 77.80 cents a pound; feeder cattle .15 cent lower to .55 cent higher with August at 89.87 cents a pound; live hogs were .12 cent to .77 cent lower with October at 49.30 cents a pound; and frozen pork bellies were .70 cent to the limit 2 cents lower with August at 47.72 cents a pound. Wheat futures lost more than 3 cents a bushel in weak grain and soybean trading on the Chicago Board of Trade. ``We'll need an influx of bullish news just to keep this market steady,'' said Joel Karlin, an analyst with Research Department Inc. in Chicago. He said the market was weakened by the sharp drop in stock prices, suggesting to grain traders that a recession isn't far off. Wheat settled { cent to 2{ cents lower with the September contract at $2.80\ a bushel; corn was } cent lower to 1 cent higher with September at $2.51} a bushel; oats were unchanged to 1\ cents higher with September at $1.17{ a bushel; and soybeans were 2 cents lower to 3 cents higher with August at $6.11 a bushel.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: Updates with closing prices throughout.
DOC.TEXT: Stock prices fell sharply in heavy trading Tuesday as investors continued to worry about the prospect of war in the Mideast. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrial stocks fell 52.48 to close at 2,603.96. Earlier, the Dow was down by as much as 77 points. Declining issues outnumbered advancing ones by nearly 6 to 1 in nationwide trading of New York Stock Exchange-listed stocks, with 243 up, 1,441 down and 340 unchanged. Volume on the floor of the Big Board came to 194.63 million shares, up from 129.63 million Monday. Nationwide, consolidated volume in NYSE-listed issues, including trades in those stocks on regional exchanges and in the over-the-counter market, totaled 236.78 million shares. With little economic news, investors fretted over the Iraqi situation, traders said. ``Everyone's just very, very nervous here,'' said Tony Woodruff, a managing director at Kidder, Peabody & Co. The market received little reassurance from a speech by Iraq's president, Saddam Hussein, aimed at President Bush. Saddam said his nation's detention of foreigners was justified given the aggressive response by foreign nations to Iraq's invasion of Kuwait. He added that if the United States continues its aggression, ``a disaster will take place concerning the whole world.'' Woodruff said the rise in oil prices due to the Mideast tension is of particular concern to the stock market. Though crude prices were mixed Tuesday, prices of gasoline and other refined products jumped. Analysts said the market also was hurt by losses on overseas stock exchanges. Stock prices fell sharply in Frankfurt, primarily due to a rumor _ later dismissed _ that a U.S. plane was shot down over Iraq. Share prices also closed sharply lower in London trading. Earlier, prices slipped for the fourth consecutive session in Tokyo. Several times the Dow fell more than 50 points, each time triggering one of the NYSE's ``circuit breakers'' designed to prevent a price freefall. The mechanism bars stock sales connected to index-futures arbitrage until the prices of the stocks involved rise. Philip Morris was the most-active NYSE stock, falling 1 to 43~ as 3.66 million shares changed hands. Stocks of consumer-oriented companies have been particularly hard-hit in recent days. Among other most-active blue-chip stocks, General Electric fell 1~ to 61~, Boeing slipped 2] to 46[, IBM dropped 1} to 100{ and AT&T fell ~ to 32~. As measured by Wilshire Associates' index of more than 5,000 actively traded stocks, the market lost $62.601 billion, or 2.01 percent, in value. The NYSE's composite index of all its listed common stocks fell 3.48 to 176.94. Standard & Poor's industrial index fell 7.92 to 379.81, and S&P's 500-stock composite index dropped 6.65 to 321.86. The NASDAQ composite index for the over-the-counter market fell 8.91 to 379.68. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index dropped 3.95 to 327.34.

DOC.HEAD: British Aerospace Announces New Orders for Quiet Jet
DOC.TEXT: British Aerospace PLC said Tuesday it had firm orders for 25 of its BAe 146 aircraft, with options for eight more, in a deal worth about $900 million for the British company. British Aerospace has now sold 293 of the four-engine airliner that entered service in 1983 and is known as the quiet jet. It can seat between 70 and 120 passengers. The total value of the latest package of orders, including options on the additional eight aircraft and spares, approaches 500 million pounds, or $900 million, making it the largest single package of orders announced for the aircraft, the company said. The 25 firm orders are from nine airlines in seven countries. The company said airlines involved in the new orders included Belgium's Sabena, Indonesia's PT National Air Carrier, Air Botswana and Dan Air of Britain, which was the first airline to introduce the BAe 146 into service in 1983.

DOC.HEAD: Six OPEC Members to Meet on Oil Supplies
DOC.TEXT: Six of the 13 members of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries will meet next week to discuss oil supplies in the midst of the Middle East crisis, petroleum industry sources said. Algeria, Indonesia, Iran, Nigeria, Saudi Arabia and Venezuela will participate, the sources said. It was not immediately clear where the meeting would be held. Saudi Arabia and Venezuela had failed Monday to convince a majority of OPEC members to agree to a conference on the Gulf crisis. The two countries want OPEC to allow members to raise production to make up for 4 million barrels of crude kept off the market each day because of the international boycott of Iraqi and Kuwaiti oil. World crude prices have risen significantly since Iraq invaded its neighbor on Aug. 2. Saudi Arabia plans no unilateral oil production increase to make up the fall in global supply, according to the Saudi ambassador to Algeria. But Saudi Arabia continues to consult with other OPEC members about raising oil production, Mohamed Hassan Faki told reporters Monday evening. An ``eventual'' increase in oil prices would have a ``disastrous effect on the world economy,'' Faki said. Saudi Arabia had indicated over the weekend it would increase production by up to 2 million barrels of oil per day, even without approval from OPEC.

DOC.HEAD: Reports 16 Percent Profit Rise in Third Quarter
DOC.TEXT: Deere & Co. said Tuesday its third-quarter earnings rose 16 percent from a year ago as its sales rose 6 percent. Deere said it earned $114.1 million, or $1.50 per share, in the three months ended July 31 compared with $98.2 million, or $1.30 per share, during the same period a year earlier. The company's fiscal year ends Oct. 31. Quarterly revenue rose to $2.05 billion from $1.9 billion a year ago. Deere Chairman Hans W. Becherer credited strong retail sales of tractors and farm machinery in North America for the increased earnings. ``However, declining consumer spending for durable goods is resulting in lower retail sales of our lawn and grounds care products, which were below last year's levels during the quarter and are now down slightly for the first nine months of 1990,'' Becherer said in a statement. Deere on Tuesday announced the layoff of 160 workers at its Horicon, Wis., plant, which employs about 1,000. A sharp decline in sales of lawn tractors and grounds-care equipment was blamed for the indefinite layoffs, which take effect next week. Deere experienced strong gains in the performance of its financial subsidiaries for the quarter. The units are involved in credit, insurance and health-care operations. For the first nine months of the 1990 fiscal year, Deere earnings are $336.6 million, or $4.44 per share, up 22 percent from $277 million, or $3.68 per share, in the first nine months a year earlier. Revenue rose 11 percent to $5.82 billion from $5.22 billion a year earlier. ``It's obvious to us the recovery of the farm economy is very much on target,'' Deere spokesman Robert Combs said. ``Some experts say farmers are seeing record increases in income and that's good news for equipment makers. The most important single factor to us is the agricultural economy.''

DOC.HEAD: Markets Whipsawed By Iraqi Statements
DOC.TEXT: U.S. financial markets took a roller-coaster ride Tuesday as traders reacted fitfully to sometimes belligerent, sometimes conciliatory talk from Iraq. The stock market ended the day sharply lower, oil prices fell, bonds were nearly unchanged and gold prices slipped _ but the markets were characterized by wild ups and downs throughout the day. ``Comments on the Middle East are just whacking the market this way and that,'' said Robert Brusca, chief economist with Nikko Securities International Inc. Financial markets focused on televised statements from Iraq by the nation's defense minister and its president, Saddam Hussein, who again escalated the level of rhetoric in the Persian Gulf standoff. The market was heartened when Iraqi defense minister Tariq Aziz said in Jordan the country was willing to negotiate a settlement to the crisis, but he did not offer to withdraw Iraqi troops from Kuwait and restore the monarchy. Hussein later offered more harsh words for President Bush and the United States, predicting a ``major catastrophe'' if hostilities break out and ``a bloody conflict'' that America will lose. Iraq also was reported to be mining Kuwaiti ports and refineries. The war words rattled Wall Street, which has taken a beating because of concerns over the U.S. economy's poor performance in recent months. The Dow Jones industrial average fell 52.48 to close at 2,603.96. Earlier, the Dow average was down by as much as 77 points. Crude oil prices slipped after Aziz's settlement comment but inched back up when the White House said it had no plans to strike a deal while Iraqi forces continued to occupy neighboring Kuwait. The price closed witha 15-cent loss on the New York Mercantile Exchange at $28.41 a barrel. ``When Hussein comes out and says let's talk, people take some profits and stay on the sidelines and say let's see what he wants to talk about,'' said Jack O'Dea, manager of international energy futures for Dean Witter Reynolds Inc. Among refined petroleum products, unleaded gasoline closed at a record high for the fifth straight day at $1.013 per gallon, up 1.01 cents. Natural gas rose .03 cent to $1.420 per 1,000 cubic feet and home heating oil rose .75 cent to 83.71 cents per gallon. The dollar finished mixed against foreign currencies in a volatile session, also buffeted by the conflicting comments from Iraq. Gold prices slipped after rising sharply in Europe. Gold prices closed at $407.40, off $2.70 an ounce from Monday. After falling sharply amid fears of oil-backed inflation, bond price gained ground to close nearly unchanged. The Treasury's key 30-year bond fell 63 cents per $1,000 face amount after losing more than $5 in morning trading before rebounding sharply. Yields on the long bond cracked 9 percent during the day, before falling back later. ``With all the different comments, you just don't really know what the heck to do,'' Brusca said. ``The markets seemed willing to seize upon a seed of good news.'' Overseas, financial markets were battered by an unconfirmed report later denied by the State Department that a U.S. plane was shot down over Iraq. The Frankfurt stock market tumbled 5 percent, while prices closed sharply lower in London and Tokyo.

DOC.HEAD: Chrysler Renames Business Formerly Split With Renault
DOC.TEXT: Chrysler Corp. has renamed its ARCAD Inc. subsidiary, created as a 50-50 joint venture with the French automaker Renault, as JJ International Automotive Corp., the U.S. company said Tuesday. The new name reflects the ``JJ'' codename of a small sport-utility vehicle the company wants to make and market. There have been rumors that Chrysler may decide to build the vehicle by itself or may be looking for a partner to replace Renault. In June, Chrysler said it terminated its $500 million agreement with Renault because it was no longer economically attractive. Chrysler bought Renault's stake in ARCAD for an undisclosed sum. When the joint venture ended, the U.S. automaker said it would continue development on the small sport-utility vehicle. There has been speculation that Chrysler will build the JJ at its Toledo, Ohio, Jeep plant as a kit with major assemblies, such as body panels, interiors and powertrains, being made by suppliers. That would cut Chrysler's investment in the vehicle. The JJ will be designed to compete with the Daihatsu Rocky, Suzuki Sidekick and Geo Tracker.

DOC.HEAD: Stardent Strengthens Relationship with Company, Ousts Two Directors
DOC.TEXT: Stardent Computer Inc. shareholders voted Tuesday to strengthen the company's relationship with Kubota Computer of Japan and oust two board members who sued the Japanese firm. The removal of Allen Michels and Matthew Sanders III from the Stardent board of directors followed their dismissal last month as co-chairmen of the company, which makes graphics computers. Stardent was formed last year through the merger of Stellar Computer Inc., based in Newton, and Ardent Computer Corp. of Sunnyvale, Calif. Prior to the merger, Kubota owned 44 percent of Ardent, and now owns 22 percent of the combined companies. But in July, Michels and Sanders, who were the founders of Ardent, filed a lawsuit claiming that Kubota forced the merger in order to weaken Ardent and eventually gain its technology. After the suit was filed, the Stardent board of directors removed Michels and Sanders as co-chairmen. On Tuesday, shareholders voted to remove the two men from the board entirely. The company said the action was taken because Sanders and Michels were no longer officers or employees of the company. Roxanne Frisiello, a Stardent spokeswoman, insisted that the removal of the two men as co-chairmen had nothing to do with the lawsuit. Instead, it was due to ``differences in management style'' and the relocation of Sunnyvale offices to Newton, which eliminated the need for their positions. Under terms of the agreements approved by stockholders, Kubota will invest up to $60 million in Stardent over the next 12 months, raising Kubota's total stake in the company to 28 percent. In return, Stardent has granted certain technology and distribution rights and licenses to a Kubota subsidiary in San Jose, Calif. Kubota abstained from the voting, Frisiello said.

DOC.HEAD: Dayton Hudson Report Second-Quarter Earnings Increase
DOC.TEXT: Dayton Hudson Corp.'s earnings increased 7 percent in the second quarter as revenue increased 4.6 percent, the retailer announced Tuesday. Earnings in the three months that ended Aug. 4 were $59 million, or 75 cents per share, on revenue of $3.24 billion. For the same period last year, earnings were $56 million, or 72 cents per share, on revenue of $3.10 billion. Dayton Hudson operates Target, Mervyn's, Dayton's, Hudson's and Marshall Field's. ``Our fastest growing businesses, Target and Mervyn's, contributed to another solid performance and remain strong,'' said Chairman Kenneth A. Macke. For the first six months of this year, earnings were $123 million, or $1.56 per share, on revenue of $6.25 billion. For the first half of 1989, earnings were $96 million, or $1.23 per share, on revenue of $5.92 billion.

DOC.HEAD: Say Board of Trade Probing Possible Attempt to Corner Soybean Oil Market
DOC.TEXT: The Chicago Board of Trade said Tuesday it is keeping an eye on soybean oil futures purchases amid reports that a unit of grain-processing giant Archer Daniels Midland is trying to corner the market. Market cornering is considered an unfair trading practice in which one company controls so much of a commodity it can wield an enormous influence over the price to the disadvantage of other traders. The actions by the Chicago Board of Trade, one of the world's leading commodities exchanges, involves ADM Investor Services, an arm of ADM. The action comes about a year after the exchange issued an emergency order to break up a similar suspected attempt by an Italian firm. The Commodity Futures Trading Commission, the federal agency that regulates the futures industry, also said it was monitoring the market closely. At ADM headquarters in Decatur, Ill., aides said the firm had no comment. ADM is believed to hold more than half of all contracts for July and August delivery of soybean oil, the Wall Street Journal reported Tuesday. Board of Trade spokesman Michael Oakes said ``a considerable amount of bean oil has been purchased by ADM.'' ``I'm sure it's being handled by our business conduct committee, that they are looking into it,'' Oakes said. ``Until it reaches a point where we feel it's a threat, we just watch and monitor,'' he said. The board of trade determined there was a similar threat in July 1989, when it appeared that Ferruzzi SPA, one of the world's largest soybean processors, was trying to corner the soybean market. Ferruzzi had acquired large positions in the soybean market and owned more than four-fifths of all soybeans available for immediate delivery, exchange officials and regulators concluded. To keep Ferruzzi from gaining control over soybean prices, the CFTC ordered the firm to reduce its holdings by 20 million bushels. The Board of Trade then issued an emergency order requiring the liquidation of large positions in its July soybean contract. That touched off wild swings in bean prices and prompted sharp criticism by farm groups and traders who saw the value of their futures holdings plummet.
