DOC.HEAD: State Board To Review Cough-Medicine Abuse
DOC.TEXT: A state panel this month will consider restricting over-the-counter sales of Robitussin-DM and other cough remedies because they apparently have found a niche among teen-age drug abusers, officials said Tuesday. In one case last winter, police in the Pennsylvania community of Waynesboro discovered dozens of discarded cough medicine bottles at a park frequented by teens. An officer in the town of Williamsport said a local boy reportedly suffered kidney problems because of his long-term abuse of cough syrups. ``The fact is they are using the substance to get high,'' said Gerald Keenan, a physician's assistant in Waynesboro who has identified cases involving cough medicine abuse. ``We could not believe at the time we saw this that the level of intoxication ... was caused by cough syrup. We thought it was caused by alcohol or something else,'' he said. A group of pharmacists from south-central Pennsylvania has asked the state Department of Health to pull Robitussin and other cough medicines containing dextromethorphan from store shelves, placing it under the control of pharmacists. If the request is approved, medicines containing dextromethorphan, the most effective cough treatment on the market, could be purchased only by people 18 and older. Consumers would have to sign a form to buy the products, and would be permitted to purchase only 4 ounces within 72 hours. ``The department needs to address it in some manner,'' said Jack Ogun, administrative secretary of the state Drug, Device and Cosmetic Board. The change ``would take it off display, which would be the biggest crunch as far as sales,'' Ogun said. Dextromethorphan, the active ingredient in about 75 cough medicines including Robitussin and Vicks 44, first came on the market as a prescription medicine in the mid-1950s. It was approved for over-the-counter sales in 1976. Officials said the drug is safe and effective when taken as prescribed, but it can produce effects ranging from lightheadedness to hallucinations when ingested in large doses. Ogun said someone who drinks large amounts runs a risk of convulsions, a allergic reaction or a slowdown in bodily functions. He was unaware of any fatalities from abuse. There is no comprehensive information on the extent of abuses, but Ogun said he was aware of at least 50 cases statewide. ``We're concerned with it here locally because it's not illegal to buy it, possess it or drink it,'' said Waynesboro Police Chief Glenn Phenicie. ``It's probably been a problem longer than we realize,'' he added. Pennsylvania is not the first state to confront abuse linked to Robitussin and other cough preparations. In Utah, a group of parents led a successful campaign to have Robitussin voluntarily placed behind pharmacy counters. Police said they favored the proposal to limit access to cough syrups, but the Nonprescription Drug Manufacturers Association, an industry group, said such a move would create an inconvenience for legitimate consumers. For the industry, there is a lot at stake. According to Kline & Co., a New Jersey business consulting firm, the 14 leading cough syrups containing dextromethorphan have a wholesale market of about $625 million annually nationwide. Controlling sales ``would literally remove that convenient access to that medicine to the vast majority of people who use it safely and effectively,'' said Vincent Clough, an association spokesman. The industry would not oppose voluntary controls, Clough said. He added that the association was working with local officials in Waynesboro and had provided pamphlets for distribution. A.H. Robins, which manufacturers Robitussin cough syrups, said in a statement it was working with the association and other companies to address the misuse of dextromethorphan. The U.S. Food and Drug Administration has formed a task force that is looking into reported abuses of dextromethorphan. The state board on drugs, devices and cosmetics plans to hold a hearing on Aug. 28 on the pharmacists' request. A recommendation will be forwarded to the state secretary of health, who has the authority to reclassify drugs.
